Bicheteau, Bichot, a little • i • de-calf; alſo a meaſure for corn uſed in Burgundy, and containing a
•
• ut ſive of their buſhels.
Bicque, a Goat, or as biche.
Bidaulx, Bidaux, cowardly ſtragglers after an Army.
Bidon, a great cage, or open basket, to keep or feed poultry in.
Bienh • urer, to make happy, or proſperous.
Bife, Biffe, a counterfeit jewel, alſo a fool that would ſeem wiſe.
Bifer. See Biffer in the N. D.
Bifement, Biffeure, Bifferie, a raſing, defacing, or blotting out.
Biforme, that is of two ſeveral forms or ſhapes.
Bifourché, conſiſting of two forked parts.
Bigearrer, Bigearrure, Bigerrerie. See Bigarrer, and Bigarrure in the N. D.
Bigne, a ſwelling after a knock.
Bigorneau, Bigornet, a periwincle, or as Nerite.
Bigotage, Bigotation, Bigotie, Bigotiſe, ſuperſtitious devotion; alſo hypocriſie.
Bigotte, as chauſſes à la bigotte, cloſe breeches tyed below the knee.
Bigotter, to make ſuperſtitious, or to fill with hypocriſie.
Bihore, a word wherewith French Carters haſten on their horſes.
Bihoreau, a kinde of little heron.
Billard (Adj.) as pié billard, a ſplay foo • .
Billardier, that goes in at the knees.
Bille-boquet, a Gardeners line to meaſure beds and borders withal; alſo a bob.
Biller, to play at billiards; alſo to ſoften the 〈◊〉 of a boat to the wood which rans croſs the hams of the horſes that are to a • aw it.

B • llette, a • ill • t of wood; alſo a lit •••
• owl, ••• ewhat longer than an ordinary one; alſo a paſſage-toll.
Billos, certain Impoſts leavied upon Wines.
Binage, as Binement in the N. D.
Binotage, Binotement, Binotir, the ſecond digging of ſoil.
Binoter, to dig land the ſecond time.
Bipartient, parting, or dividing into two.
Bipedal, double footed; alſo two foot long or wide.
Biquoquet, the peak of a Ladies mourning-hood.
Birraſque, a high-going Sea, or a tempeſt at ſea.
Biſantin, as Beſant in the N. D.
Biſcapit, a double imployment of one ſum in an account.
Biſeau, ſuch a ſlopeneſs as is in the point of an iron leaver, &c.
Biſeté, wrought or ſtript with plate, as ſome kinde of ſtuffs be.
Biſette, plate of gold, ſilver, or copper, wherewith ſome ſtuffs are ſtriped.
Biſexte. See Biſſexte in the N.D.
Biſnoire, a forked mattock, or pick-axe.
Biſon, a kind of wild Ox.
Biſongne, as Biſon; alſo a raſcally fellow; alſo a raw ſouldier.
Biſlin • s, ſpruce terms, fine words.
Biſ • arde, a bird called Buſtard.
Biſtortier, a rolling-pin, or peſtle of wood.
Bite, beets. Prendre, du potage de la bite, to do that a maid ſhould not do.
Bites, the bits, two great wooden pegs whereto the cable is faſtened when an anchor is let fall.
Bivet, faire bivet, to make an end of a candle ſtick with a drop of tallow upon the edge of a candleſtick.
Bizarreure, diverſity of colours or faſhions in one ſubject.
Bizet, as Biſet in the N. D.
Bladier (Adj.) of, or belonging to corn.

Blaier, Seigneur Blaier, the Landlord that may amerce all ſuch Foreiners as turn their Cattel into the vaines paſtures, or waſt grounds belonging unto his Lordſhip, which without his permiſſion (paid for) they ought not to have done.
Blairie, Droit de Blairie, a Lords power to fine, &c. as you have it in the word Blaier. Pais de blairie, a Country plentiful of corn.
Blanchard, an Order of Friars going in white ſheets, and wearing neither hats nor ſhoes.
Blanche-puce, Blanche pute, the Sea-ground-pine (a whitiſh herb.)
Blanche-putain, the herb rank-goat, or ſtinking motherwort.
Blanche-queuë, the ravenous Kite, called a Kingtail.
Blanchet, a waſt-coat, a blanket for a bed; alſo the apple called a White-ſweeting.
Blanchette, fine white flour of wheat.
Blanes-ma ••••• , w • it • Cloaks, an Order of begging Friars.
Blancuier, a bird like a Whittail.
Blandir, to flatter, or ſooth up.
Blandiſſement, blandiſhment, flattering, or ſoothing up.
Blandureau, a kinde of white apple.
Blanquet, a ſort of the best white wine in Languedoc.
Blaſſer, to foment, moiſten, or bathe gently with the hand a hurt (eſpecially about a horſe.)
Blatir, to gather up, draw, or ſhrink in himſelf.
Blatte, a moth, a beetle, a kinde of red wheat, a ſilk-worm, a weeſel.
Blavier, of, or belonging to corn.

Blayeries, a corn-Ground, or corn-Country; alſo the feeding of cattle upon Corn-lands; alſo the ſeaſon (from the Annunciation to the end of harveſt) wherein cattle may in ſome places be turned by ſome priviledged perſons into common corn-grounds.
Bleche, Blecque, over-mellow. Pomme blecque, an apple that's too ripe, or too mellow.
Bledier, of, or belonging to corn. Terre-blediere, Corn-ground.
Blette, as poire blette, an over-ripe pear.
Bliſires, as Beliſtres; alſo the herb called Bleets.
Blocul, the chiefeſt pole that upholds a Tent; alſo a blockhouſe.
Blondir, Blondoyer, to grow light, or flaxen.
Blondoyement, a making, or becoming light yellow.
Bloquil, as Blocul in the firſt ſenſe.
Bloſſe, as poire bloſſe, an over-mellow pear.
Bloti, ſquat, hidden, or kept cloſe.
Blotir, to ſquat, alſo to hide, or keep cloſe.
Bluterie, a boulting, alſo a boulting-tub.
Bluttage, Blutement, a boulting of meal.
Bluttis, a boulting-tub, or a room to boult meal in.
Boage, a place in Abbeys full of drawers, wherein they lay up Copes, &c.
Bobance, Bobans, riot, luxury; alſo pride, inſolency.
Bobelin, a patch, or piece ſet on a ſhooe or garment.
Bobeline, an old patched ſhooe or garment.
Bobeliner, to patch, or to cobble.
Bobulaire, big, huge, unweildy like an Ox.
Boccaſin, for Bocaſſin, a kinde of fine buckram.
Bocque, a kind of fiſh, alſo a ſlace.
Boëtouyer, to halt, or be lame.
Boie, a kinde of great water-ſnake, that uſes to ſack whole herds of Kine.
Boiffer, to ſlubber over things in haſte.
Boiffeur, one that ſlubbers over things in haſte.
Boileau, Boileſve, an ordinary drinker of water.
Boiſe, a log, alſo a brace of timber.
Boiſſé, haſted, or trimmed with box.
Boiſſel d'oſier, a weel, or weer of oſ • er-twigs.
Boiſſelier, a maker, or ſeller of buſhel-meaſures.
Boitte (for boëte) a box. Boitte (for bote) de foin, a bottle of hay.
Bolar, a kinde of aſp-reſembling tree.
Bolet, Bolete, a little muſhroom, or toadſtool.
Boline, a rope uſed when a ſhip ſails with a ſide-wind, or goes near a wind.
Bollettes de Cypres, Cyprus nuts, or clogs.
Bolus, a morſel, or mouthful; alſo clay which hath no mineral ſubſtance in it.
Bombarder, to diſcharge a murthering piece.
Bombardier, a diſcharger of murthering pieces.
Bombycine, the worſe kinde of the Levant-Manna.
Bondelle, a fiſh much like a great ſmelt.
Bondener, to argue; alſo to grumble.
Bondonné, ſtopped up with a bung.
Bondonner, to ſtop up with a bung.
Bondrée, a kind of ſhort-winged Eagle.
Bonifier, to make good; alſo to make rich or wealthy.
Bonnes-dames, the herb Orage, or Golden-herb; alſo Beet.
Bonneter, to pull off his cap to one.
Bonniere, a meaſure of Land not much differing from the Arpent.
Bons-hommes, (for Minimes) an Order of Friars.
Borax, for Borras, Borax, a green Mineral.
Borborigme, the rumbling of the guts; alſo the murmuring noiſe of running waters.

Bordage, edge, ſide, or brim; alſo Villenage. Droict de bordage, the drudgery, or baſe ſervices reſerved by ſome Lords, upon the letting of their Cottages or ſmall Tenements; which cannot be given, ſold, nor ingaged by the poor ſlaves that have taken them.
Borde, a ſcattered houſe in the Country, a farm, or farm-houſe; alſo a ſtalk of pilled hemp.
Bordeliere, the name of a fiſh that reſembles a Bream, and hath neither teeth nor tongue.
Bordelois, the name of a very great grape.
Bordereau, a ticket, a bill, an account.
Borgner, to wink with one eye and look with another.
Borgneſſe, a woman that hath but one eye.
Borgnet, almoſt blinde of one eye.
Borgnoyer, to want an eye, to look or ſee but with one eye, to wink with one eye.
Borlet, for Bourlet, a roul of cloth.
Bornage, bounds, or limits. Droict de bornage, the Royalty of laying out bounds for other mens Lands.
Bornion à miel, a honey-comb, or bees-neſt full of honey.
Borret, a beaſt about a year old.
Borrette, a heifer about a year old.
Borriere, as vache borriere, a Cow that hath a Calf running after her.
Borrugat, the name of a Sea-fiſh.
Boſe, the name of an apple, alſo wood.
Boſcale, Champ boſcale, a piece of ground or Common (without any Houſe upon it) wherein divers have certain and ſeveral parts.
Boſquillon, a Wood-ſeller, or a Wood-cleaver.
Boſſeler, to bruiſe, or make a dint in a veſſel of metal or piece of plate.
Boſſelure, ſuch a kind of bruiſe.
Boſſetiere, a lettle bunch or knob; a little heap, riſing, or ſwelling of earth; a boſs ſet on a book; a ſtud on any part of a horſes furniture.
Boſſis, high grounds, or little hills raiſed by the hands of men.
Boſſuer, to make crooked; alſo to ſwell or puff up unevenly.
Bot, a wooden ſhooe, or patten; alſo an ill-favoured big piece of any thing.
Botaige, Temps de botaige, the time from the ninth of October to the laſt of November.
Botanique, of, or belonging to herbs.
Botanomantie, divination by the vertue of herbs.
Botargues, the hard rows of the Murene, or of a kind of Mullet ſalted, and then dri'd, and eaten, to provoke drinking.
Botineur, a buskin-maker; alſo one that continually wears boots or buskins.
Bortyte, Cadmia in grape-like cluſters gathered from the roofs of copper-houſes, or over the furnaces wherein copper is ordinarily melted or made.
Botte, Botter, and Botté. See them with a ſingle t in the N.D.
Botteler (for boteler) du foin, to make bottles of hay.
Bouäde, the Work of two Oxen, or Ʋſe of a ſmall Cart due certain days in Summer by Tenants (that hold by Socage or Villenage) unto their Landlords, for the labouring and dreſſing of their Vineyards.
Boubax, the name of a kind of Olives.
Boucal, a Weeſel, alſo a vent for the fire or heat of a furnace.
Boucaner, to do like a Goat.
Boucanier, out of date, out of ſeaſon.
Bouchard, a kind of great-eared brown Wheat.
Boucharde, a Maſons hammer, or pick, pointed at both ends like a diamond.
Bouchet, a kind of broth for a ſick body; alſo a drink made of water ſweetned with Sugar and Cinnamon.
Bouchonnet, a little wiſp, or ſtopple.
Bouconneux, full of ſtopples, wiſps of ſtraw, bunches, cluſters.
Bouclure, a buckling; alſo a ſwelling, or bearing out in the middle; alſo a buffetting.
Boucon, bit, morſel, mouthful. Bailler le boucon, to poyſon.
Bouconnier, a poyſonner, one that gives a poyſoned bit.
Boucquine, a rammiſh, or laſcivious quean.
Bouc-ſoufflé (for bourſoufflé) ſwoln, or puffed up with wind.
Boudinal, of, or belonging to a pudding.
Bouë de fer, the ſmall flakes that flie from a hot iron when 'tis beaten.
Bouée, a buoy for an anchor.
Bouëtte, as Bonnette; alſo a little box; alſo a wheel-barrow.
Bouffard, often puffing, alſo ſwelling with anger.
Bouffe, the part of our cheeks which we puff up in blowing or feeding, a ſwoln or ſwelling cheek.
Bouffe, puffed, blown, or ſwoln up.
Bouffement, a puffing, blowing, or ſwelling up.
Bouffer, to puff, blow, or ſwell up. Bouffer de courroux, to ſwell with anger.
Bouffiſſure, a ſwelling or puffing up; alſo a kinde of dropſy.
Bouffon, Bouffonner, Bouffonnerie. See them with a ſingle f in the N. D.
Boug, the little and venemous green frog, or hedge-toad. Boug coupé, a tortoiſe.
Bouge, valiſe, a budget, or wallet.
Bougeon, a bolt, or arrow with a great bead.
Bougier, to ſear with a wax-candle.
Bougiron, Bougironner, and Bougironné. See Bougeron, &c. in the N. D.
Bougrin, buggering, or fit for buggery. Chauſſes à la bougrine, ſtrait Venetians without codpieces.
Bouhourdi premier & ſecond, the firſt and ſecond Sunday in Lent.
Bouillonneux, boyling, or bubbling; alſo dirty; alſo full of puffs.
Boujon, a boult, an arrow with a great or broad head.
Boujotte, a pigeon-hole in a dove-coat.
Bouiſſiere, a plot of ground ſtored with Box.
Boular, the little round neſt of a Martin, Titmouſe, &c.
Bouldure d'un moulin, the conduit of a Mill, wherein the wheel goes.
Boulengé, baked, or made into bread.
Boulenger, (a Verb) to bake, or make into bread.
Boulerot, a kinde of Gudgeon that lives continually in mud.
Boulieux, of, or belonging to pap.
Boulin, a pigeon-hole in the Dove-coat.
Boulinage, a laying of tack aboard, or ſailing with a ſide-wind.
Bouller, to cozen, alſo to box.
Boullonné, puffed, or drawn out with puffs.
Bouloers (or Bouloirs) d'un vis, the circles or circling of a ſcrue.
Boulon, a great peg of wood wherewith Carpenters joyn great pieces of timber together. Boulon de fer, a great pin of iron, ſuch as Tradeſmen ſhut in their ſhop-windows withal.
Boulture, a boyling, ſeething, or bubbling.
Bouquer, to kiſs another mans thumb; to take or give a kiſs; alſo to ſtrike ſail, or to pay cuſtome.
Bouquetier, (Adj.) of, or belonging to noſegays, or noſegay-like.
Bourache, as Borrache; alſo a little candle-caſe; alſo an engine (like a candle-caſe) wherewith fiſh is caught.
Bourachon, a ſmall leather-bottle; alſo a candle-caſe; alſo a drunkard, or toſs-bottle.
Bouras, the tow of hemp, the courſeſt part of any ſuch like ſtuff.
Bourbelier, the breaſt, or eſſay of a wild ſwine.
Bourbeter, to wallow in the dirt, alſo to mutter.
Bourbeteux, full of mud or dirt, alſo loving dirt or mud.
Bourbetre, a ſmall freſh-water-fiſh, that altogether lives on, and lies in mud.
Bourboulene, the name of a Vine.
Bourdaine, a kinde of hedge-tree, exceedingly loved by ſtags.

Bourdelage, a Tenure in the Dominion of Nevers, whereby the Tenant is bound to pay unto his Landlord a yearly Rent in money, corn, and feathers, or in any two of them; which if he omit three years together, he forfeits his eſtate.
Bourdelois, a certain Vine or Grape that yields very ſowr wine, and therefore it is uſually ſet about Arbours, more for the ſhadow than for the fruit it yields.
Bourdelaſier, full of jeſts, or tales.
Bourder, to tell tales, to ſell a bargain to one.
Bourdeur, a tale-teller, a jeſter, a guller.
Bourdonnaſſes, a faſhion of great hollow launces uſed in old time.
Bourdonneur, a hummer, or buzzer; alſo a player upon a bag-pipe.
Bourdonniere, the gudgeon that's in the top of a bar or hinge-band of a gate.
Boureler, &c. See Bourreler under Bourre in the N. D.

Bourgage, a Townſhip, or Boroughſhip, the Inhabitants of Houſes in Lands belonging to a Town or Borough; alſo an eſtate or tenure in Bourgage, held either of the King, or of other Lords of the Borough, and ſubject to no other than the cuſtomary rents and ſervices thereof.
Bourgalois, a Spaniſh coin worth about 18 d. ſterl.
Bourgeonneux, full of buds, richly ſet with pimples.
Bourguignotte, a burganet, or Spaniſh murrion.
Bourjaſſotte, the name of a certain fiſh.
Bourjon, Bourjonner, as Bourgeon, Bourgeonner in the N. D.
Bourrachiere, as Corneille bourrachiere, a royſten crow.
Bourrade, a ſtorm, or tempeſt; alſo the cuffing or ruffling of a bird by a hawk; alſo the toſſing or muzzling of a hare by a greyhound before he bear her.
Bourraquin, as Bourrabaquin, or a Spaniſh leather-bottle.
Bourras, (for borras) borax; alſo ſilkraſh; alſo courſe canvas.
Bourrée, a fagot of twigs, a bundle of any ſuch like ſtuff.
Bourrelet, (for bourlet) a wreath, or roul of cloth.
Bourrette, the uppermoſt part of the clue or ball of ſilk yielded by the ſilk-worm, the courſeſt of ſilk.
Bourriquet, a kinde of tumbrel or dung-cart; alſo as Bourrique, an aſs.
Bours de Chevres, ſtables for goats.
Bourſal, (Adj.) of a younger brother. Fief bourſal, the portion belonging to a younger brother.
Bourſalement, by the title of Youngerſhip, different from that of the elder Brother, who is to do homage unto the Lord for the whole Inheritance.
Bourſavit, a purſe for a mans yard; alſo a kinde of big leathern purſe.
Boursé, put up in a purſe; alſo bulching, or bearing out, as a full purſe.
Bourſer, to put up in a purſe.
Bourſeteux, Bourſeaux, purſe-like; full of purſes; belonging to a purſe.
Bourſiller, the ſame; alſo to put his hand into ones purſe.
Bourſouffleure, any ſwelling, puffing, or blowing up.
Bouſant, Bouſat, a buzzard, or bald kite.
Bouſe, Bouſée de vache, a cowturd.
Bouſet, petit bouſet, a little odious fellow, a paltry crop of a cowturd.
Bousfler, to puff up, or blow wind into.
Bouſin, a ſoft and mouldring ſubſtance that cleaves to the outſide of freeſtone in quarries.
Bouſinier, as pierres bouſinieres, ſoft and mouldring ſtones, apt to melt away in water, or by weather.
Bouſſade, the rot, or plague among ſheep.
Bouſſe, a bunch, the bunch of a Camels back.
Boutage, Droict de boutage, a certain Duty or Fee exacted by the Lord of Breci (a Member of Bourges) for the wine retailed within his Juriſdiction.
Boutant, thruſting forward; alſo budding, or putting forth.
Bouſé, thruſt forward, alſo budded or put forth.
Boute-cul, a new Monk, or Friar.
Boutée, a thruſt, a jert, a violent attempt; alſo a budding.
Boutefoire, a certain ſhitten yew game.
Bouteillerie, a cupboard, or table to ſet bottles on.
Bouteillette, a ſmall bottle, or bubble.
Bouterolle, the chape of a ſcabbard.
Bouticle, for boutique, a ſhop; alſo a well, or lepe, for fiſh.
Bouticlier, a ſhop-keeper, or he that looketh to a ſhop.
Boutignan, the name of a kinde of Olive.
Boutillier, as Bouteiller in the N. D.
Boutis, the rooting of a wild boar; alſo as boutement.
Boutonnerie, a buttoning, or claſping; alſo a budding, or ſprouting out; alſo a cauterizing.
Boutonneur, a buttoner, or an inſtrument wherewith buttons are pulled through their over-ſtrait holes.
Boutouër, the ſnout of a wild ſwine.
Bouts, a great bottle, or as Oudre.
Boutrice, an aſhler, or binding-ſtone in building.
Boutture, as Bouture under Bout in the N. D.
Bouvi, as qui ſent le bouvi, ſmelling like an Ox.
Bouzine, a ruſtical Trumpet or wind-Inſtrument, made of pitched bark.
Bozel, a thick or great boultel commonly in or near unto the baſis of a pillar.
Braçal, for Braſſal, an Archers brace, or bracer.
Braçats, vambraces, an armour for the arms.
Brachial, Brachieux, of, or belonging to the arm.
Brachialement, with main force of arms.
Bragarder, to flaunt it, to ſwagger.
Brague, a kind of mortaiſe, or joyning of pieces together.
Bragues, ſhort and cloſe linnen-breeches worn next unto the thighs.
Bragueſques, large Venecians having Cod-peeces, and gathered, or full of ſtuff at the knees.
Braguette, a cod-piece. Bonnet à quatre braguettes, a four-ſquare cap.
Brailler, to make a great noiſe, to cry out.
Brain, the branch of a tree.
Braiſillonner, to roast upon quick coals.
Brancal, and Brancas, as Brancar in the N. D.
Branchet, as Eſpervier branchet, a brancher, or young hawk, newly come out of the nest.
Branchiere, a Paſſage-toll, ſo called, becauſe the little log that's a ſigne thereof hangs on the branch of a Tree.
Branchieres, the out-places, or parts of the highway wherein the ſaid logs or billets have been a long time hung up.
Brandif, brandiſhing, luſty. Il mangea un gigot de mouton tout brandif, he eat a whole leg of mutton.
Brandonner, to ſeize land by pitching down into it a ſtaff topped with ſtraw.
Brane, boeuf brane, a kind of wilde Ox in Languedoc and Provence fit onely for the Shambles.
Branglage, a kind of Toll or Tax.
Branquar, as Brancar in the N. D. alſo the edge of the Deck of a ſhip.
Branque urſine, an herb called Brankurſine, or Bears breech.
Braque, for Brac, a little hound.
Braquemar, ou Braquemard, a wood-knife, hanger, whineyard.
Braſer, to ſlope the edge of a ſtone, as Maſons do in windows, &c. for the gaining of light.
Braſiller, Braſillonner, to broyl upon quick coals, or hot embers.
Braſſage, the fee which the Maſters of the Mint have out of every ſort of money coyned.
Braſſart, and Braſſat, as Braſſal in the N. D.
Braſſier, a Brazier; alſo a ſling; alſo a cudgel; alſo the tab that receives the droppings of a tap; alſo a labouring man.
Braſſiere, a womans or a childs waſtcoat; alſo the doublet ſome women wear in child-bed; alſo the arm or branch of a river; alſo a brace; one of the ſtaves whereby men turn the beam of a Crane, &c.
Brater un Chariot, to turn, ſet, or bend a cart on the right or left hand.
Brave (a Subſt.) the reward or prize for him that hath done best in Plays or Games.
Braveux, he that gives the prize.
Brayant, Brayart, braying, or crying like an Aſs.
Brayer, Brayement. See Broyer, broyement in the N. D.
Brayetter la chemiſe, to put his ſhirt between the legs. La Langue me brayette, my tongue trips, or faulters.
Brayeul, the parts or feathers about the hawks fundament, called the brail in a ſhort-winged, and the pannel in a long-winged hawk.
Breant, the bird called a Siskin.
Brebiette, a little ſheep, or ew.
Breborions, old dunſical books; alſo charms againſt the tooth-ach, &c.
Breché, having a breach made in it.
Brechedent, one that wants divers teeth, or as Breſchedent.
Brecheure d'une Riviere, a breach in a River.
Bredaille, a great paunch, or belly.
Bredouillard, one that ſpeaks or pronounces imperfectly.
Bredouille, a lurch at Cards or Tables. Ma p • tite bredouille, my little rogue.
Bredouiller, to ſpeak, or pronounce imperfectly.
Brehaigne, a barren woman or female, or (adjectively) barren.
Breil de foreſt, a thick-grown wood, or corner of a forest, wherein wilde beaſts uſe to lurk.
Breits, for Bray, a kind of ſhippitch.
Brelm, Brelandier. See Berlan, Berlandier in the N. D.
Brelengue, Brelingue, a piece of coin worth about 8 pence ſterl.
Breller, to bat-fowl, to catch birds by bat-fowling, alſo to twinkle, or glitter.
Brelue, for Berlue, dimneſs of ſight.
Bremant, as il n'a enfant ne bremant, he hath neither childe nor chick to care for.
Bremer, for Bramer, to cry out like a Hart.
Breſche, the name of a very hard and ſundry-coloured marble.
Breſchedent, as Brechedent; alſo an Ironical alluſion to Preſident.
Breſillé, made red as Braſil-wood. Boeuf breſillé, Martlemas-beef.
Breſin, the hook of a Crane, and in a ſhip the Cane-hook.
Breſſaudes, the criſpy mammocks that remain of fri'd hogs greaſe.
Breſſaux, a kind of fine cakes, or wafers, or as Pain de Quinque.
Breſſe, a bruſh; alſo a thin leaf or cake of wax, &c.
Breſſille des yeux, the twinkling of the eyes.
Breſſiller, to twinkle with the eyes.

Bret, a little Engine (made of two ſticks joyned together) wherewith Fowlers catch ſmall birds whilst they wonder at an Owl that's ſet of purpoſe to amaze them; alſo as Bray in the N. D. Etre, ou parler bret, to ſtammer.
Breteque, Breteſche, Breteſque, and Brethecque, a publick place in a Town wherein Out-cries and Proclamations are ordinarily made; alſo a port, or portal of defence, in the rampire or wall of a Town.
Bretonner, to ſpeak thick and ſhort; alſo to ſtammer.
Bretteſſe, the Battlements of a wall.
Bretueil, the iron piece called a fowler, or port-piece.
Brevade, Brevetade, as Brevet under Brief in the N. D.
Breveter, to abbreviate, to reduce into briefs or breviates.
Breuvoer, liquor, or any liquid ſtuff that's fit to be made into drink.
Breze, for braiſe, a burning coal.
Brezil, for breſil, the wood Brazil.
Bribe, a piece of bread given to a beggar.
Briber, to beg his bread; to eat greedily; to run up and down.
Bribeur, a beggar, a greedy eater; a goer up and down.
Bribonner, to mumble up his Prayers.
Bric, as Prendre au bric, to take advantage of a word ſpoken by another, alſo to give a dead liſt.
Bricot, the ſtump of a ſhrub, or little tree; an up-ſticking ſtub of a latecut ſhrub or tree.
Bridaveaux, hollow, round, and wreathed cracknels of fine flour, ſugar, ſalt, and yolks of eggs incorporated together with water and white-wine.
Bridoye, a gooſe-bridler (a Nickname for a Lawyer.)
Briemart, poor folks drink (made of bran, leaven, and water.)
Briere, as Bruyere in the N. D.
Brigande, for brigade, a great body of horſe-men.
Brigandin, for Brigantin, the Brigantine Veſſel.
Brigandine, an ancient armour ſo called.
Brignon, the name of an excellent plum.
Briguerie, an underhand ſuing for an Office; alſo a wrangling, or contending; alſo a ſharking, or robbing.
Briguet, a mongrel; alſo one that is nobly born but of one ſide.
Brihat, one that is hot and loud.
Brillonner, for briller, to ſparkle, or glitter.
Brimbaler, ſonner trop fort les cloches, to ſet the bells agate.
Brimbales, the bells worn by Carthorſes.
Brimballotier, Brimbeur, Brimblotier, a paultry Pedlar, one that hath nought but traſh to ſell; alſo a ſpangle-maker.
Brimborions, as Breborions; alſo the knacks or bawbles wherewith fools caps, &c. are garniſhed. Il dit ſes brimborions (for breviaire) he mumbles up his prayers.
Brindell • s de balay, the ſprigs or twigs of a beeſom.
Brioche, a brake for hemp; alſo a rowl or bun of ſpiced bread.
Brioler, to glide, or ſlide on the ice.
Briquer, to lay bricks, or to build with bricks.
Briquet, as Briguet; alſo a young hare.
Briqueux, full of bricks, or fit for bricks.
Briſche, a buſh made of lime-twigs, and a ſtale hung at it to draw birds unto it.
Briſe, a piece of ground that's new broke up for tillage, and hath lai • long untilled.
Briſette, a little ſcale or husk, a little ſplint or ſhiver broken off any thing.
Britaſcher, as j'ai ouï britaſcher d'une telle choſe, I have heard ſome ſuch muttering.
Briz, as Bris under Briſer in the N. D.
Brizer, for Briſer, to bruiſe, to break.
Brocar, for Brocatel, Satin purfled with gold; alſo a cutting jeſt.
Brochard, as Brocar; alſo a peg of wood.
Brode, broth, pottage, brue; alſo a Sun-burnt wench. Pain de brode, brown bread; Langage brode, a looſe or an effeminate language.
Brodes, a leather cloak or mantle.
Bronchique, as muſcle bronchique, one of the four Muſcles which open the Larinx.
Brondes, green boughs, brouze-wood, or brouzing for cattle.
Brot, a drinking Jack; a flagon, or great tankard. Un brot de vigne, the bud of a Vine.
Brouailles, waſhing of diſhes; alſo guts and garbage of fowl; any ſuch outcaſt traſh.
Broüée, a miſt, or fog; alſo a bluſter, hurry, or hurly-burly.
Brouëtteur, one that works with a wheel-barrow.
Brouffer, to ſnurt with the noſe, like a horſe.
Brouhaha, Brouhou, a bluſter, hurry, hurly-barly.
Brouil, for Brou, the outward husk of a green walnut.
Brouillar, Brouillas, a miſt, or fog.
Brouillaſſer, Brouillaſſeur. See Brouiller, & Brouillon in the N.D.
Brouïné, blaſted, or burnt with miſts.
Brouïr, to ruſtle, or bluſter; alſo to humme.
Brouïſſement, a ruſtling, or bluſtering; alſo a humming.
Brouſſaille, as Broſſailles in the N. D.
Brouſſin, a bunch, or knurr in a tree.
Broute, the root of the box-tree ſeaſoned and fit for uſe.
Brouteur, a brouzer; alſo as Brouëtteur.
Broüyr, to burn, or parch with heat.
Bruchet, the craw-bone, or merry-thought of a bird.
Bruel, Brueil, the brail, or pannel of a hawk.
Brugier, to bellow, or make a hideous noiſe.
Brugne, a faſhion of Corſelet, or Brigandine uſed in old time.
Bruiement, Bruiment, a rumbling, ruſtling, or bluſtering.
Bruiné, blaſted and burned with miſt; alſo hoary.
Bruinement, a blaſting or burning with hot miſts; alſo a glazing over.
Bruiner, to blaſt or burn with hot miſts; alſo to glaze, or ſet a hoary gloſs on.
Bruineux, full of hot blaſting miſts.
Brumal, of, or belonging to winter, or winter-like.
Bruman, a ſon-in-law, the husband of a daughter.
Brumbay, brown bay, or dark bay.
Brume, the ſhorteſt day in the year; alſo the midſt of winter; alſo winter.
Brumeſtre, the name of a kinde of Vine.
Bruncher, Brunchement. See Broncher, Bronchement in the N. D.
Bruneau, clos bruneau, the bum, the arſ • .
Bruni d'un Cerf, the burniſhing of a Stags head.
Bruſ • able, apt to be burnt.
Bruſquet, as vin bruſquet, brisk, or ſharp wine.
Brute-bonne, the name of a pear.
Brutif, clowniſh, alſo raſh, heedleſs. Parler brutif, to falter in his ſpeech.
Brutivement, clowniſhly, rudely; alſo raſhly, heedleſly; alſo faulteringly.
Bubelette, Bubette, a red pimple on the noſe, &c.
Buberiges, dogs leeks, or the herb that bears the purple ſtarry Jacint.
Bubon, a great bunch, a plague-ſore, or a pockie-ſore.
Bucail, Buccail, the courſe grain called French-wheat.
Buccine, a Cornet, or Trumpet for the Wars; alſo the horn of a Cow-herd or Swine-herd; alſo the ſhell-fiſh called Venus-ſhell.
Bucheronner, to cleave, or cut down wood; to make faggots, &c.
Bucquer, as Buquer; alſo to but, or jurr.
Buer, to waſh a buck, to ſcowr with lie.
Buffe, a cuff, or box on the ear.
Buffelin, buff-like; of, or belonging to a buffle.
Buffer, to puff, or blow hard; alſo to ſpout water on.
Buffeté, wrought rough or ſhag like buff; buffeted, cuffed; deaded as wine that hath taken wind, or hath been mingled with water.

Buffeter, to make rough or ſhag like buff; alſo to buffet, or cuff; alſo to marr a veſſel of wine by often
taſting it before it is broached, or to fill it up with water after much wine hath been taken out of it.
Buffeteurs de vin, ſuch as ſteal wine out of the Veſſels they have in charge, and afterwards fill them up with water.
Buffetolt, the fiſh called a Lump, Padle, or Sea-owl.
Bugie, the bark of a barbary-tree.
Bugle, middle Conſound, or middle Comfrey.
Bugleux, full of bellowing, often or much lowing.
Bugleſat, of bugloſs, made of bugloſs.
Bugrande, Bugrane, Bugrate, Bugrunde, Reſt-harrow, Cammock.
Buire, an oyl-glaſs, viol, or cruze.
Buirette, a cruet, or little viol, or a cider-jugg.
Buiſine, Buiſſine, a little pipe, a water-pipe.
Buiſſonner, to lye in wait for among buſhes.
Buiſſonneux, buſhy, or full of buſhes.
Buiſſonnier, (Adj.) of, or belonging to buſhes; frequenting or haunting buſhes; living or lurking among buſhes. Faire l'eſchole buiſſonniere, to play the truant.
Buler, as Bugler; alſo to ſend a Bull, as Popes do; to execute or excommunicate by Bull.
Buliſte, of, or belonging to a bull; a writer, or maker of bulls.
Bullage, the ſ • aling of cloth, the marking thereof with a ſeal of lead.
Bullé, ſealed with lead, as a Bull; alſo that hath obtained the Popes Bull for ſome particular advancement or privilege to himſelf.
Bulletin, a T • cket, a Cocket. Bulletins are among the Gray-Friars ſuch as have been reformed by the Pope's bulls.
Bullettes, ſuch bubbles or bobs of glaſs as women wear for pendants at their ears.
Bullonner, to run, boyl, or burſt out in great abundance.
Bullot, a certain great, yellow, and ſowr apple.
Buon, the beak of an ewer or pot, the mouth of a cruet, viol, &c. alſo a little oyl-pot.
Bupreſte, the venemous black fly, called a long-leg, or wag-leg.
Buquer, to knock, or to rap at a door.
Bur, as Bureau in the N. D.
Burail, Burat, ſilk-raſh, or any kinde of ſtuff that's half ſilk and half wooſted.
Burate, that which remains in a Churh after the butter is taken out; alſo as Burail.
Burgrave, the Captain or Governour of a Fortreſs.
Buriot, a young duckling newly crept out of the ſhell.
Burler, to howl; alſo to jeſt with.
Burne, the ſolitary place or corner wherein an Owl ſits in the daytime.
Burnie, as main burnie, ward, cuſtody.
Burrier, a ſeller of butter; alſo a great eater of butter, a butter-box.
Burſauli, Cane-withy, with the yellowiſh bark.
Buſchetter, to gather ſticks for the fire.
Buſchettes, Buſchilles, ſmall twigs or ſprigs.
Buſine, the pipe of a Ciſtern or Conduit; alſo a bag-pipe.
Buſquer, chercher fortune, to ſeek his fortune.
Bu • ſirt, a ſort of Wine-veſſel.
Buſſe de raiſins, a great Veſſel, wherein raiſins be put or tranſported.
Buſte, the whole bulk of a man from his face to his middle; alſo a Tomb, or Sepulchre.
Buſtuaire, burnt as a dead body, or expecting the ſacrifice of mens bodies.
Buteux, of, or belonging to a butt, full of butts.
Butineux, full of prey, ſpoil, booty.
Buttel, for Hotte, a ſort of basket, called a Doſſer.
Buvable, fit to be drunk of.
Buvetier, an Officer that gathers money for the Judges Collations.
Buvettes, ſippings, tipplings; and particularly the Judges Drinkings or Collations.
Buxolle, for Bouſſole, a Mariners Compaſs.
Buydon, a Poulterers Cage or Coop, where he feeds his chickens and other fowl in.
Buyrette, as Burete under Bure in the N. D.
Buyſer, to bore, or make holes into.
Buyſé, bored, that hath holes made into it.
Buy • ronne, a furnace to melt and fine ſ ••• n in.
CAbab, the chucking of a Partridge.
Cababezancé, loaded with bags and wallets, alſo commented on.
Cabal, the money, or merchandiſe, which one takes of another, to yield him part of the gain that's made thereof.
Cabalanizer, to drink like a horſe.
Cabalin, of, or belonging to a horſe.
Cabaliſte, a Cabaliſt, a Profeſſor of the Jewiſh Traditions.
Cabaliſtique, of, or belonging to the Jewiſh Cabal or Traditions.
Cabaretrer, to frequent ale-houſes, or the like.
Cabaſſé, put, or packed up in a frail.
Cabaſſer, to fill a frail with raiſins.
Cabaſſet, a ſleight helmet. Cabaſſet de papier, a long hood or miter of paper.
Cabaſſon, the name of a fiſh.
Cabeçon, as Caveſſon in the N.D.
Cabeſtant, the Capitane of a ſhip.
Cabirots, the ſpawn of Sturgeons ſpread upon bread, and eaten with vinegar, oyl, and pepper.
Cable, for abbatis, a wind-fall, a tree overthrown by winde or tempeſtuous weather.
Cabochard, Cabochenu, Cabocheux, heady, or obſtinate.
Cabot, Cabote, the gull-fiſh, or mull-head.
Cabriole, for capriole, a caper in dancing.
Cabrioter, to caper, to cut a caper.
Cabrol, an iſſue made of a fiſtula.
Cabrole, the name of a fiſh.
Cabuſſer, to grow to a head, like a Cabbidge.
Cacaſſement de poule, the cackling of a hen.
Cacaſſer, to ch ••• as a Partridge.
Cache, as Chaſſe in the N. D. alſo a hiding-hole or corner.
Cache-col, an ancient velvet attire, or ornament for the neck.
Cachectique, in a Conſumption, pining away.
Cachelaid, Cachelet, a mask, or muffler.
Cachemi-tula, a Play wherein one muſt keep a thing privately delivered him, and another finde out the keeper among many others; which if he do, he is rewarded, otherwiſe puniſhed.
Cache-muſeau, a kinde of flawn; alſo a mufler, or mask, for the face.
Cachexie, an indiſpoſition of the body.
Cachotte, for Cachette, a ſecret place.
Cachotté, laid in the hole of a priſon.
Cacidoine, for calcedoine, Chalcedony, a kinde of Onyx-ſtone.
Cacoëthe, an incurable bile, or ſore.
Cad d'eau, a great fall, or ſhower of rain.
Cadarce, the tow, or co •• ſiſt part of ſilk.
Cade, the crimzon, or prickly cedar.
Cadel, a caſtling, a ſtar •• ling, one that hath much need of pampering.
Cadelé, pampered, made much of. Lettres cadelées, capital or 〈◊〉 -Lett • s.
Cadeler, to pamper; alſo to write a Text-hand, or make great Letters.
Cafarde, as a la cafarde, hypocritically.
Cafarder, to pretend devotion, to play the hypocrite.
Cafas, a kinde of courſe Taffata.
Cafetin, as ſuere cafetin, refined ſugar.
Cafezate, the name of a moſt venemous and malignant Serpent.
Caffard, as cafard, an hypocrite; alſo a beetle that flies by night.
Cagerotte, a Chesford, or Cheesfat (of wicker.)
Cagnaſque, as parler cagnaſque, to ſpeak doggery.
Cagnot, a little Dog; alſo a kind of little Dog-fiſh that hates men extreamly.
Cagot, for bigot, a ſuperſtitious man.
Cagoulle, a Monks hood, or cowl.
Caguemaille, Cagueraffe, a greedy wretch, a ravenous oppreſſor.
Cahier, for Cayer, a ſheet (or more) of a written book.
Cahot, the jogg of a Coach in a rough and uneven way.
Cahoter, to jog as a Coach.
Caignarder, to play the lazie rogue.
Caignart, as Caignard; alſo a naſty place or corner wherein Beggars lie in the Sun and lowſe themſelves.
Caigne, a Bitch; alſo Gods me, or the like Inter • ection of wonder.
Caignon, the hinder part of the r •• k.
Caillat, Caillebotes, c •• dy of milk.
Caillel oteux, full of 〈◊〉 . Licus cailleboteux, craggy, ſto •• , or rockie places.
Cailles, round Beads wherewith French-men play at Trou-madame.
Caillette, a fool, a natural; alſo a Rams cod; alſo the outward skin of the cods; alſo a ſmall bead.
Caillon, a congealed lump of flegm, bloud, &c.
Cailloroſat, a Lording-apple; alſo a green and great Pear of a pleaſant taſte.
Caillouët, the name of a very ſweet Pear.
Caillouëux, full of ſmall, hard, and ſharp ſtones.
Caimander, to beg from door to door.
Caïon, a young, or little Hog.
Caire, the look of ones face.
Cairin, a Turkie-carpet, ſuch as is brought from Caire in Egypt.
Caiſſans, the ſide-teeth, called the Grinders.
Calage, the Caulking of a Ship; alſo Oakam, or the Tow wherewith it is caulked.
Calabaſſe, a bottle made of an empty'd Gourd.
Calamar, a Pennar; alſo the Calamary, or Sleeve-fiſh.
Calame, a Cane, or Reed; Wheaten, or Oaten-ſtraw; Pipe, or Flute, &c.
Calaminaire, as Pierre calaminaire. See Calamine in the N. D.
Calamite (Adp.) of, or belonging to Reeds, or kept in Reeds.
Calandre, as Calendre in the N. D.
Calangement, an accuſation, or ch • r • e.
Calanger, to accuſe of, to charge with.
Calar, as Caler; alſo to be ſilent, 〈◊〉 talking, deſist from babbling.
Calathe, a basket, or hamper; alſo a Veſſel to bring milk or cheeſe to Market in; alſo a cup for ſacrifice.
Calcioler, to ſtand much on a matter, or to urge a thing often.
Calcitrer, to kick, or fling; to be ſtubborn, obſtinate, diſobedient.
Calderon, a kind of long and round Whale.
Cale, a ſorry kind of cap.
Calenge, a claim; alſo a challenge; alſo a charge, or accuſation; alſo an arrest; alſo a ſeizure of, or complaint against beaſts that are found damage ſeſant.
Calengé, claimed; challenged; accuſed of, or charged with; arreſted; ſeized.
Calenger, to claim; to challenge; to accuſe of, or charge with; to arrest; to ſeize.
Calepiner, to interpret, or tranſlate exactly, or word by word.
Calepinerie, a preciſe interpretation of every ſingle word.
Caleſſon, for Calçon, a pair of drawers.
Calfactif, apt to heat or warm.
Calfat, an Officer in a Gally that looks to the caulking thereof.
Calfaterie, the caulking of a ſhip.
Calfatin, the ſervant of a Caulker of a Galley.
Calfreter, for Calf • utrer, to caulk a ſhip.
ſe Calibrer à quelcun, to equal himſelf to one.
Calicules, little cups or goblets; alſo the rough ſhells of Cheſnuts; alſo the parings of a corn or kernel; alſo little skins upon any tender part of the body.
Caliges, flockings; alſo an armour for the legs; alſo breeches. Faire caliges, ou caligas, to bewray his hoſe.
Calin, a beggarly rogue, or lazie vagabond.
Caliot, the name of a Pear.
Callate, a ſtoping piece of ground, the deſcent of a hill.
Calle, for Cale, the hold of a ſhip.
Caller, as Caler; alſo to kittle.
Calles, Corns in the feet or toes.
Calique, the name of a fiſh.
Caloniere, a Pot-gun made of a quill or elder-ſtick.
Calvainier, Calvanier, a Hireling for the time of Harvest.
Calvatré, laid all-along on his back.
Calvan, pomme de calvan, a certain Apple that hath a blackiſh rind.
Camarine, the name of a ſtinking herb that provokes vomit.
Camarre, a Martingale for a horſe.
Cambouy, Camboy, the gome, the black and ovly greaſe of a wrought Cart-wheel.
Camelin, as alier le Camelin, to pace like a Camel. S •• ce Cameline, a certain dainty Italian Sauce.
ſe Cameloter, to become waved like Chamlet.
Cameraire, a Chamberlain, a Groom of the Chamber.
Camiete, the name of a certain ſweet Apple.
Camion, the pin wherewith women pin in their ruffs, &c. alſo a kinde of little Cart; alſo a ſmall muſe-role for a horſe.
Camote, the name of an Indian root, which roaſted is very good meat.
Camoufflet, a ſmoakie paper held under the noſe of a ſleeper.
Campal, of, or belonging to a Camp.
Campane, a Bell; alſo the herb Elicampane; alſo an Alembick, or the upper part thereof, which reſembles a Bell.
Campanette, Hedge-bells; alſo the Peach-bell, or Steeple-bell-floor.
Campole, the name of a certain white grape.
Campoles, the tendrels, or twining ſprigs of plants.
Campos, leave to play, or a vacation-time for Scholars.
Canabaſſer, to canvas, to ſift out.
Canabaſſerie, Canabaſſement, a canvaſſing, or ſifting out.
Canabel, a kind of earth which (as Arabians report) falls with rain from the Skie.
Canaliere, the name of a pear.
Cancelareſque, Chancery-like, of, or belonging to Chancery.
Canceler, to cancel, blot, or put out.
Candide, white, fair; alſo proſperous, happy; alſo courteous, fair-conditioned; alſo upright, ſincere, innocent.
Canelle, for robinet, a cock, or tap.
Canellé, of Cinnamon, of a Cinnamon-colour; alſo made of, or ſeaſoned with Cinnamon.
Canepetiere, a kind of land-fowl reſembling a Buſtard. Il fait de la canepetiere, he cowardly hides himſelf in every hole.

Canepin, the thin inner-rind of the bark of the Linden, and the outward of the coat of a Birchtree, written on in old time inſtead of Paper; alſo the outward thin and white pilling of a dreſſed Sheeps-skin.
Canepineuſe, the bark of a Sugarcane.
Canet, a young Duck, or a wild Duck.
Caneter, to waddle, or go like a Duck; alſo to breed young Ducks.
Canetier, of a Duck, like a Duck, catching Ducks, feeding or preying on Ducks.
Caneton, Canette, a Duckling; alſo a little Can or Cruſe; alſo the quill of a Spinning-wheel.
Canjar, Caniard, a Sea-cob, a Sea-gull.
Canidé, the name of a bird.
Canin, dogged, or dog-like. Convulſion canine, the cramp of the mouth.
Caniſſe, a little table or hurdle of reeds, whereon fruits are dri'd, or Silk-worms fed.
Canneau du col, the nape of the neck.
Canniſade, a cage, or basket of reeds.
Cannule, a little Cane, Reed, Pipe, or hollow ſtraw.
Cannulé, hollowed like a Reed, or Cane, alſo channelled.
Canolle, a Hawks narel, one of the little holes whereat ſhe draws in and lets out her breath.
Canoniſte, a Practicer in the Canon-Law.
Canthare, a duskie and muddy Sea-fiſh that never changes her mate; alſo a great jug, or as
Cantharide, for Cantaride, a fly called Cantharides.
Canthenot, a certain tawny and unſavoury Sea-fiſh.
Canton, for coin de rue, a corner, or croſs-way in a ſtreet.
ſe Cantonner, ſe mettre en un coin, to go aſide from the rest.
Canule, a little Cane, reed, or Pipe.
Canus, the name of a Sea-fiſh.
Capdeul, a Gentlemans chief houſe, falling (almoſt every where) unto the ſhare of the eldeſt Heir.
Capeau, for chapeau, a hat. Capeau carnu, ou charnu, the Sea-nettle.
Capel, a hat, a little hat.
Capelan, a Chaplain; alſo a kind of Cod-fiſh.
Capelin, as Capeline in the N. D.
Caperaſſon, as Caparaſſon in the N. D.
Capeſolde, Capeſoulde, a Gentleman of good entertainment.
Caphard, and its derivatives. See Caſard, &c.
Capheran, a kind of courſe Taſſata; alſo a long caſſock of the ſame.
Capifou, a Play not much unlike Hide-man-blinde.
Capilaire, Capillaire, hairy; or belonging to hair.
Capilament, a hair, or flaw in a ſtone, &c.
Capitanerie, the Place of a Captain.
Capitaineſſe, as Capitaneſſe in the N. D.
Capite, a Cabbin in a ſhip; alſo a little Summer-houſe.
Capitel, a ſtrong compounded Lye, whereof Cauters and other violent remedies are made.
ſe Capitonner de, to cover his head with.

Capitoul. So they call in Tholouſe twelve principal Magiſtrates, whereof the firſt is to be a Gentleman of that Province, the rest Lawyers and ſubſtantial Merchants. Capitouls d' Orleans, the Sheriffs of Orleans.
Capitulairement, capitally; alſo in Chapter, or with full conſent of the Chapter.
Capitulant, having a voice in Chapters; alſo capitulating.
Capnomantie, divination by ſmoke riſing from an Altar, whereon Incenſe or Poppy-ſeed is burnt.
Capolie, the name of an Indian fruit much like a Cherry.
Cappe, as Cape in the N. D.
Cappeer, a ſhip to lie a try; alſo to go very neer the wind.
Cappette, a little hood; or a cloak having a capuch inſtead of a cape.
Caprimulge, a Goat-milker, an unluckie Night-bird that ſucks Goats, and mortifies their udders.
Caprin, le caprin, the kind or nature of Goats; alſo Goats fleſh.
Caprin (Adj.) of a Goat, or like a Goat.
Caprioter, to caper, to cut a caper.
Capſe, a caſe, box, or chest.
Capſetin, a little caſe, box, or chest.
Capſoos, the Rights and Royalties belonging to the Lord of a place.
Capſule, as Capſetin. La Capſule du coeur, the Pericardium wherein the heart lies.
Capucinage, the order, profeſſion, or life of a Capucin.
Capulaire, a coffin for a corps.
Caquerel, a ſprat, a pickled herring, or as Cagarel.
Caqueroles, the ſhells of Snails, Periwincles, and ſuch like.
Caquerolerie, a ſhore full of little ſhells.
Caquerotier, a catcher, or eater of ſhell-fiſh.
Caquetoire, a Mill, Oven, or the like, where women meet and prattle together.
Carabaſſe, as Calabaſſe in the N. D. alſo a Girt, Grampel, Pungar-fiſh.
Carabaſſé, much uſed or carried up and down as a Gourd-bottle is.
Carabe, a Corracle, or little round Skiff made of Ozier-twigs woven together and covered with raw hides; alſo yellow amber.
Carabinage, an aſſault made by Carabines.
Caracteré, characteriſed, ſtamped with a peculiar mark.
Caracterer, to make characters; alſo to ſtamp with a peculiar mark.
Caraffe, paſſage or toll-money paid to the Arabian Boothalers, by ſuch as travel without a ſtrong Caravan towards the Holy Land, &c.
Carance, want, or lack of. Carance de biens, a Teſtimonial under ſeveral mens hands, that ſuch an one hath no Goods nor Chattels in ſuch a place.
Carathement, a charming of a mans childgetter.
Caravelle, a Carvel (the little Ship ſo called.)
Caravene, a little Boat made like a Trough, and moſt commonly of one piece.
Caravirée, a wry-faced wench, or one that makes ill-favoured wry faces.
Carbaſſat, Wet-ſucket, made of the upper part of the long white Pompion cut into ſlices.
Carcamouſſe, the battering engine called a Ram.
Carcant, for Carcan, a carknet, or collar of Gold.
Cardamome, grain of Paradiſe, alſo Ethiopian pepper.
Cardinale, a kinde of Artillery for ſhipping, leſs than the Culverine, and deviſed at firſt by the Cardinal of Lorrain.
Cardons, the ſtalks of artichoke, or of the white thiſtle, buried in the ground, or otherwiſe uſed, to get them a whiteneſs.

Care, a diſeaſe that benums the head, and makes the whole body more ſenſeleſs than an Apoplexy; or a ſleepineſs joyned with weakneſs of the brain, ſenſes, and motion. Alſo the look, countenance, or aſpect of one.
Carfou, a peal of one bell, and about 8 or 9 a clock at night; alſo a place where two ways meet together.
Cargade, Cargaiſon, the fraught, or lading of a ſhip.
Carguer, to charge; alſo to lade; alſo to lean all on one ſide.
Cariage, carriage, baggage; all the neceſſary proviſion of an Army.
Caribe, the moſt biting kinde of Indian pepper.
Caribot, a lunchion, or big piece of bread, &c.
Carie, rottenneſs, or putrefaction in wood, or any thing elſe; a worm in wood.
ſe Carier, to rot, putrifie, corrupt.
Carine, for carêne, the keel of a ſhip.

Cariol, Cariole, the root of a horſes
tail, or the bone thereof; the rump-bone.
Cariophillate, herb Avens, Bennet, or bleſſed.
Cariſi, the name of a pear, alſo the perry made thereof.
Carler, for Carreler, to pave with bricks.
Carlin, the name of a Coin.
Carlonne, as vivre à la carlonne, to deal plainly.
Carlure, for Carrelure, a pavement with bricks.
Carme, a verſe, alſo a charm, alſo the horn-beam or yoke-tree; alſo a white Friar, as in the N. D.
Carmelitain, an Order of white Friars.
Carnagier, for carnacier, a great fleſh-eater.
Carnallage, for carnage, ſlaughter; alſo fleſh-time, the ſeaſon wherein 'tis lawful to eat fleſh.
Carnaller, to kill, or ſlay, eſpecially beaſts found damage-feaſant (which the party damaged in ſome places and caſes may lawfully do) and eat, or ſell their fleſh.
Carne, an edge, or corner. Carne de teſtons, a quartern of Teſtons, conſiſting of four, or of forty.
Carneau, (for creneau) a battlement of a wall.
Carnelle, the ſtamp of a piece of coin.
Carneller, to ſtamp a piece of coin.
Carner, a piece of a written book.
Carolle, a kinde of Dance; alſo a Carrol, or Chriſtmas ſong.
Caroller, to dance, to revel it, to ſing carrols.
Caroſide, a branch of the great artery.
Carous, as Carouſſe in the N. D.
Carpaſe, the name of a plant, whoſe juice being drunk cauſeth ſleep, and in ſleeping ſtrangleth.
Carpendu, for Capendu, a Short-ſtart, the name of an apple.
Carpion, Carpionne, a kinde of Trout.
Carpir, as Charpir in the N. D.
Carpobalſame, the fruit of the balſam-tree.
Carpot, part of the fruit or profit of a Vineyard, yielded as a Rent by the Tenant unto the Lord thereof.
Carquois, (Adj.) of, or belonging to a Quiver.
Carracon, Carraquon, a ſmall (but ſtrong) Carrick.
Carrat de bois à baſtir, a certain quantity of timber.
Carrube, as Carrobe; alſo a ſmall weight (among Mintmen and Goldſmiths) making but the 24th part of an ounce.
Cartaſonne, the Indian and black-horned Ʋnicorn.
Cartée, for cartel, a challenge to fight, in writing.
Cartibé, a ſquare table of ſtone, but ſomewhat more long than broad.
Cartiſannier, a maker of playing cards.
Cartophilaces, Law-books, ancient Records; alſo the room, cheſt, or preſs wherein ſuch Writings are kept.
Cartouſle, a ſhrub bearing a muſhrom-like fruit; alſo the fruit it ſelf.
Cartulaire, a Paper-book. Juges Cartulaires, Judges that give their Sentences in writing.
Cas, for caſſé, hollow, or broken-ſounded.
Caſal, a Mannor-houſe, a great houſe; alſo a Village, or Hamlet.
Caſard, one that never ſtirs out of doors.
Caſcaret, a furious tide, as ſometimes there is between Bourdeaux and Rochel.
Caſeiforme, made round and flat like a cheeſe.
Caſole, a poſnet; alſo a narrow-mouthed pot, ſomewhat like a perfuming pot.
Caſſard, a cheſt-like cover; alſo a buzzard.
Caſſe, for caiſſe, a box, or caſe; alſo a coffin, a dripping pan, an open-mouthed pan or veſſel of earth, &c. fit to boyl things, or ſet plants in; alſo the hollow part of the ſole of a horſes foot.
Caſſe-pot, a kinde of ſport in toſſing of earthen pots.
Caſſerie, a breaking, or quaſhing; a diſcharging, infringing, or cancelling.
Caſſerins, drawers in a preſs or cabinet.
Caſſier, the tree that bears the fruit Caſſia.
Caſſignon, a pump, or thin-ſoled ſhoe.
Caſſole, Caſſolle, a box for Perfumes, &c.
Caſtaigne, a ſcallop-like piece of iron in the midſt or mout • of an old-fa • hioned bit.
Caſtaloigne, a Spaniſh coverlet, or rug.
Caſtillaniſer, to imitate Spaniſh faſhions or humours.
Caſton, the bea • il of a ring.
Caſtoreum, as Caſtorée in the N. D.
Caſtrametation, the pitching, or meaſuring out of a Camp.
Catachreſe, the abuſe, or neceſſary uſe of one word for lack of another more proper.
Catachreſtique, uſed (though improper) for want of that which would be more proper.
Catadoupes, Catadupes, the falls of Nilus.
Cataglottiſer, to kiſs with the tongue.
Cataglottiſme, a kiſs with the tongue.
Catagmatique, of, or belonging to broken bones, or breaking of bones; alſo healing, or cloſing ſuch breaches.
Catalepſie, a diſeaſe coming of the brain diſtempered with drineſs and cold.
Catapuce grande, the herb Kick, or Tick; Catapuce petite, garden-Spurge.
Catapulte, a ſling, or warlike engine, whereout great arrows or darts were ſhot.
Catarre, for Catherre, a catharr, or a rheum.
Catarre, Catarreux, for Catherreux, rheumatick, troubled with a rheum.
Catel, a chattel; or a thing which (though of it ſelf it be immoveable) is divided and held as moveable; or as Cateud.
Cateud, a chattel; or not only a moveable (which may follow a body, and be removed from place to place) but alſo any immoveable that is no inheritance.
Cathedrant, ſitting as Judge or Moderator.
Cathedratique, a certain ſee or duty belonging to a Biſhop, when he is firſt inveſted into his See.
Cathelane, the name of a plum.
Cathene, a chain. Mat de cathene, a furious or inraged fool.
Catheretique, eating, or gnawing away ſuperfluous fleſh or skin.
Catherinettes, certain pretty flowers leſs than pinks, growing in cluſters, or many together on one ſtalk.
Catheux, a kinde of moveables, although they adhere to the ſoyl, or be faſtened to a houſe.
Catholicon, a Compoſition in Phyſick, ſo termed, becauſe it purges all kinde of humours.
Catholizer, to become a Catholick, to carry himſelf like one.
Catholiſation, the being, or becoming a Catholick.
Catoblepe, a kinde of Baſilisk, which with her ſight kills a mile off.
Cavain, a hole, cave, or hollow place.
Cavalet, a long hollow ſtick through which they uſe in ſome places to blow the fire, inſtead of bellows.
Cavallé, ridden, travelled on, toyled; alſo ſtaulked, or dogged.
Cavaller, to ride; alſo to toyl, or uſe like a horſe; alſo to ſtaulk, or dog.
Cavallet des planches, the higheſt or moſt raiſed part of Garden-beds.
Caubare, a ſandy-coloured and very venomous Serpent.
Caucheaux, Taxes paid towards the maintaining of common Banks or Cauſeys.
Cauche-poulet, Cauche-vieille, as Cauchemar in the N. D.
Caucher, to hatch, or ſit on; to tread a hen; to put on ſtockings.
Caudice, the ſtock, ſtump, or body of a tree.
Cavedal, the principal ſum lent out to uſe.
Cavelade, a kinde of ray-fiſh of a very hard ſubſtance.
Cavenne de Berger, a Shepherds cottage.
Caverneux, full of caves; alſo dwelling in caves.
Caveſanne, a falſe rein to lead a horſe by.
Caveſot, a pole-head, or bull-head; the little black vermine whereof toads and frogs do come.
Caveſſine, a martingal for a horſe.
Cavette, a little cellar, a little cave or hole under ground.
Caveure, a hole, a making hollow.
Cavier, Seigneur Cavier, a Lord having low Juriſdiction over his Tenants.
Caviller, to cavil, or to wrangle.
Cavillon, a kinde of little mullet.
Cavin, a hollow way, or dry brook.
Cavine, the bottom of the mouth wherein the root of the tongue is.
Caule, the ſtem of an herb; alſo the herb Colewort.
Caulebaſſe, as Calabaſſe in the N. D.
Cauné, the name of a kinde of Vine.
Caune, a certain fiſh not much unlike a Perch.
Cauque, a tent for a wound.
Cauqué, tented as a wound; trodden as a hen.
Cauquemare, as Cauchemar in the N. D.
Cauquer, to tent a wound; alſo to tread a hen, as a cock doth.
Cauſateur, a party in a Suit, or in Law.
Cauſativement, litigiouſly; alſo cauſatively, or for a cauſe.
Cauſereſſe, a pratling huſwife; a ſcold.
Cauſſe d'un Aiſement, the bottom of a Jakes.
Cay, as Quay in the N. D. alſo a ſemicolon.
Caymant, a beggar; alſo a certain great Lizard that lives in hot rivers.
Cayſieron, Caſſon, a wooden ch • ſt.
Ceciliane, the water-chain of a bit.
Cedriac, a kinde of Po •• e-citron.
Cedride, the fr • it or berry of the low Cedar.
Cedrie, the • ozen or pitch that iſſues from the great cedar.
Cein •• , for ceinture, a girdle, a ſtring.
Ceinctes, the thick ledges that compaſs the outſides of a ſhip.
Celerier, the Yeoman of a Cellar.
Celerin, the name of a Sea-fiſh.
Celeume, the ſhout or noiſe that Mariners make when they weigh anchor, or do any Office in the ſhip with joyned ſtrength.
Celiac, flux celiac, a continual thin flux with pain in the belly.
Celiaque, troubled with belly-ake and a continual flux.
Celidoine, for Chelidoine, the herb Celandine.
Celle, the houſe, or manſion of, and a community of goods among Villains, or perſons of a ſervile condition.
Celoce, a kind of ſwift brigantine.
Cement, for Ciment, a kind of morter made of lime and ſand.
Cenchre, Cenchrite, Cenchryne, a g ••• niſh Snake, whoſe ſting cauſes a L • thargy.
Cencive, as Cens in the N. D. Alſo an Inheritance hold by, or ſubject unto Cens; alſo the title of, or a tenure by Cens.
Cenſcable, as Cenſable in the N. D.

Cenſer, to reckon, eſteem, a ••
•• t a •• ng 〈…〉 ; to 〈◊〉 , tell, or maſter; to tax, or to • alue.
Cenſivement, by the title of Cens.
Centa • rée, the herb Cent • ry.
Centeſimer, to count, o • euil o • t by hundreds.
Centonifique, confuſedly heaping, or hudling many things together.
Cepée, an herb like Brook-lime, or water-Pimpernel.
Cephalonomantie, divination by an Aſſes head broyled on coals.
Cepier, a Gaoler; one that looks to the Stocks.
Ceramite, Potters earth; alſo a precious ſtone of the colour of a tile.
Ceranvienne, a certain precious ſtone that's always very moist, and ſeems to ſweat.
Ceraſte, the name of a most venomous ſerpent.
Cerat, a plaiſter made of wax, gums, and certain oyls.
Ceraunobule, thundering with bulls, as the Pope.
Cerceau, a circle, ring, or hoop; a round, or a round compaſs; alſo the Sarcel-feather of a Hawks wing.
Cercelé, compaſſed with a round, or circle.
Cerceler, Cerceller, to compaſs with a round or circle.
Cercerelle, for Crecerelle, a Rattle for children; alſo a ſort of Hawk.
Cerche, a ſearch, or inquiry. Cerche ralongée, the Inſtrument wherewith Maſons round and faſhion Pillars.
Cerchement, a ſearching, or inquiring after.
Cerclet, a little circle; alſo a ſmall wreath of Ozier-twigs to ſet under a diſh on a table. Cerelet à feu, a Fire-work made like a wreath.
Cerclou • re, a pair of weeding-tangs.
Cerebelle, for cervelle, the hinder part of the head wherein the memory is lo • ged.

Cere • rin,
• eady, raſh, gl • dy-brained.
Cerfouïr, to dig the ground about the roots of trees; or as Sarfouïr.
Cerin, as Serin in the N. D.
Ceriſee, the revenue that comes in, or profit that's made by cherries.
Cerne, Cerneau, a circle, a round.
Cerner, to compaſs with a circle, to make a round.
Cernoir, a kinde of tool to pick out withal the kernels of walnuts being yet in the ſhale.
Ceroeſne, Ceroine, any oyntment or plaiſter whereof rozen or wax are the principal ingredients.
Ceromantie, divination by wax put into water.
Cerot, a ſearcloth, or plaiſter made of wax, gum, &c.
Cerquemage, Cerquemanage, an aſſignment of bounds between private mens Lands, as alſo in Commons, High-ways, Rivers, &c.
Cerquemaner, to lay out the bounds.

Cerquemaneurs, certain ſworn Officers who have authority to ſet or plack up meers and bounds between ſeveral mens poſſeſſions, and to examine and reform incroachments made upon high-ways, commons, rivers, &c.
Cerreſine, gum, or liquour becoming like rozen or gum.
Certain (a Subſt.) certainty, or certain truth. Teſmoin de certain, a Witneſs that aſſures or ſays he knows all he ſays.
Certeau à deux teſtes, the name of a ſort of pear.
Certificateur, a certifier, alſo an Informer, or notice-giver.
Certification, a certification; alſo a certificate.
Cervelliere, a ••• ll, or ſallet of iron.
Cervical, belonging to the nape, or hinder part of the n •• k.
Cervineſ • ine, the ſhrub Way-thorn, Buck-thorn, Laxative-ram.
Ces, (a Subſt.) a ſtay, ceaſing, or forbearing; alſo a putting to ſilence, or forbidding to proceed.
Ceſſionaire, one that gives up his goods, thereby to be put out of the reach or danger of Creditors; and, though he loſeth his credit thereby, yet he is not held ſo baſe as a Bankrupt.
Ceſt, Ceſte, as Cet, Cette, in the N. D.
Ceſton, a ſtudded Girdle, which in old time the Bridegroom put about his Bride aſſoon as they were married, and took off when they went to bed together.
Ceſtrin, a kinde of yellow ſtone, whereof Beads are made.
Ceſtuy, he. Ceſtuy ci, this. Ceſtuy là, that.
Ceſue, for ſeve, the ſap of trees.
Cetacé, poiſſon cetacé, a fiſh of the kinde of Whales.
Cete, for cette, the feminine of cet, this, or that.
Cethin, a kinde of wood that corrupts not.
Cetier, as Setier in the N. D.
Ceton, a rowel for a bruiſed or impoſtumed horſe.
Ceucheter, to whiſper in the ear.
Chabins, the ſheep of Berry, whoſe wooll is very thick, and as long as goats-hair.
Chabrer, as Cabrer in the N. D.
Chace, Chacer, Chaceur. See Chaſſe, Chaſſer, Chaſſeur in the N. D.
Chacie, Chacicuſeté, as Chaſſie in the N. D.
Chacieux, as Chaſſieux in the N.D.
Chacunerie, every ones own. Chacun à ſa chacunerie, every one to his own home, or about his own buſineſs.
Chaffaulder, to ſet up ſcaffolds; alſo to ſet upon ſcaffolds.
Chaffourré, dis •••• d, beſ ••• ar • d.
Chaffourrer, to d ••• are, to beſmear.
Chagrigner, for Ch ••• iner, to vex.
Chahuant, as Chathuant, under Chat in the N. D.
Chair-bouillé, a ſodden fellow, or one whoſe fleſh doth look as if it had been ſodden.
Chaircuicterie, or Chaircuiterie, the Market or place where bacon or any kinde of hogs-fleſh may be had ready boyled.
Chaircuictier, a Cook that ſells all kinde of hogs-fleſh ready boyled; alſo a bungler.
Chaircuter à coups d'eſpées, to cut, or hack.
Chaiz, low Ware-houſes or Cellars to lay merchandiſe in.
Chalamine, as Calamine in the N. D.
Chalcide, a kinde of ſpotted Lizard.
Chalcite, the recrement of braſs, cleaving to the ſides of the furnaces wherein 'tis purified.
Chalemelle, Chalemie, a little pipe made of a reed, or of a wheaten or oaten ſtraw.
Chalemeller, to play on a little pipe.
Chalibé, ſteeled, done over with ſteel; wherein ſteel is quenched; belonging unto ſteel.
Chaline, a little thunder in a morning; alſo drought.
Challer, a hare to breed young; alſo to ſhale, or unſh • l •• ts.
ſe Chaloir de, to • a • e for.
Chalon, as Chalan; alſo a kinde of fiſh-net.
Chalu • , a kind • of Ma •• t.
Chamelleon, as Cameleon in the N. D.
Chamarrier, the name of an Office.

Cham • ellage, Cham • ellenage, a duty a fine paid or courſe unto a Lord upon e •• ry change of T •
nant; alſo a V •• d •• unto the chief Ʋſher of the Chamber of Accounts, upon every Homage made by one of the Kings Tenants.
Chambreux, that keeps much in his chamber.
Chambrier, a Chamberlain in an Abbey or Inne; alſo a Princes Chamberlain.
Chambrillon, a little chamber; alſo a young Chamber-maid.
Chameleon, as Cameleon in the N. D.
Chamion, a little dray without wheels.
Champayage, a running, or grazing of cattle in the fields.
Champayer, Champeyer, to reſide, or continue among fields; alſo to wander in, or walk over the fields; to carry abroad into the fields; to feed in fields; to turn cattle into the fields.
Champi, baſe born; alſo conſening, cheating; alſo ſeeming, but not being honeſt.
Champicerie, tour de champicerie, a cheating trick.
Chandeleux, full of candles, belonging to candles.
Chandelier, (Adj.) of, or belonging to a candle or candleſtick.
Chanfron, the name of an Italian Coyn.
Chanſi Chanſiſſeure. See Chanci, Chanciſſ • ure.
Chanſonn • ur, Chanſonier, always ſinging of Songs.
Chanſtié, as Chantier in the N. D.
Chantepleure, a watering-pot; the cock of a diſtern; a device for the emptying of a water-veſſel.
Chantepou • t, the leſſer C •• tory.
Chanter • me, a great ſong, or hedge-toad.
Chanterie, a ſinging; alſo a Chantery; the place or office of a Chanter.
Chantournement, a turning in and out.
Chantourner, to turn in and out, like a ſmall ſtream in a plain field.
Chapel, a hat, a garland. Chapel de roſes, a ſleight portion.
Chapelainie, Chaplainſhip; alſo the charge of a Chappel.
Chapeler, for Chapler, to chip bread.
Chapelier, (Adj.) of, or belonging to hats.
Chapeline, as Capeline in the N.D.
Chapelures, for chaplures, chippings of bread.
Chaperonner, Chaperonnier, to uncover his head before one; alſo to put a hood on.
Chapitreur de ſoin, a ſcar-crow, one that threatens much and does but little.
Chaplis, bread-chippings; alſo rags of ſtones, that fly from them in the hewing.
Chappins, a kinde of high ſlippers for low women.
Chappler, as Chapler in the N. D.
Chappronnier, as faulcon bon Chappronnier, a • awk that takes the hood gently.
Chaptel, a leaſt of a beaſt, and of the whole increaſe thereof, or a beaſt let out to the halves.
Chaptels deniers, the principal ſum and charges a Purchaſer has paid and been at for land, which the next of Kin offers to redeem.
Charadrien, a Bird which earneſtly beholding one that is ſick of the Jaundice, or beheld by him, heals him.
Charanſon, Charanton, a Mite, or Weevil.
Charbonnerie, for Mine de charbon, a Coal-pit, or Mine.
Charcuter, for gâter une beſongne, to ſpoil a piece of work.
Chardonnereau, the bar of a door.

Chardonnette, for Chardonnerette, the thiſtly Artichoke; alſo a kinde of ſawce for Kid. Formage à la chardonnette, cheeſe whoſe milk was curded with the juice of the wild Artichoke; or a Lenten cheeſe made of eggs and the ſpawn of fiſhes, and curded with the juice of the Thiſtle.
Chareſſe, Chareſſer, as Careſſe, Careſſer in the N. D.
Chareti, Charetin, a Waggon-houſe, a hovel to ſet carts under.
Chargais, the name of a bird.
Chariage, and Charier. See Charriage, and Charrier, under Char in the N. D.
Chariotte, a ſmall Chariot for children; alſo a kinde of Litter.
Charlataner, Charlater, to play the Mountebank.
Charmoye, a grove of Yoaks, or of Horn-beam trees.
Charnage, fleſh-time; alſo fleſh, or fleſh-meat.
Charnié, a prop, ſtay, or pole to ſupport a Vine.
Charnie, a Plain, Down, open, or unincloſed Ground.
Charniere, a binge; alſo a knuckle, or turning joynt; alſo a certain device whereby a wooden-leg or arm is made to move. La charniere des genoux, the whirl-bone of the knees.
Charopper, to boyl one ſort of liquor nine or ten times over.
Charpentailler, to cut, or hew, as a Carpenter doth timber.
Charpi, Charpie, Charpy, for Charpis, Lint, or Tinder.
Charrée, Buck-aſhes, the aſhes whereof Lye hath been made.
Charroyer, for Charrier, to carry in a Cart.
Charruage, the Plough-gears; alſo tilled, or plowed land.
Charté, having a Charter, holding, or held by Charter.
Charterie, a Carters trick; alſo a Hovel to ſet Carts under.
Chartil, Chartin, the frame of a Cart or Waggon without the wheels.
Chartrier, a Gaoler; alſo a Priſoner.
Chaſmate, a Chaſ • mate in fortification.
Chaſſable, chaſtable ſit to be chaſed.
Chaſſe-corneille, a kind of ſmall Fowling-piece.
Chaſſe-maſſe, a fire-lock, or horſe-mans piece that goes off by a fire-lock.
Chaſſe-rat, the name of a Serpent that commonly feeds on Rats.
Chaſſeton, a Scritch-owl; alſo a little cheſt of wood.
Chaſſiſſé, as feneſtre chaſſiſſée, a window covered with paper inſtead of glaſs.
Chaſſitier, a maker of paper-windows, or of frames for paper or linnen-windows.
Chaſte • lenie, Chaſtellerie, as Chatelainie in the N. D.
Chaſtenereie, a plot of ground full of Cheſnut-trees.
Chaſti-villain, a whip, or cadgel for a knave; alſo a Caſtle, or Cittadel, in or near a good Town.
Chat-chaſteil, ou chateil, a defenſiue Engine of War, ſomewhat reſembling the Roman Teſtudo.
Chat-fourré, a Lawyer, or Petti-fogger, who commonly wears a Gown lined with wilde Cats-skin.
Chat-garanier, a Pole-cat, a kind of wild Cat that haunts Warrens.
Chatonnie, a waggiſh trick; a knaviſh or unhappy prank; alſo the art of pilfering.
Chatouille, a certain fiſh very full of ſmall bones.
Chatouilloir, any tickliſh part of the body, eſpecially the ſide.
Chattement, a ki • ling, a breeding or bringing forth of young Cats.
Chavaſſme, a certain meaſure or quantity of land, in length 120 foot, and in breadth 30.
Chaucher, to crowd a thing in.
Chauche-mare, as Cauchemar in the N. D.
Chaude (Subſt.) a fierce onſet, a violent aſſault. A la chaude, in anger.
Chaudeau, a Caudle, or warm broth.
Chauderonnerie, fleſh or fiſh that's ordinarily boyled in Cauldrons or Kettles.
Chaudot, a heat, or hot thing.
Chauffe-dos, a kind of low chimney having but a hole inſtead of a fannel for the voiding of ſ • oak.
Chauffe-pied, a Foot-ſtove, a little and low Stove that ſerves to keep the feet warm.
Chauffour, as Chauſour, under Chaux in the N. D.
Chaufrain, as Chanfrein in the N.D.
Chauliere, a plot or bed of Cabbidges in a Garden.
Chaulmage, the cutting or mowing of ſtraw or ſtubble.
Chaulmer, to pick, or gather up ſtraw; alſo to cut or mow ſtubble.
Chaulmeur, a gatherer of ſtraw; a cutter or mower of ſtubble.
Chaumer, as Chaulmer, and as Chommer.
Chaumin, made of, or covered with ſtubble.
Chaumouflet, Bumbaſt put into a cornet of paper, then kindled, and the ſmoak thereof put into the noſtrils of a ſleeper.
Chauſſage, ſhoe-money, expence in ſhoes; alſo hoſen, or ſhoes.
Chauver, to make bald. Chauver des oreilles, to clap down the • ars.
Chauveſouriſſier, the bat-wing-bone in the lower part of the head.
Chebule, the biggeſt kind of the M ••• olan-plum.
Chedins, the head-men of the Pari • h.
Chef • ciet, the Treaſurer, or Keeper of the Veſ • ry.
Cheintre, a baulk or ſwath of graſs, a long •• de •• , or highway.
Chelſydre, Chelydre, a moſt venomous and ſtinking Serpent.
Chemage, the paſſage-toll that's paid at Sc • .

Ch • me, as ancient meaſure holding about t ••
•••• f • ls.
Ch • mer, to de •• e •• , or be (as the M •• ) in the wai • ; to pine, or f • ll away.
Che •• er, the 〈◊〉 or chief H • ir in a D • ſ ••• nt, who is to do homage ſor • whole land that is diſcended.

Ch • min • ux, a great walker; alſo 〈◊〉 to a way, or to a chim

〈…〉 , a chain; alſo a 〈…〉 w • rk.
Chenevilles, the broken ſtalks of Hemp.
Chenevette, for Chenevote, a ſtalk of Hemp.
Chenillé, of, or belonging to Caterpillars; Caterpillar-like; full of, or wrought with Caterpillars. Taffetas chenillé, a kinde of ſtriped Taſſata.
Chenillier, an Inſtrument wherewith Gardeners pull down Caterpillars.
Chenin (Adj.) dog-like, of or belonging to a dog.
Chermaye, a wood of ſcarlet oaks; alſo as Charmoye.
Chermine, the fruit or berry of the ſcarlet oak.
Cheſaux, the rubbiſh of decayed houſes; alſo manſions, houſes.
Cheſneau, a water-ſnake, mortal enemy to oaks; alſo a young oak.
Cheſnette, for Chainette, a little chain; alſo the hath G • rmander.
Cheſneux, of Oak, or f • ll of Oaks.
Cheſt • eté, miſ • ry, wret •• ed •• ſs, poorn •• s; alſo k ••• ry, ſhr • wdn ••• .

Ch • te, the height •

Chevage, a w • r • duty paid to the Kings 〈◊〉 , 〈◊〉
• y Ba • tard, &c.
Cheval • r, to 〈◊〉 ; alſo to 〈…〉 ; 〈…〉 of ca ••• ip to lap out •• g 〈◊〉 an •••• r.
Chevalereſque, Knightly, of, or belonging to a Knight.
Chevalet, or petit cheval, a little horſe.
Chevalin, of, or belonging to a horſe.
Chevaline, the Herb called Horſetail, or Shave-graſs. La Chevaline, horſe-fleſh, or the kinde of ho • ſ • s.
Chevalet, a little horſe; alſo a treſſel of wood; alſo a ſort of coyn.
Chevauchable, eaſie to be rid on.
Chevauchée, a riding on horſeback; alſo a Princes Progreſs; a Judges Cheuit, &c. alſo a furniſhing of horſes to ride on.
Chevaucher, for voyager à cheval, to ride a horſe.
Cheveche, an Owl, the rough-footed ſhort-tailed Owl.
Chevecher, Chevechier, Chevecier, a S • xton.
Chevecherie, the V • ſtry, or Treaſury of a Church.
Cheveil, Chevel, chief, principal. Lieu chevel, a Mannor-houſe, or chief houſe; Fief chevel, a noble Inheritance held in capite, and capabl • of J • riſdicti •• .
Cheveler, to ſprig, or ſpriggle; to put forth a ſmall or hairy 〈◊〉 .
Cheveliere, a hair-la •• ; alſo a dreſſing of • air.
Chevelite, a S •• ker, a ſmall imp of a plant ſpr • nging from the root th • r • of, or o • it ſ • ly rooted.
Cheveſne, the Ch •• i • , or P • llard-fi h.
Cheveſtre, a 〈◊〉 , or • alter for a cow, cal • , &c.
Cheveſtreux, blading, or ſ • raini g the head.
Cheve • ain, a Captain, a Commander.
Chevilleur, a pegger; alſo a Sorcerer that holding his finger in a hole, and muttering certain ſuperſtitious Words, will hinder a man from piſſing until his finger be removed.
Chevir, to compaſs, prevail with, reclaim. Ils ne pouvoyent tous chevir en la maiſon, there was not room enough for them all in the houſe.
Cheviſſance, an agreement, or compoſition made.
Chevolée, a ſprig of a plant; alſo a fiber, or hair-like thread growing unto the root of a plant.
Chevrette, a little Goat; a wilde Goat; a great Prawn; a little and low andiron; a ſmall piece of Ordnance.
Chevrin, Goat-like; of, or belonging to a Goat.
Cheurme, as Chiorme in the N. D.
Chevronde, as Severonde in the N. D.
Chevrottement, the breeding, or bringing forth of Kids.
Chezal, Chezeau, a chief Manſion, or Mannor-houſe.
Chi, as Ci in the N. D.
Chiappon, a kinde of port in the mouth of a Bit.
Chiaſſer, to ſhite; alſo to be too curious.
Chic, de chic à chic, from little to little.
Chicambault, the luff-block in a ſhip.
Chicancus, Chicanous, for Chicaneur, a wrangler.
Chicheron, the Nipple of ones breaſt.
Chieneſſe, Dogs, the kinde or nature of dogs, a breed of dogs.
Chienneterie, doggiſhneſs, the kinde or nature of dogs.
Chiennetier, a Dog-keeper, one that looks unto Hounds.
Chiennette, a young, or little bitch.
Chiſſe, an old rag, an off-caſt piece of ſtuff.
Chiffetier, a ſeller of old ſtuff.
Chil, as Chyle in the N. D.
Chilifier, to concoct, digeſt, or turn into a milky or white juice.
Chiller, as Ciller in the N. D.
Chilleure, a ſeeling, or ſowing up of the eyes.
Chimagrée, as Cimagrée in the N. D.
Chimolie, terre chimolie, a kinde of earth that is good againſt burning and hot Impoſtumes.
Chinchille, the name of an Indian and Squirrel-like beaſt.
Chine, a red and ſpungeous Indian root, good againſt the Gout.
Chinon, as Chignon in the N. D.
Chinquer, to quaff, or drink extremely.
Chiot, a whelp, or little dog.
Chippe, a ſhip, or bark; alſo an old clout, rag, or patch.
Chiquanourris, Chiquanoris, crafty pleaders, or pettyfoggers.
Chiqueture, a cutting, cut, or gaſh.
Chiquot, a ſcale in the root or end of a nail; alſo a ſprig, or ſhoot of a tree; alſo the ſtump of a tooth.
Chiquoter, to ſift, ſearch, or ſeek out; alſo to hack with a knife, &c.
Chiragre, the Gout in the hands.
Chirographaire, Creancier chirographaire, a Creditor that hath a Note under the Debtors hand.
Choënes, the lines, or chains, and rods wherewith Surveyors meaſure Land.
Choine, Choiſne, a loaf of white bread.
Cholagague, the thin or ſmall gut wherein the Chylus thickening begins to rest.
Chole, Cholere, as Colere in the N. D.
Choleré, Cholerique, and Cholereux. See Colerique in the N. D.
Cholique, as Colique in the N. D.
Chomer, as Chommer in the N. D.
Chommable, Jour chommable, a Play-day, a Holy-day.
Chommage, a reſting, or ceaſing from work.
Choner, as Chommer, or Chopiner in the N. D.
Chonquetage, a View taken of the Kings Woodſales.
Choriage, a keeper of Players Garments.
Chore, a Company of Singers, or Dancers; any Company; the Chorus between every Act in a Tragedy.
Choreal, frequenting, or belonging to a Quire.
Chorer, a Barrow-pig, a young hog.
Choriſte, a Singing-man in a Quire.
Chorme, as Chiorme in the N. D.
Chourme, as Chiorme in the N. D.
Choyer, to have a great care of.
Chran, the name of a fiſh.
Chreſme, as Chreme in the N. D.
Chreſmer, to anoint with holy oyl.
Chronique, (Adj.) temporal, or returning at a certain time.
Chryſopaſe, Chryſopatie, a green precious ſtone that hath a golden luſtre.
Churle, the white field-onion, or ſtar of Bethlehem.
Chyloſe, a digeſtion of ſap or 〈◊〉 .
Ciathe, the name of a meaſure and weight.
Ciboile, as Ciboire in the N. D.
Cicatricé, Cicatricer, as Cicatrisé, Cicatriſer in the N. D.
Cices, Ciches, as Chiches in the N. D.
Cicle, as Sicle or Cycle in the N. D.
Cic •••• , or Cicoigne, for Cigogne, a Stork.
Cicogn • au, Cicoig • eau, a young Stork.
Cicotrin, the herb Orpin; alſo a kinde of fine ſcarce.
Cicotrine, or Cicrotiné, very finely ſearced.
Cielin, heavenly; alſo belonging to the firmament; or to a canopy, teſtern, or upper cieling.
Cilindre, as Cylindre in the N. D.
Cillier, as Ciller in the N. D.
Cimaiſe, as Cymaiſe in the N. D.
Cimaſulte, carving that reſembleth rowling waves.
Cimet, for Cime, the top of a tree or a hill.
Cimmerique, as Tenebres Cimmeriques, Cymmerian (or continual) darkneſs.
Terre Cimolée, Cimolie, or Cimolienne, Fullers earth.
Cin de bois, a knot in wood.
Cincinatule, one that continually curls his hair.
Cincture, or Cindre, for C • inture, a girdle.
Cindrer, to gird, alſo to ſpot.
Cinnabrisé, mingled, or coloured with cinoper.
Cinnamé, ſweetned with cinnamon, or ſweet as cinnamon.
Cinnamome, as Cinname in the N. D.
Cinquaine, the name of a certain Vi • e that th • ives not in a moist ſoil.
Cinquener, to yield five for one.
Cion, a ſtorm; alſo as Scion.
Circuition, a circuition. Circuition de paroles, a circumlocution.
Cirette, the name of a pear.
Cireux, of wax, full of wax.
Ciroeſnes, as Ciroines in the N. D.
Cironnier, as main cironniere, a hand troubled with worms.
Cirre, a lock of curled hair.
Cirſotomie, the cutting or opening of the corrupt veins called Varices.
Ciſaille, the clipping of coyn preſently after the ſtamp. Ciſailles, Garden-ſheers, any great ſheers.
Ciſé, carved, wrought with a chiſel.
Ciſellage, a clipping with ſheers or cizars.
Ciſteaux, for Citeaux, an Order of White Friars.
Ciſternin, of, or belonging to a ceſtern.
Ciſtophore, an antient coyn, worth about two pence farthing.
Ciſtre, as Siſtre in the N. D.
Citadin, a Citizen, or Freeman in a City.
Citrin, of a citron, citron-like, pale-yellow as a citron.
Citronnelle, a kinde of ſmall balm.
Civade, a ſhrimp; alſo oats, or provender for horſes.
Civadier, the fourth part of a Quarteron.
Civadiere, the Sprit-ſail of a ſhip.
Civé, a kinde of blacke ſauce for a Hare.
Cive, a Scallion, or unſet Leek.
Civettien, perfumed with, or ſmelling of civet.
Civois, a bed of ſcallions, or of unſet leeks.

Cizailler, Cizaille, Cizeler, Cizeleure.
See them with an s, inſtead of z, in the N. D.
Clabaud, a came for a bound; alſo the harking of a Cur.
Claboſſer, to ho • ſe, or t • ſs up and down; alſo to be daſh with dirt.
Clac, any thing that makes a clacking or clattering noiſe; the •• acket that frights away birds from fruit-trees, &c.
Clache, a certain engine wherewith ſmall birds are caught.
Claguet, the name of an apple.
Claigner, as Cligner in the N. D.
Claim, a publick demand or claim; alſo a Bill of complaint put or preferred into a Court.

Clain, as Claim; alſo an Arreſt or Seizure of a Debtors Goods upon execution; alſo a fine of twenty pence due unto Juſtice for the ſeizure of beaſts Damage ſeſant; alſo a penalty inflicted on the Party that yeelds by confeſſion in Court, before the Suit come to conteſtation.
Clairins, a certain Order of Cordeliers, or Gray-Friars.
Claironner, to ſound a Clarion; alſo to ſqueak, to ſpeak ſhrill.
Clamant, a clai • er, a challenger; alſo a Creditor that ſeizes b • Debtors Goods upon Execution.
Clamant, (Adj.) crying out; alſo claiming, or challenging.
Clame, a Fine levied in ſome places upon ſuch as d • fer the payment of their debts; alſo the fine paid unto Juſtice, or a Lord having Juriſdiction, for the ſeizure of beaſts found Damage-ſeſant.
Clamporte, as Cloporte in the N.D.
Clanche, the • atch of a door.
Clangueur, a ſhrill noiſe, or ſ ••• aking.
Clappeter, to clap one with his hand.
Clapp • nie • , t • e •• ckle-bone of a 〈◊〉 .
Cla • re- ••• r, a la •• ro • , one that will • at • er ſtar • e with cold and longer, than work to get heat or 〈◊〉 .
Claquer, Claqueter les dents, to k • a • h the teeth.
Claquette, for Cliquette, a Lazer's clicket or clapper.
Clas, a k • ell, or woful noiſe.
Clavaller, to ſtrengthen the young ſhoots or ſlips of a Vine againſt the fury of ſtrong winds.
Clavandier, a Key-bearer; alſo the chain whereon women uſe to wear their keys.
Clavarins, an Order of black Friars which wore two great paper-keys upon their habits.
Clavelé, Clavellé, nailed, or faſtned with nails; alſo • uſ •• fied with the ſcab, as a ſheep.
Clavet, for Claveau, the ſcab amongſt ſheep.

Clavette, the Craw-bone; alſo a Spring-pin; th • little pi • ce of iron wherewith Tradeſmen keep in the iron-pins of their ſhop-windows; alſo the forelock of the carriage of Cannon, or that which faſtens it. Clavette du pied, the ••• l, or hinder-bone of the foot.
Claveure, a key-hole, or all that part of a lock wherein the key • a •• s or plays; alſo a chi • k.
Clavicules, the channel-bones, neck-bones, or craw-bones.
Claviere, a woman that hath charge of all the keys in a houſe.
Clavin, a little grapple, or book like a claw.
Clauſtier, for Clauſtral, of, or belonging to a Cloyſter, living in a Cloyſter.
Claver, to ſhut up with hurdles.
Clematide, Clematite, a kinde of the b • th Ha ••• wort.
Clepſ • drie, a limited running of ſand in an hour-glaſs.
Clercelier • , a kind • of 〈◊〉 ribbon; alſo a ſtring wherewith wo •• n •• ng their keys to their girdles.

Cleré, a kind 〈◊〉
• d Hy ••• ra • .
Cleres-voyes, lattices, or ſecret holes to ſpy out at.
Clergeau, Clergeon, a petty Clark, an under-Clark, or young Clark.
Clerical, of, or belonging to the Clergy.
Clide, an antient warlike engine, whereby they uſed of old to hurl a great number of ſtones.
Clientelle, defence, protection; alſo a ſtore of Clients.
Climacterie de 63 ans, the climacterical or dangerous year of 63.
Clinqueillerie, a ringing of much money, or of many pans and skellets together; alſo coin.
Clinquet, as Cliquet; alſo a certain trick in wreſtling.
Cliquer, the knocker of a door; alſo a L ••• rs • li • ket.
Cliſ • e, a little wreath of wicker to ſet under a diſh on the table; alſo a wattl • , or hurdle. Treillis de cli •• e, a gr • te o • wick • r.
Clitie, or de clitie, a Marigold.
Clitori • , a w • rna is privit ••• .

Cliver, to 〈…〉 o • twa • d, as t ••
〈…〉 .
Clocherie, a r •• gi •• , or peal of •• ll • .
Clochier, for Cl •• her, a 〈◊〉 , alſo a Pari •• , 〈…〉 and 〈…〉 a Bi • h • p • ick, 〈◊〉 Di •••• s.

Cl •••••• x,
〈…〉
to mud-walls, hedges, or Incloſures.
Clomaſſoles, the defence which a horſe makes with his Nether-lip or gums againſt his bit.
Cloper, Clopiner, Cloquer, for Clocher, to hal • .
Cloſcuau, the neſt-cockle, the laſt-hatched bird in a neſt.
Clot, as jouër au clot, to play at hide and finde.
Clouët, a little nail, a tack-nail.
