Clouïr, to open and produce young ones, as eggs that have been ſitten on their full time.
Clouiſer, for Cloſſer, to cluck like a hen.
Clyſteriſé, applied as a Gliſter, or made into a Gliſter.
Clyſteriſer, to apply a Gliſter, alſo to make or put a thing into a Gliſter.
Coaine, for Coenne, the skin of bacon.
Coärcter, to reſtrain, or bring within a narrow compaſs.
Coärcté, reſtrained, or brought within a narrow compaſs.
Coäxer, for Coaſſer, to croak as a frog.
Cobbir, to bruiſe, or break into pieces.
Cobeter, or Cobter une cloche, to toll a bell.
Cochelin, a kinde of Cake full of not • hes.
Cochepierre, a bird like a Bull-finch.
Cocluchon, as Coqueluchon in the N. D.
Cocytide, homme cocytide, a helliſh fellow, as cruel as the Devil.
Codicile, a Cedicii, or bill annexed.
Codicilaire, or Codicillaire, one that is inſtituted into a Benefice, &c. by Codicil.
Coelibat, for Celibat, the ſtate of a Batchelor.
Coeſte, Coeſton, a very thick and great Glove uſed by the ancient Grecians in their Theatre-Combats.
Coëtivement, a cheriſhing, or keeping warm.
Coëtiver, to cheriſh, to keep warm.
Coëval, coetaneous, or equal in age.
Coſerruminer, to ſoder iron with other metals.
Coffré, put into a chest or coſſer; alſo laid up in priſon.
Coffrer, to put into a cheſt or coffer. Coffrer aulcun en priſon, to lay one up in priſon.
Cognil, Cognoil, the baſtard Tunnyſ • h, or a fiſh like unto a Mackerel, but greater and thicker.
Cognoſcitive, the faculty of knowing, or diſcerning.
Cohiber, to reſtrain, curb, or keep in.
Cohue, a Hall to plead in, a Seſſions-houſe.
Coiche, the feathering of an arrow.
Coignaſſe, the greateſt kind of Quince.
Coigné, wedged, driven, or knocked in, ſtamped, coyned.
Coigne-feſtu, an idle fellow; or one that will neither do good himſelf, nor ſuffer others to do any.
Coigner, to wedge, or faſten with a wedge; to drive hard, or knock fast in; to ſtamp or coyn. Coigner les larmes, to hold in his tears by force.
Coignet, a little wedge; alſo a little corner.
Coigniaux, a kind of ſmall and bright green vermine.
Coignoir, a wedging tool, a wedger.
Coiſſin, for couſſin, a cuſhion; alſo a pillow.
Coiti, Coitis, Coitte, for Coitre, a tick.
Coitte-pointe, a quilted covering for a bed.
Colatoire du nez, the ſpungy bone through which the ſnivel paſſeth from the brain into the noſtrils.
Colature, a ſtraining; alſo the thing ſtrained.
Cole, a ſtormy gale of wind.
Coliaux, the name of a kinde of Olives.
Colin, gros colin, bran, alſo dogs meat made of it.
Coline, for Colline, a little hill.
Colique, (Adj.) of, or belonging to the Chollick.
Colitor, the name of a certain Vine.
Colle, for Colline, a little hill; alſo anger.
Collectage, a collecting, or gathering together.
Collectanes, a certain Order of Franciſcan Friars.
Collée, a taking (or imbracing) of one about the neck; alſo a thump, or blow in the neck.
Collerage, a pecuniary Duty exacted in ſome places for the Collers worn by wine-drawing horſes or men.
Collerette de ſemme, a ſmall neck-ruff.
Colles, croſs-walls of ſtone, &c. in ſome Vineyards.
Colletages, Taxes and Subſidies levi'd of the people.
Colligence, a gathering, bringing, or uniting together; alſo as Colligance.
Colliger, to gather, bring, or unite together.
Collin, a grey and long-beaked River-fowl; alſo as Colin.
Colliquation, a melting, reſolving, or diſſ •••• g; a Conſumption of the radical humour, or ſubſtance of the body.
Colliſion, colliſion, a knocking, or beating together.
Collitigant, wrangling, or going to law together.
Collizée, as Coliſée in the N. D.
Collobe, a kind of ſleeveleſs upper garment in faſhion among the old Romans.
Collyre, a liquid medicine for the eyes; alſo a kind of Samian earth, whereof among other things Eye-medicines are made.
Colobe, as Collobe; alſo a furrehood or tippet worn by Graduate Prieſts.
Colocaſie, the Prieſts pintle; alſo the root of the Aegyptian bean.
Colocinthe, for Coloquinthe, the plant called Coloquintida.
Colom, the name of a great gut.
Colombage, board-work on the outſide of walls, &c.
Colombeau, Colombelle, a little young Pidgeon.
Colombine, a whitiſh and ſpungy ſtone found in leaden mines; alſo a delicate Italian pear.
Colomneux, full of pillars, or columns.
Colophone, the herb Scammony, alſo as Reſine Colophonienne, clarified, or hard rozen.
Coloſſal, Coloſſien, Coloſſus-like, huge, or mighty.
Coloſtration, the indiſpoſition of Infant-ſtomacks by the ſucking of beeſt.
Colporter, to carry upon the neck or ſhoulders.
Columelle, the uvula, or a ſpungious fleſh reſembling a Cocks ſpur, and hanging down in the bottom of thereof of the mouth; alſo the ſwelling thereof.
Colure, for Encoulure, the neck of a horſe.
Combe, a narrow Valley or Paſſage between two hills, wherein commonly Theeves do lurk.
Combinage, a coupling, or joyning of pairs.
Combleau, the breeching, a great cable uſed about the carriage of a piece of Ordnance.
Comblette, the cleft or diviſion of a red Deers foot.
Combrecelle, or Combreſſelle, a tumbling trick wherein the heels are caſt over the head; alſo a reciprocation of Venery.
Comeſtible, eatable, ſit to be eaten.
Comet • ux, like unto a Comet, full of Comets.
Command, command, power, authority; alſo a Mandamus, or an Injunction for Poſſeſſion, &c. alſo an Injoyner, Commander.

Commande, as Commende in the N. D. alſo the main Cable of a Ship; alſo a thing left in trast with another. Droict de Commande, a Duty taken yearly by ſome Lords of every one of their Widows (that holds by Villenage) in acknowledgement and preſervation of the right of their Authority over them.
Commandereſſe, a woman that commands; alſo Command, Rule, or Authority.
Commenſalité, a conſtant eating together at one Table.
Commeſurable, meaſurable together, or with one and the ſame meaſure.

Comminué, l • ſt • ned; beaten, or broken 〈◊〉
• all pl • ces.
Comminuer, to leſſen; alſo to beat, or break into ſmall pieces.
Commiſe, a forfeiture. Droict de Commiſe, the right or power a Landlord hath to ſeize the Land held by his Vaſſal or Tenant who diſadvows him, gives him the lie, or commits felony.
Commiſſure, a ſeam in a bone, as in the ſcull; alſo any near cloſing, or joyning of things together.
Commiſtion, a mixing, or mingling of ſeveral things together.
Commoderation du Corps, a good diſpoſition of the whole body.
Commoditer, to thrive, to grow rich.
Commouvoir, to trouble, or to diſturb.
Compacture, a ſubſtantial joyning of all the parts of a thing together.
Companage, all kind of food except bread and drink.
Comparer, (Sub • .) le comparer du Corps, the price of a mans life, or the buying of a thing with the loſs thereof.
Comparuit, an Order or Teſtimonial, ſignifying the appearance of a party.
Compenſible, able to make amends for.

Compe ••• une cho •• par une a •
tre, to make up a thing by another.
Comperage, the being a Goſſip; alſo a goſſipping.
Competer, to be ſufficient for; to belong to; alſo to ſue for the ſame thing that another doth.
Compilation, a compilation; alſo a rapſody.
Compiſſer, to piſs every where, or to bepiſs every place he comes in.
Complanté, planted, or ſtored with young plants.
Complanter, to plant a Vineyard; alſo to lay out, or deliver over, a Lords part or ſhare in the fruits of a Vineyard, let by him unto parts or halves; or to let a Vineyard in a manner.
Complanterie, a letting out of a Vineyard to halves, or for part of the fruit thereof; alſo the part or portion due unto the Landlord.
Complication, a complication, or folding together.
Comprehenſion, a comprehenſion; alſo an apprehenſion, or underſtanding of.
Compromiſſaire, he unto whom a Controverſie is compromitted.

Compulſoire, a compelling, or com
••• ſion; alſo an inſtrument or means of compulſion; alſo a Commiſſion in •• yning a Regiſter, Notary, or Clerk, to deliver the Contracts, Pleadings, Acts, Orders, or Judgement which a Suitor has n • ed 〈◊〉 .
Compurgateur, a Compurgator, one that by • ath • ſtiſ • es the innocency, •• port, or • at • of another.
Conare, a Kernel like a Pine-apple, that ſticks to the outſide of the Brain.
Concathener, to concatenate, to link or chain together.
Concentrique, having one and the ſame center.
Conceptacle, any hollow thing apt to receive, hold, or contain.
Conche, a ſhell; alſo a kinde of open veſſel like a baſon; alſo order, equipage, or furniture.
Conchylion, as Conchyle in the N. D.
Concilipete, one that is going towards a general Councel.
Concion, a Congregation; alſo the ſpeech delivered unto them.
Concorder, to pacifie; alſo to live in concord.
Concreé, created together; alſo congealed, or thickened.
Concreer, to create together. Se concreer, to thicken.
Concret, a conjunction. Alſo (Adj •• tively) concrete, thickened, or compared together.
Concubin, a man unlawfully kept and uſed by a woman.
Conde, a Butler, or a Yeoman of the Larder.
Condemnade, a kinde of Card-play, like unto Lanſquenet.
Condemner, and its Derivatives. See Condamner, &c. in the N.D.
Condignac, for Codignac, Marmalade of Quinces.
Condol, a ridge, or raiſing of earth.
Condore, the name of a great and ravenous Indian bird.
Condyle, the out-ſwelling or knots of the thigh, anckle, elbow, and knuckle-bones; alſo a blow with the fiſt.
Condylome, an excreſcence of fleſh in the fundament, or in a womans privity's.
Coneſtablie, as Connêtablie in the N. D.
Confanon, as Gonſanon in the N.D.
Confeſſionaire, of, or belonging to auricular Confeſſion.
Confeſſionat, an act of Confeſſion tending to Abſolution.
Confiez de Cour, as Plairs de la Cour.
Configuration, a likeneſs, or reſemblance of figures.
Confin, (Adj.) Conſinant, near neighbour, confining, or adjoyning to.
Confluer, to run or flow together.
Conforte-main, a helping hand; alſo the ſtrengthening and confirmation of an inferiour perſon.
Congeable, diſmiſſable, diſchargeable. Domaine congeable, a Demeſne held at will.
Congiaire, a dole, or liberal gift of money, or victuals to the people.
Congie, a Veſſel among the antient Romans, containing very near a Gallon.
ſe Congreer, to congeal, or to thicken.
Congregable, that may be congregated, or congealed.
Congreger, to congregate. Il ſe congrege en pierre precieuſe, it grows or congeals into a precious ſtone.
Conjectural, which may be gueſſed at by conjecture.
Conillart, a certain very tender and delicate pear.
ſe Conjoyr, to rejoyce with one.
Conjuger, to play the part of a husband.
Connoiſtre, Connoiſſance, as Conoìtre, Conoiſſance in the N. D.
Connon, a long Dray or Cart, having at the fore-end a pulley for the drawing up of a loading.
Conoeïdal, Cone-like, broad and round at the bottom, and ſharp at the top.
Conqueſt, an Eſtate or Purchaſe compaſſed by a mans own induſtry; alſo a thing got wherein another is to have a ſhare.
Conroy, ſtuff through tawed or curry'd.
Conſalme de Mer, the great horſe-muſcle.
Conſçachance, a full knowledge or notice of.
Conſçachant, fully acquainted with, or privy unto.
Conſcinomantie, Divination by a ſieve and a pair of ſheers.
Conſemblable, very like unto. Ses Conſemblables, his fellows.
Conſequentieux, moſt important, or of great conſequence.
Conſervatoire, the Office of a Conſervator, his Court, or the Room wherein he uſeth to keep it.
Conſierge, as Concierge, in the N. D.
Conſilles, two conduits or pipes in the throat.
Conſiſtorié, cenſured, or determined of in Conſiſtory.
Conſiſtorier, to cenſure, or determine of in Conſiſtory.
Conſoner, to agree, or ſound alike.
Conſoulde, & Conſourde, for Conſolde, the herb Conſound.
Il Conſte, it is clear, plain, or certain.
Conſtitueur, he that conſtitutes or appoints.
Conſtuprer, to conſtuprate, raviſh, or deflowr a Virgin.
Conſultatif, conſulting. Qui a voix conſultative, that hath power to give his advice, but not to determine.
Conſuyvre, to overtake, to get, or obtain.
Conſyre, for Conſire, the herb Comfrey.
Contemner, to contemn, ſcorn, or deſpiſe.
Contemplatiſs, certain Friars of St. Mary Maudlins Order, who ſeed on all ſorts of fleſh, and wear black upper-habits, and white under-ones.
Contendre, to contend, or to ſtrive.
Conterolle, as Contre-rolle, in the N. D.
Contexte, a context; the form or ſtile of a Proceſs, Book, or Diſcourſe.
Continemment, continently, ſoberly, chaſtly; alſo ſparingly, abſtemiouſly.
Contrahant, contracting, or making a contract.
Contradveu, Contre-adveu, an Anſwer or Oppoſition to a Bill of Complaint for poſſeſſion of Moveables.
Contre-advoüé, owned, or claimed by ſeveral Parties.
Contr'amour, a holy and honeſt love
Contr'applegement, an Anſwer to a Bill of complaint for the poſſeſſion of an Immoveable.
Contrebaſe, a counter-baſe, the lower part of a baſis.
Contre-boutant, as Contrefort in the N. D.
Contre-bouter, to ſupport, or bear up.
Contre-carre, a reſiſtance, or oppoſition; an arguing againſt; alſo compariſon, or equality.
Contre-chanter, to anſwer in the ſame note or tune.
Contre-charger, to interchange burdens or accuſations.
Contrechifre, a countercypher, a note explanatory of particular cyphers, or as le chifre d'un Prince.
Contrechifrer, to anſwer cyphers with cyphers; alſo to expound cyphers; alſo to requite private affection in private faſhion.
Contrecourber, to bend one from another, as Wreſtlers do their backs.
Contre-cueur, as Contrecoeur in the N. D.
Contredigué, fortified againſt banks and ditches.
Contrediguer, to ſet up banks againſt banks.
Contrediſe, and Contredite, for Contradiction, contradiction.
Contr'eſcrire, to confute, or write againſt; alſo to copy, or write out.
Contr'eſcript, confuted, or written againſt; alſo copied, or writ out.
Contr'eſcript, (a Subſt.) a confutation; a copy.
Contr'eſtang, a Pool-dam, a back-pool, or counter-pond; a great ditch, or hollow-ground, whereinto the water of a Pond that's to be fiſhed is let.
Contre-ſente, the bruize or craze of a bone, in another or oppoſite part to the place where the blow that cauſed it was given; which happens eſpecially in the Scull.
Contreferme, an affirmation of that whereof another affirms the contrary.
Contrefermé, the contrary whereof is affirmed or avouched.
Contrefermer, to oppoſe an affirmation unto an affirmation.
Contreſeu, an iron-back or plate for the back of a chimney.
Contreflaté, whoſe flattery is anſwered with flattery.
Contreflater, to flatter as faſt as another.
Contrefortuner, to arm againſt the injuries of fortune.
Contrefrontail, the brow-piece, or upmoſt poſt of a door.
Contrehaſtier, a Rack to turn ſpits on.
Contrehaulte, as Hautecontre in the N. D.
Contre-lettre, a counter-letter, or counter-ward; a private releaſe in diſcharge of a bond paſſed; or a private diſcharge of a duty or ſervice acknowledged before a publick Notary.
Contrelouër, to return praiſe with praiſe.
Contrelutter, to wreſtle, or contend against.
Contremand, Contremandement, a countermand, or countermanding.
Contremejane, the ſecond (or after) mizen of a ſhip.
Contrementir, to ſet one lie against another.
Contremettre, to oppoſe, or ſet against.
Contre-ouvrier, one that works against another.
Contrepan, a pawn, eſpecially of an immovable.
Contrepenſé, thought otherwiſe of than before; diſliked, or diſtruſted.
Contrepenſer, to think otherwiſe than he hath done; to diſlike, or diſtrust.
Contrepenſeur, one that is of another minde than before.
Contrepeter, to anſwer one crack with another.
Contrepicquer, to give one prick for another, to return gird for gird.
Contre-pleige, a Counter-ſurety, one that's bound to ſave a Surety harmleſs.
Contre-pleiger, to ſave a Surety harmleſs by counter-bond, &c.
Contreplié, bent, bowed, or folded back.
Contreplier, to bend, bow, or fold back.
Contrepoinct, back-ſtitch; or as Contre pointe in the N. D. A contrepoinct, croſſly.
Contrepoinctier, for Contrepointeur, a Quilter, or Counterpoint-maker.
Contreporteur, a paultry Pedlar that carries his ſhop before him.
Contreſcedule, as Contrecedule in the N. D.
Contreſign, for Contreſeing, a ſubſcription joyned to another.
Contretaluer, to oppoſe bank to bank, or cauſey to cauſey.
Contre-temperament, a contrary temper. Faire un contre-temperament à la nature, to alter nature.
Contretenir, to hold against, or to debate for a thing against another.
Contretenon, a ſtop in a Watch, or Clock.
Contretenu, held against; alſo claimed, challenged.
Contreteſte, as faire contreteſte, to make head against.
Contretrancher, to fortifie against an Enemy intrenched.
Contrevenger, to revenge one blow, or injury with another.
Contreventer, to hold against the wind.
Contrevention, for Contravention, the breaking of his agreement.
Contr'invective, an anſwer to an invective.
Controlle, as Contre-rolle in the N. D.
Contumacer, to be rebellious; alſo to proceed againſt one for contempt or rebellion.
Contumelie, contumely, ſlander, or ſcandalous rebuke.
Contumelieuſement, contumeliouſly, reproachfully, in deſpightful terms.
Contumelieux, contumelious, outragious, or injurious in words.
Contundre, to braiſe, or ſtamp in pieces.
Contuteur, a joynt Tutor, or Guardian.
Conventioné, for Conventionel, done by agreement.
Convereau, a fi • h ſomewhat reſembling, but leſſer than the Aloſe.
Converſe, a Nun that formerly hath been of looſe behaviour.
Convertiſſement, a converting, turning, or changing.
Convertoir, part of the head, or chapter of a Ionian pillar.
Convice, a reproach, or railing word.
Conviement, an inviting, or bidding unto a feast.
Copelle, for Coupelle, a Goldſmiths Coppel.
Copellé, teſted, melted, or fined, as ſilver in a Test, or Coppel.
Copieux, copious, abundant, plentiful; alſo a well-ſpoken perſon.
Coppe, a meaſure, the half of a Burgundian buſhel.
Coppeter, to ring all in, to ring the last peal.
Coppier, to rouſe and ſtretch out himſelf.
Cops, a certain fiſh like unto a Sturg • on.
Copuland, a coupling, or joyning together.
Copulaſſe, an Exerciſe in Schools, when Scholars diſpute, and he that hath done best is placed higheſt.
Copule, a conjunction, a joyning, or coupling together.
Coquar, an egg, or egg-ſhell; or as
Coquarde, bonnet à la coquarde, a Spaniſh Cap uſed by the best ſort of men; alſo any Cap, or Bonnet worn proudly or pertly on the one ſide.
Coquardeau, a proud aſs, one that hath more wealth than wit.
Coquaſſier, a ſeller of Egg-ſhells; alſo a maker or ſeller of Kettles, or Chaſers.
Coqueliné, dandled, made a wanton of.
Coqueliner un enfant, to dandle a childe, to make a wanton of it.
Coqueluchonné, that wears a hood, or a Spaniſh Capuch.
Coqueplumer, a proud Coxcomb, a Skare-crow.
Coquer, to play the cock, to tread hens like a cock. Se coquer contre, to run his head against.
Coquerelles, Coquerettes, Coquerez, for Coquerets, the herb Alcakengy.
Coqueret, the name of an apple.
Coqueté, cackled, or clucked; alſo ſwaggered.
Coqueter, a Cock to call his hens, or to cluck as a Cock among hens; alſo to ſwagger like a Cock on his hung-hill.
Coquillade, a little fiſh living among rocks.
Coquillard, as Coquardeau; alſo a ſmall Veſſel whereon they ſerve rear-eggs unto the table.
Coquillé, ſet thick with ſhells; alſo made like a ſhell.
Coquiller, to ſet thick with ſhells; or to faſhion a thing like a ſhell.
Coquillier, having, or bearing a ſhell; of, or belonging to a ſhell.
Coquilliere, a woman that makes biggins and caps.
Coquillon, a little ſhell; alſo a little hood; alſo a fools hood; or a hooded fool.
Coralin, of corral, like to corral.
Corapei, a Princes Cloth of State.
Corbillon, for Corbeillon, a little basket.
Corbinet, the croaking of Ravens or Crows.
Corceſque, a kinde of broad-headed javelin, or dart.
Corchiere, the battlement of a wall; alſo as Courſie.
Cordée, a ſtring full of; alſo a rank or file.
Cordeur de Terres, a Surveyor of lands.
Cordilles, the young ſ • y of Tunny.
Cordonné, twiſted; made as, or into a cord.
Cordonner, to twiſt; alſo to make as, or into, a cord.
Cordouannerie, a Shoomakers trade; alſo a Shoomakers row or ſtreet.
Cordule, a ſmall kinde of Lizard.
Core, the broad piece that's between the Croſs-bars of the Hilt of a Sword.
Corions de ſouliers, the latchets of ſhoots.

Cornage, hornage; alſo a yearly Duty of Corn exacted by the Lord Chaſtelain of Berri, in the Juriſdiction of Bourges, upon every Ox that labours in the winter-corn-ground, which is within his Territory.
Cornée de l'oeil, the horny tunicle, wherein the apple of the eye is placed.
Corneur, a winder of a horn.
Cornichet, the Sleeve, or Calamary fiſh.
Cornier, as Cornillier; alſo a horner.
Cornillé, jurred, or butted with horns.
Corniller, to jurr, or butt with the horns.
Corniole, part of a Stags throat • , or as Gargatre.
Coronal, of, or belonging to a Crown, or Crown-like.
Corporail, as Corporal, in the N.D.
Corporance, Corporence, a mans preſence, or conſtitution of body.
Corpſet, a little body; alſo a pair of womens bodies.
Corrente, a Strait of the Sea where commonly it runs violently.
Corret, an agnail, or little corn upon a toe.
Corroder, to wear, or fret away.
Corrugation, a frowning, or wrinkling of the skin.
Corſer, to imbrace, take, or hold by the body; to catch, take, or lay hold of the body.
Corſeſque, a kinde of broad-headed Javelin.
Cortine, for Courtine, a Curtain, (in Fort ••• cation.)
Corveable, liable unto baſe and perſonal ſer • ices; of whom a Landlord may exact certain days work in the year.
Corybanter, madly to run up and down, playing on a Cymbal; alſo to ſl •• p with 〈◊〉 eyes.
Cor • mi e, an I •• -b • rry.
Coſmovague, a wanderer, or traveller throughout the world.
Coſſats de febves, pois, &c. the husks, or cods of beans, &c.
Coſſi, the warbling note of a Swallow.
Coſſonnerie, a Market for Fowl or Veniſon.
Coſſot, for Coſſon, a mite, or weevil.
Coſtal, belonging to the ſides or ribs.
Coſtau, for còteau, a little hill.
Coſtereauls, a nickname given unto certain footmen that ſerved the Kings of England in their French Wars; or as Cotereaux.
Coſtié, on a ſide, of the one ſide; alſo tainted, or bruiſed (being applyed unto fruit.)
Coſtier, ſideling, of, or on a ſide; à coſtiere, aſide, ſideways.
Coſtin, huile coſtin, an Oyl made of Coſtus, a medicinable root.
Coſton, the ſtalk of an herb; alſo the root Coſtus.
Cotereaux, as Coſterauls; Or a certain Crue of peaſantly Outlaws, who in old time did much miſchief to the Nobility and Clergy.
Coterie, company, ſociety; or as Cotterie.
Cotice, as Cottice in the N. D.
Cotivet, the upper part of a hens or capons neck.
Cotte (for Cote) de maille, a coat of mail.
Cotte-maillé, armed with a coat of mail.
Cotterie, a ſervile Tenure, not held in Fee, and yielding only Rent.
Cottier, as Roturier in the N. D.
Cottir, to knock heads together, to cruſh, or bruiſe.
Cottité, a particular mans rate, part, or portion of an Aſſeſſment.
Cottizer, Cottization, as Cotiſer, Cotiſation, in the N. D.
Cottoire de Perles, a chain of Pearls.
Cottonneux, full of cotton, ſoft as cotton.
Cotonniere, the herb Chaſſ-weed, or Cotton-weed.
Cotyle, an ancient meaſure, containing about 24 ſpoonfuls.
Cotyledons, the mouths or ends of the menſtrual veins, whereby the ſuperfluous bloud of all the body falls into the Womb, and gives nouriſhment unto the Child there, if there be any.
Couät, the underling, or ſtarveling of any beaſt or bird.
Couble, as Chevaux de couble, pairs, or couples of horſes.
Couchable, ſit to be lien on.
Couchement, a lying, or laying down.
Coucheur, a layer down; alſo a bedfellow.
Couchine, the name of a certain apple.
Coucon, the little bottom or clue of ſilk ſpun by the Silk-worm.
Coucourbe, Coucourde, a round Gourd; alſo a kind of large Stillatory; or as Courge.
Coucourelle, the name of a certain fig.
Coudeer, to jog with the elbow.
Coudiere, any thing to lean upon with his elbows.
Coudre, a Filherd, Haſel, or Smallnut-tree; alſo their fruit.
Couë, tail d, having a tail.
Couët, the name of a certain apple.

Couëts, two ropes belongi • g to the
mizzen-ſail of a ſhip.
Couëtte, a tick to lie or ſit on.
Coufler, to ſwell, or be puffed up.
Cougourde, Congourle, Couhourde, a bottle-gourd, the round-gourd whereof bottles are made.
Couillage, a Tribute paid in times paſt by Prieſts for Licenſes to keep Wenches.
Couillards, as Clide; or certain round and ringing pieces of iron, which in old time they uſed to ſhoot out of ſhips.
Couillebarbe, the name of a cidar-apple.
Couilleu, ſtoned, or that wants not his ſtones.
Coulagion, the running of a ſore, &c.
Coulans d'un Jardinier, a Gardiner's lines, wherewith he meaſures out his beds and plots.
Coulant de riviere, the ſtream of a river.
Couldoye, à couldoye, made with an nut-neck like an elbow-
Couldray, Couldraye, a plot of ſmall nut-trees.
Coule-ſang, a certain Viper by whom a man being bitten, he bleeds to death.
Couletage, Droict de Couletage, a penny, or half-penny-toll collected and taken of all Wares, or Merchandiſe bought and ſold.
Couleuvré, Couleuvrin, made after the faſhion of an Adder.
Couleuvriner, to ſquat, lurk, or lie cloſe; alſo to glide along.
Coulonëre, a Culla • der; a • ſo a channel, gutter, or any ſuch hollow along which melted things are to run.
Coulper, to blame, to tax, or finde fault with.
Coulure, a gentle running, or ſliding along; a leaking; a ſtraining.
Coupant, a ſpade, or ſuch another earth-cutting Inſtument of huſbandry.
Coupau, a Cuckold; alſo a green Gooſe.
Coupe-oreille, a knife wherewith the ears of Rogues and petty Thieves are cut off.
Coupe-queuë, as deux mots à coupe-queuë, two words and there's an end.
Couperet, a Butchers knife, or cleaver.
Coupeuſe, a woman that reaps, or cuts Grapes in the time of Vintage.
Coupeux, cutting, ſit to cut. Denis coupeuſes, the fore-teeth.
Couplot de bois, the foot of a ſerve, &c.
Coupon, a great cup, or bowl; alſo a tray of wood; alſo a cut of.
Coup-orbe, red pimples on the face.
Courbatu, worn out, or grown crooked with toyling and moyling; alſo foundered.
Courbature, the foundering of a horſe.
Courbe, a crooked, or bowing piece of timber. Courbes d'une Voulte, the arching of a Vault.
Courbée, as Corvée in the N. D.
Courbe-eſpine, the name of an apple.
Courcaillée de cailles, the calling of Quails.
Courcie, the Courſey, part of a Galley.
Courpendu, as Capendu in the N. D.
Courratage, Courraterie, brokage; horſe-courſing; buſie dealing, or intermeddling between party and party.
Courratier, a Broker; alſo a Meſſenger, or Foot-post. Courratier de chevaux, a Horſe-courſer.
Courreau d'une huiſſerie, the bolt, or bar of a door.
Courroyer, for Conroyer, to dreſs leather.
Courſerot, a little Corſair; alſo a little Courſer, or horſe of ſervice.
Courſier (Adj.) belonging, or like unto a Courſer.
Courſiere, the Grating in a Man of War.
Courſon, a young Vine-branch, or ſhoot reſerved for ſtore.
Court-d'aleaume, the name of a bitter-ſweet apple.
Courvé, for Courbé, bent, or bowed.
Couſiner, to claim kindred for advantage.
Couſinette, the name of an Apple.
Couſſer, to butt, or jurr, as Rams do.
Couſſi, the name of a ſmall black grape.
Couſſineux, ſtored with cuſhions; ſoft as a cuſhion.
Couſſon, the guſſet of a ſhirt or ſmock; alſo a mite, or weevil.
Couſtau, as Côtau, a little hill.
Couſtilier, Couſtillier, an Armour-bearer unto a Knight; alſo a Groom of a ſtable.
Couſtumerie, a Cuſtome-levying or taking; alſo a place where Cuſtome is due.
Couſtumier, a cuſtomary Tenant, a Copy-holder.

Couſtumier (Adj.) cuſtomary, uſual. Bourſe couſtumiere, a purchaſe of lana made, or price given for a purchaſe by a Yeoman or Roturier. Païs Couſtumier, a Country governed by particular Cuſtoms. Quint Couſtumier, the Portion of younger Brethren left by their father, being (by the cuſtome of divers places) a fifth part only divided among them.
Couſtumiers, old and experienced Lawyers, able to inform the Court what the Law and local Cuſtoms are in any caſe.
Couſturiers, certain long Muſcles in the outward part of the thigh, which they make pliable to croſs one leg over another.
Coutau, for Côtau, a little hill.
Coutelaſſe ſur le viſage, a fleſh over the face with a cuttelas.
Coutelaſſé, ſlaſhed, or cut with a cuttelas.
Coutelaſſer, to ſlaſh, or cut with a cuttelas.
Coutes, the ſeams, or diſtances that are between plank and plank in a ſhip.
Coutillade, a cut made by an edge-tool.
Couton, a faggot-ſtick, or the thick ſtalk of cabbage, &c.
Coutre, for Coteret, a faggot made of great ſticks.
Coutrepoincter, as Contrepointer, in the N. D.
Couvade, as ouvée, in the N. D.
Couveleque, the lid of a pot.
Couvertoir, a trick, or engine wherewith water-fowl is caught.
Couvi, oeuf couvi, an addle egg.
Couvine, the canning carriage of a buſineſs.
Couvoir, a hens neſt, alſo the top of a bed in a garden.
Couvre-ordure, gold; alſo a womans mask.
Coyed, as Cayer, in the N. D.
Coypellé, chipped, cut as a ſtick.
Coypeller, to chip, to cut a ſtick.
Coytes. ta •• , great ropes uſed about the Main-ſail of a ſhip.
Crac, a crack, or thing that cracks.
Crainſer, to ſhrink, alſo to crackle.
Cramas, ſtones torn from rocks by tempeſt, &c.
Crampelle, the name of a fiſh.
Cranequin, the gaffle of a croſs-bow; alſo as Crennequin.
Cranequinier, a croſs-bow-man; or as Crennequinier; alſo an inferiour Officer, that had of old the care of warlike Engines.
Crappe, the crab-fiſh called a Pungar.
Creac, Creal, a Sturgeon. Creac de buſe, a Scate-fiſh.
Creancer, to promiſe; alſo to taſte another mans meat or drink.
Credos, as qui fait credos charge ſon dos, he that lendeth often loo •• th.
Creiche, for Creche, a rack, a • a • ger.

Crema • cres,
• o • inews o • Muſcles, wher by t •• cods 〈◊〉 .
Cremillée, Cremillere, a pot hang r.
Cremer, to pear, to dr • ad.
Cren, Crené, a ſnip in a knife, tool, &c. alſo a 〈◊〉 th • nib of a pe • .
Creneau, for recoin, a nook, or corner.
Crennequin, as Cranequin; alſo a kinde of horſe-mans head-piece like a Helmet.
Crenquinier, a Serjeant, or Officer that can ſerve Executions.
Crenure, as Creneure, and as Cren.
Crepets, or Crepez, Fritters, alſo Wafers.
Creſme, as Chreſme in the N. D.
Creſmeau, as Chrêmeau in the N. D.
Creſpe, Cipres, alſo Cobweb-lawn. Creſpe de chaperon, the crepine of a French hood.
Creſpelure, a c •• ling, o • ru • fling.
Creſper, to crack, or ſcreek; alſo to craſh between the teeth; to crisp; to ſleek.
Creſſerelle, as Crecerelle in the N. D.
Creſſonadiere, Creſſonnerie, a bed of Creſſes.
Cretons, criſpy pieces or mammocks of Lard.
Criage, a crying, the Cryers Office, or his fee.
Cribleux, full of holes as a ſive.
Cridons, certain thick hairs of a pins length.
Crie, a cry, a Cryers fee, a Cryer.
Crimination, a charging with a crime.
Criniere, a hair-cloth; a hood for a horſe; an armour for the neck or mane of a horſe; a lock of hair.
Criquer, for Criqueter, to give a crack.
Criſtalin, of, or belonging to Chryſtal, or Chryſtal-like.
Croac, the croaking of Ravens, Frogs, or Toads.
Croailler, Croaillement, and Croaillerie. See Croaſſer, and Croaſſement in the N. D.
Croaquer, to croak as a Raven.
Croaſſeur, one that croaks like a Raven, or Toad.
Crochement des dents, the outward bending of the teeth.
Crocheton, a ſilver coin ſo called.
Crocodilée, a M dicine made of ſome parts of a Crocodile.
Crocomagnie, an Oyntment made of Saffron, alſo the dregs of Saffron-oyl.
Croiſadeur, that makes the ſigne of the croſs.
Croiſeur, one that ſets or marks a croſs on any thing.
Croiſie, a croſs, a croſſing, or marking with a croſs.
Crolant, as bois crolant d'un Ladre, a Lazers-clack, or clicket.
Cronique, as Chronique in the N. D.
Crope, Croppe, the top of a hill.
Croque-jarret, one that goes in with his hams.
Croque-quenouille, he that is beaten by his wife with a diſtaff.
Croquer, to crack; to catch, or ſnatch.
Croqueter, to pick out the beſt bits; alſo to feed greedily.
Croqueteur, a gormandizer, a greedy feeder.
Cros, deep holes digged into the earth to preſerve corn in.
Croſilles, the ſhells which Pilgrims near about their hats.
Crotaphiques, the two muſcles of the Temples.
Croteſque, as Groteſque in the N. D.
Crotpeſcheret, a kind of black Oſprey.
Crotton, a deep hole, a filthy dungeon.
Crouäcement, Crouäs, the croaking of Ravens.
Crouë d'un Preſſoir, the uppermost board of a Preſs, and the hole thereof whereinto the Vice-pin enters.
Crouillet, the latch of a door.
Croulier, as prez crouſier, quagmire-like, ſhaking under ones feet.
Crouſille, the ſhell-fiſh called a Scallop.
Crouſiller entre les dents, to craſh between the teeth.
Crouſteau, a great cruſt, or great ſcab.
Crouſlelevé, beſcabbed, full of the pox.
Crouſtelles, Crouſtellettes, little cruſts, or ſcabs.
Crucher, to crouch; alſo to make hollow like a pitcher.
Cruente, le flux cruente, the bloudy flux.
Crujon, Cruon, any round thing, as a mans ſcull.
Crural, of, or belonging to the thigh.
Crytoportique, a ſecret walk, or vault under ground.
Cubebes, Cubebs, an Aromatical and Indian fruit.
Cubiculaire, a Groom of the Chamber.
Cubiculaire (Adj.) of, or belonging to the Chamber.
Cubital, of, or belonging to a cubit.
Cucurbitin, of, or belonging to Gourds.
Cucuye, the name of a bird.
Cueux de plomb, a ſow of lead.
Cuferin, a horſes running at the noſe.
Cuigner, to hold open with wedges.
Cuignet, a little corner; alſo a little wedge.
Cuiraſſeux, thick and ſtiff as a hide.
Cuiſinal, of, or belonging to a kitchin.
Cuiſineux, fit for Cookery, belonging to the kitchin.
Cuiſſal, for Cuiſſar, an armour for the thigh.
Cuiſſedame, the name of a kind of pear.
Cuiſſier, of, or belonging to the thigh.
Cuiſſinet, for couſſinet, a little cuſhion.
Cuiſſots, taſſes, armour for the thighs.
Culace, Culaſon, for Culaſſe, the breech of a gun.
Culaſſeur, one that foils, or ſets another on his tail.
Culeron, the hinder part of the buttocks of a horſe.
Culetage, Culetis, a leacherous motion of the back-ſide.
Culeter, to ſtir the buttocks up and down.
Culette, for Culaſſe, the breech of a gun.
Culier, of, or belonging to the arſe.
Culiere, a crupper for a horſe.
Culinaire, of, or belonging to a kitchin.
Cullot, as Culot; alſo a cuſhion made to ride poſt on.
Culpe d'un artichau, the pulp or ſubſtance of an Artichoke.
Cultellaire, of a knife, like a knife.
Cume (for cuve) de preſſoir, the trough which receives the liquor expreſſed.
Cuniculeux, full of inward holes, or by-corners.
Cupule, the cup of an acorn.
Curailles de maiſon, the ſweepings of a houſe.
Cure, for ſoin, care, heed, or regard.
Curial, of, or belonging to a Court.
Curie, a Tribe, or Ward in a City.
Curtin, the name of an apple.
Cuſcoamy, Cuſcouil, well hanged, well ſtoned.
Cuſcute, a kind of worm; alſo the weed Dodder.
Cuſtode (for Gardien) a Guardian. Cuſtode de lit, a bed-curtain.
Cutané, skinny, or of the skin.
Cuticulaire, full of Pores for ſweat to come out at.
Cuviel, Cuvier, a Bathing-tub; alſo a Dying-fat, or lead.
Cuviere, a Ceſtern to cool drinking-pots in Summer.
Cyboïde, Os Cyboïde, a certain bone in the inſtep.
Cyclamine, the herb Hogs-bread; the wilde Vine; Wood-nightſhade.
Cygnean, like a Swan, of, or belonging to a Swan.
Cymace, Cymas, as Cymaiſe in the N. D.
Cymacion, Cymat, a ſmall Ogee in building.
Cymettes. See Cyme in the N. D.
Cymier, as Cimier in the N. D.
Cymiti • re, for Cimetiere, a Churchyard.
Cynamolge, an Arabian bird that uſed to ſuck bitches.
Cyntre, as Cintre in the N. D.
Cypreſſier, of, or belonging to a Cypras-tree-
Cyre, as Sire in the N. D.
Cyron, for ciron, a ha • d-worm.
Cyſtique, the name of a v • in.
Cythariſer, to ſing, or whizze as the wind.
Dablée, a crop of corn, corn-growing.
Dacque, the name of a weed.
Dactier, for datier, the Palm, or Date-tree.
Dactilaire, of, or belonging to a Date; alſo Date-like.
Dactylogie, ſpeech made with the fingers.
Dagobert, the name of a pear.
Dagorie, the name of an apple.
Daguer, to ſtab with a dagger.
Dail, a ſithe to mow with.
Daille, the name of a Shell-fiſh.
Daine, Daing, the name of a Sea-fiſh.
Daintiers, the doucets of a Deer.
Daiſſellé, made of, or covered with boards.
Dalader, a kind of fruitleſs privet.
Daldre, Dale, the name of a Flemiſh Coin.
Dameret, as Damoiſeau in the N. D.
Dam • on, the name of an apple.
Da • din, a M • ac • ck.
Dandiner, to gape and look like an Aſs.
Danſpied, the hollow part of the ſole of the foot.
Dante, the name of an Indian beast.
Daphnomantie, divination by a Laurel or Bay-tree.
Dapifer, the great Maſter or Steward of the Kings houſe.
Dardanaire, Dardanier, an Ingroſſer of any Commodity.
Darde, the name of a boyiſh play.
Dardereſſe, a woman that caſteth a dart.
Dardeur, a thrower of a dart.
Dardiller, to ſhake like a dart cast with violence.
Darioles, a kind of ſmall Paſties.
Dariolette, a Bawd, or carrier of Love-meſſages.
Davier, a pinſer to draw out teeth withal; alſo a kind of pick-lock.
Dauſſe d'ail, a clove of Garlick.
ſe Dauſſer, to be divided into ſeveral parts or cloves, like a head of Garlick.
Debaccher, Debaquer, to take on like a drunken man.
Debatis, the unquiet flattering of a Hawk.
Debeller, to conq •• r, o • ſubdue.

De • endade, for Debandade. c •• ſ •
ſion, want of order.
Debiffé, razed, or ſcraped out; ſplit aſunder.
Debiffer, to raze, or ſcrape out. Se debiffer, to ſplit aſunder.
Debiller, to unloſe the rope of a boat, &c.
Deboire, an after-taſt, which an unſavoury thing leaves behinde in the mouth.
Deboité, for Deboëté, put out of joynt.
Deboſquer, to ruſh out of a wood.
Debriſé, ſplit aſunder; alſo nimbly footed in dancing.
Decadenaſſer, to undo a padlock; alſo to reſolve a riddle.
Decal d'argent, want of allay in ſilver.
Decaller, to ſlacken, or grow ſoft.
Decimal, of, or belonging to tythes.
Deciſ •• re, a • t to decide.
Decourir, to run down; alſo to purge downwards.
Decouru, run down; alſo purged downwards.
Decrepité, for decrepit, decrepite, very old.
Decretant, the Creditor, at whoſe ſuit the Debtors goods are decreed to be ſold.
Decretation, an Order paſſed in Court for the ſale of a Debtors goods, or a proceeding thereby.
Decruſtation, a paring off of the crust.
Decruſter, to pare off the cruſt.
Decuiſant, boyling or ſeething very much.
Decuit, boyled or ſodden very much; alſo unſodden, made raw again.
Decurie, a band of ten Senators, or Souldiers.
Dedicaſſe, and Dedication, for Dedicace, a Dedication.
Defaille, Defaillement, a default, defect, or ſailing; a pining away.
Defaitte, as Defaite, in the N. D.
Defardé, whoſe painting is wiped off.
Defauciller, to put out of joynt.
Defaux, the ground or paſture wherein a beaſt ſhould not be.
Defendo, the name of a Play.
Deferrure, an unſhooing of an horſe.
Deffaicte, as Defaite in the N. D.
Deffaire, and Deffait, as Defaire, and Defait in the N. D.
Deffaveur, Deffavoriſer, as Defaveur and Defavoriſer in the N. D.
Defferrer, as Deferrer in the N. D.
Deffier, Deffiance, as Defier, Defiance in the N. D.
Deffiler, Deffilé. See them with a ſingle f in the N. D.
Deffleurer, as Defleurer in the N. D.
Deffriché, as Defriché in the N. D.
Deffroncer, as Defronſer in the N. D.
Deffroqué, as Defroqué in the N. D.
Definement, a pining, or waſting away. Le definement du monde, the latter end of the world.
Definer, to pine, or waſte away.
ſe Deflicher, to pluck arrows out of his body.
Defloration, the change from a flouriſhing colour to the contrary.
ſe Deflorer, to ſhed or let fall its flowers.
Defrichage, as Defrichement in the N. D.
ſe Defriper, to ſcrub with the ſhoulders.
Defueiller, as Defeuiller in the N. D.
Defunctoirement, by deſcent, or ſucceſſion after the deceaſe of another.
Degaerie, the Office or Circuit of an Ʋnder-Bayliff.
Degalico, waxen poor, gone down the wind.
Degaſouiller, to ſing or warble fast and confuſedly.
Degaſtement, a deſtroying, ruining, or ravaging.
Degaſter, to deſtroy, ruine, or ravage.
Degonder, to lift, or heave off the hinges.
Degreſſeur, for Degraiſſeur, a ſcowrer of greaſie things.
Degroumeler, to unclot a thing that's cluttered.
Deguener, for Degainer, to draw his ſword.
Dehayté, loathed as meat, alſo out of tune.
Dehayter, to loath meat, to be out of tune.
Dehotté, drawn out of the mire.
Dehotter, to draw out of the mire.
Dehouſé, diſpatched, rid out of the way; alſo unbooted.
Deject, Dejecté, dejected, or cast down.
Dejecter, to deject. Se dejecter, to ſtand on terms.
Dejectement, a dejecting; alſo a contemptible repulſe.
Deillavier, to ſtarve, to bereave of life.
Delivre, after-birth. A delivre, looſely, freely.
Delocher, to put out of joynt.
Deltoïde, the name of a muſcle.
Deluter, to take the dirt off.
Demachoirer, to tear a jaw from.
Demacqué, ſpit out of the mouth.
Demacquer, to ſpit out of the mouth.
Demainier, an Owner of a Demain.
Demaiſonné, turned out of a houſe.
Demaiſonner, to turn out of a houſe.
Demange-chair, ſetting an itch on the fleſh.
Demener deuil, to lament, or to mourn. Demener joye, to rejoyce. Demener marchandiſe, to trade. Demener un proces, to follow a ſuit.
ſe Dementer, to bewail himſelf. Se dementer de, to medd •• with.
Demeurance, a ſtaying, manſion, or dwelling.
Demi-ceinctier, Demicinctier, a maker of half-girdles.
Demi-eſpineux, the name of a muſcle.
Demi-lict, brotherhood, or ſiſterhood on the one ſide onely.
Demonachation, an abandoning, or depriving of Monkiſh profeſſion.
Demoure, and Demourer, as Demeure, and Demeurer in the N. D.
Demouſſer, to rid (or bare) of moſs.
Demyon, the quarter of a French pint.
Denaire, the number of ten, or a tenth.
Dendrille, the rag wherewith a leaking tub is ſtopped; alſo a mans privities.

Deneantiſe, extream baſeneſs, or vil •
neſs.
Dentade, a bit of the teeth.
Dentelé (Su • rt.) a kind of miſchievous Dog-fiſh.
Dentelet, a little tooth; alſo a meal.
Denteliz, teeth, or a tooth-like notching in Imagery. &c.
Dentier, the part of an Helmet that covers the teeth.
Deparqué, broke out of a Park, got away.
ſe Deparquer. to • ak out of a Park, to 〈◊〉 .
Departiment, Departiſſement, as Departement in the N. D.
Deperir, to be undone, to periſh.
Depié de fief, an aliening part of an Inheritance.
Deplicer, for Depliſſer, to undo the plaits.
Deplumation, an unfeathering; alſo an inflamed and hard thickneſs of the eye-lids.
Depoché, pulled out of a pocket.
Depocher, to pull out of a pocket.
Depopuler, Depopulé. See Depeupler, Depeuple in the N. D.
Depourprer, to unpurple, or make pale.
Depriant (a Subſt.) a purchaſer that upon requeſt agrees with the Lord Cenſuel for his Lods and Ventes.
Derbro, the name of a Sea-fiſh.
Derceau, a little Dace, or Dare-fiſh.
Derme, the skin which covers the extream parts of the body.
Derrain, Derrainer, Derrenier, for dernier, laſt.
Derrider, as Derider in the N. D.

Ders, a Cloth of State, a Cano
• y.
Derſelet, a little Canopy, or Cloth of State.
Dertre, for Dartre, a Tetter, or Ring-worm.
Deſabiller, Deſabillé. See Deſhabiller, Deſhabillé in the N. D.
Deſaccointé, grown a ſtranger to one.
Deſadvenant, a portion of an Inheritance left a Vaſſal, but not ſufficient for the Homage due unto the Lord.
Deſaffleurer, to pluck the flowers from, to hinder the flouriſhing of.
ſe Deſagenouiller, to get up from kneeling.
Deſaimé, fallen into the diſlike of.
Deſaimer, to deſ • t from l •• ing.
Deſairer, to ſpoil and deſtroy an A •• y of Hawks.
Deſaiſe, a being ill at • aſ, a diſeaſe.
Deſaiſe, ill at eaſe, di eaſed.
Deſamaſſer. t fall down a •• ap.

Deſanger, to extirpate, or deſtroy t ••
• a • . of.
Deſapetiſſance, a diſtaſt, or loathing of meats.
Deſapetiſſer, to take away the appetite.
Deſapointer, as Deſappointer in the N. D.
Deſareſter, to take the bones out of fiſh.
Deſarnacher, as Deſharnacher in the N. D.
Deſaſſocié, parted from the company of.
Deſattiſé, put out, as a kindled firebrand.
Deſattiſer, to put out a firebrand.
Desbandée, à la desbandée, out of their ranks.
Desbarbouiller, to make clear from ſpots.
Desbaſtiment, a pulling down of buildings.
Desbaſtir, to pull down a building.
Desbaudir, to make ſad, or aſhamed.
Desbauger, to rowſe a wild Boar from the place he lies in.
Desboëture, a putting out of joynt.
Desboiſté, Desboité, unboxed; put out of joynt.
Desboiſtement, the being out of joynt.
Desboiſter, Desboiter, to unbox; to put out of joynt.
Desborné, whoſe bounds are laid open.
Desbornement, a laying open of bounds.
Desborner, to lay open the bounds.
Desbourbé, drawn out of the mire.
Desbourber, to draw out of the mire.
Desbourgeonner, to pluck, or nip off young buds.
Desbrigandiner, to deprive of a brigandine.
Desbrodequiné, whoſe buskins are drawn off.
Desbuiſſonné, driven out of a thicket.
Desbuiſſonner, to drive out of a thicket.
Deſceptrer, to deprive of a Scepter.
Deſceu, as Inſceu in the N. D.
Deſchambrer, to ſeparate people that lived in a chamber.
Deſchampé, got out of the fold.
Deſchamper, to get out of the fold.
Deſcharges, coſts and charges in a Suit.
Deſcharongner, to tear fleſh in pieces.
Deſcharper, Deſcharpir, to take off the nap of cloth. Je ne me puis deſcharpir de luy, I cannot rid my ſelf of him.
Deſchaud, & Deſchault, as Dechaux, in the N. D.
Deſcheveſtrer, to take off the halter.
Deſcigler, as Deciller in the N. D.
Deſcirer, Deſciré, as Déchirer, Dechiré in the N. D.
Deſclaveter un Canon, to diſmount a Cannon.
ſe Deſcombatre de, to rid his hands of.

Deſcombré,
• leared of incumbrances; alſo warranted.
Deſcombrement, a clearing of incumbrances; alſo a warranting (in Law.)
Deſcombrer, to clear of incumbrances; alſo to warrant (in Law.)
Deſconſeilleur, an adviſer to the contrary.
Deſcouché, put out of his lodging; alſo got up.
Deſcoucher, to put one out of his lodging. Se deſcoucher, to get up.
Deſcoulourer, Deſcoulouré, Deſcoulourement. See Décolorer, &c. in the N. D.
Deſcri, Deſcrier, Deſcrié. See them without ſ in the N. D.
Deſcrit de monoie, the calling in of money.
Deſcroire, to give no credit to.
Deſcuvé, tak n out of • tab.
Deſcuver, to take out of a tub.
Deſdamer, to deprive a Lady of her title; alſo to take a Queen at Draughts.
Deſdetter, to rid out of debt.
Deſdommage, or Dedommagement in the N. D.
Deſembrocher, to pull off the ſpit.
Deſembuſché, got out from among buſhes.
Deſembucher, (Subſt.) that part of a thicket, whereout wilde beaſts uſe to go into the Plains.
ſe Deſembuſcher, to ruſh up from among buſhes.
Deſemmuré, taken out of a wall; unwalled.
Deſemmurer, to take a thing out of a wall; alſo to unwal.
Deſempeſcher, to make a clear riddance.
Deſemplumer, to pluck the feathers off.
Deſendetter, to bring out of debt.
Deſenfourné, drawn out of an oven.
Deſenfourner, to draw out of an oven.
Deſengeance, the race whereof is extingui • hed.
Deſengeancer, to extinguiſh the race of.
Deſenger, to pluck up by the root.
Deſengroſſer, to miſcarry (meant of a woman with child.)
Deſentourner, to turn, or wind off.
Deſequipper un Navire, to unrig a ſhip.
Deſeſperade, a kind of mournful Song. Jouer à la deſeſperade, to throw at all.
Desfacer, for Effacer, to blot out.
Desfaire, Desfaict, Desfaicte, as Defaire, Defait, Defaite in the N. D.
Desferre, caſt cloaths; alſo an intangl d buſineſs. Ces gens ſont de faſcheuſe desferre, theſe men are hard to be pleaſed.
Desferre-cheval, the ſmall Pulſe called Horſe-ſhooe.
Desfiement, a defying, alſo a diſtruſting.
Desflammer, to put out the flame.
Desfoncer, Desfoncé. See Defonſer in the N. D.
Desfroy, a defraying, or bearing of charges.
ſe Desfuler, to put off his cap.
Deſgaine, Deſgainade, a drawing out of a weapon. Il y marcha bien d'une autre deſgaine, he went about it with another manner of reſolution.
Deſgeſter un lievre, to put a Hare off her form.
D • ſgozillé, whoſe t • roat is cut.
Deſgrapher, as Deſagraſer in the N. D.
Deſgravir, to fetch, or throw down a climbing thing.
Deſgreſſer, Deſgreſſé. See Dégraiſſer in the N. D.
Deſgroſſer, Deſgroſſé. See Degroſſir, Degroſſi in the N. D.
Deſguilleter, to unty, or undo points; alſo to take points from.
Deſguiſeure, as Déguiſement in the N. D.
Deſhalé de famine, worn away through hunger.
Deſhanché, whoſe hips are out of joynt.
Deſhancher, to put the hips out of joynt.
Deſhanter, to leave the company of.
Deſheaulmer, to take a helmet off.
Deſhingander, to lift off the hinges.
Deſhouſé, whoſe boots are pulled off.
Deſhouſſé, whoſe horſe-cloth is taken off.
Deſinfecter, to take off the infection.
Deſintereſſer, to ſave harmleſs, to rid from all intereſt in.
ſe Desjouer, for quitter le jeu, to leave off playing.
Deſlaicter, to milk; alſo to wean.
Deſlayer, Deſleer, to ſoften, to ſoak.
Deſlouëure, the putting of a thing out of its place.
Deſmaillé, cut in pieces as a coat of mail.
Deſmailler, to cut in pieces a coat of mail.
Deſmaillure, a cutting of mail in pieces.
Deſmaiſonné, turned out of the houſe.
Deſmaiſonner, to turn out of the houſe.
Deſmandibuler, to break the jaws of.
Deſmarcher, to ſtep, or go back.
Deſmoëller, to take away the marrow; alſo to weaken.
Deſmorché, without pouder in the touch-hole.
Deſnaturer, to make unnatural; to weaken nature; to renounce his natural Prince or Country.
Deſnouëure, as Dénouëment in the N. D.
Deſpaiſement, the driving one out of his Country; alſo a leaving of rude Country-faſhions.
Deſpampé, bared as a Vine of leaves.
Deſpamper, Deſpamprer, to pull the lea • es off a Vine.
Deſpence, &c. See Dépenſe in the N. D.
Deſpercher, to throw off a perch.
Deſplaiſance, grief; alſo a diſpleaſure, or ill-turn.
Deſplumer, to pull off the feathers.
Deſpourpré, whoſe purple hue is loſt.
ſe Deſpourprer, to loſe its purple hue.
Deſprier, to deſire to the contrary.
Deſpriſonner, to get out of priſon.
Deſpu • elage, Leſpucellement, a deflowring of a Virgin.
Deſracher, to pluck off, or tear away.
Deſrene, a proof of the denial of a fact.
Deſrener, to make good the denial of a fact.
Deſreumé, whoſe rheum is dried up.
Deſreumer, to dry up the rheum.
Deſroché, beaten out of a rock; alſo thrown down a rock.
Deſrocher, to beat out of a rock; alſo to throw down a rock.
Deſrondir, to bring out of roundneſs.
Deſrouler, to lay open, to unfold.
Deſrouter, to put by, to rout.
Deſruer, to miſtake one ſtreet for another.
Deſſarrier, a woman to caſt her childe.
Deſſeiller, as Deſiller in the N. D.
Deſſengler, as Decengler in the N. D.
Deſſente, the gout proceeding from a rheum.
Deſſerre, a ſudden opening; a releaſing.
Deſſerte, as Deſſert in the N. D.
ſe Deſſoiver, to quench his thirſt.
Deſſonger, to awake out of a dream ſtarting.
Deſſous-mis, the name of a Muſcle.
Déſtacher, for ôter une tache, to take off a ſpot.
Deſtailler, to hack; alſo to ſell by retail.
Deſteindre, to ſlain; alſo to put out a light.
Deſteler, as Deſatteler in the N. D.
Deſtenture, a letting, or taking down.
Deſtrabord, ſtarboard, the right ſide of a ſhip.
Deſtraincte d'amour, an extremity of paſſion in love.
Deſtraindre, to ſtrain, alſo to ſtraiten.
Deſtrapé, ſtamped with the feet; alſo rid from intanglements.
Deſtraper, to ſlamp with the feet; alſo to clear the feet from the things intangling them.
Deſtrempis, as Deſtrempement, a ſleeping in water.
Deſtriar, a ſteed, a great horſe.
Dezvalizer, to rob one of his Cloakhag.
Deſveiné, bereft of all his veins, or bloud.
Deſveiner, to deprive one of his veins.
Deſvier, to miſlead; alſo to die.
Deſultoire, Chevaux deſultoires, two horſes from the one whereof an active rider leaps upon the other in a full career; alſo led horſes kept freſh for Souldiers uſe.
Detaillé, cut into pieces; alſo ſold by retail.
Detailler, to cut into pieces; alſo to ſell by retail.
Determinance, an Order, a Decree; a determination of a matter already debated.
Detomber, to take out of a tomb.
Detraquer quelcun, le débaucher, to take one off from his work.
Detrichouëre, as Dextrochere; alſo the fold of leather wherewith Yarn-winders preſerve their fingers from ſcars; alſo the ſharp iron wherein the quill or ſpindle of a wheel doth twirl.
Deuës à vetando, Priviledges of forbidding others to fiſh or gather ſticks in his waters or woods.
Deveſt, a diſadveſture, or as Deſſaiſine.
Deveſtir, to put himſelf out of poſſeſſion of.
Deveſtu, put out of poſſeſſion of.
Devideau, a little pair of Yarn-windles.
Devidereſſe, a woman that winds Yarn.
Devidoire, for devidoir, a pair of Yarn-windles.
Devinereſſe, a woman that foretels things to come.
Deviſer, to talk, to diſcourſe; alſo to deviſe.
Devolut, as Devolutaire in the N. D.
Devolutif, devolutive, ready, or like to devolve.
Devolution, a devolution, or falling into lapſe.
Deuſdet, as Maſſe d'armes in the N. D.
Dextrochere, the right arm (from the elbow to the wriſt) whereon there hangs a Maniple fringed at the bottom, and charged all over with Ermines.
Dez en dez, by and by.
Diabete, a continual and immoderate voiding of urine, accompanied with extreme thirst.
Diablerie, deviliſhneſs; alſo a deviliſh Crue.
Diacartami, a kind of purging compoſition.
Diacatholicon, a compoſition purging all kind of humours.
Diaciminon, a compoſition made of Simples fit to diſſolve windineſs in the ſtomack.
Diaconal, of, or belonging to a Deacon.
Diaconie, Deaconry, the place of a Deacon.
Diagalange, a Salve made of Galingale.
Diagonal, extending from one corner to another.
Diagredé, an ointment made of the gum Diagredi.
Diagredi, a ſtrong purging gu • deſtilled from the root of the 〈◊〉 S • ammony.
Dialthée, the name of an Oyntment.
Diamantin, of a Diamond, as hard as a Diamond.
Diamargariton, an Electuary made of Pearls.
Diamerdis, a confection of Turds, Pilgrims ſalve; alſo a ſhitten fellow.
Diamoſchum, a kind of cordial powder.
Dianier, conſecrated to Diana, or that hath vowed chaſtity.
Dianiſum, an Electuary made of Anniſeeds and other things good to break wind.
Diantre, the Devil, the God of darkneſs.
Diapaſon, a Diapaſon in Muſick; a Gage to meaſure Casks with.
Diapente, a Powder or Compoſition wherein there are five Simples equally incorporated.
Diaphenicum, a kind of purging Electuary.
Diapré, diapered, diverſifi'd with ſundry figures.
Diaprer, to diaper, to diverſifie with flouriſhes.
Diaprerie, Diapreure, flouriſhing in work, or flouriſht work.
Diarrhoëtique, that has got a task.
Diarrodon, a kind of pain-abating Syrrup.
Diarthroſe, a connexion of bones that evidently move together.
Diaſené, Diaſenné, a purging Compoſition made of Sene, or Triſoly.
Diaſtolé, the dilatation of the heart.
Diatipoſe, a double deſcription, or figuring.
Diaule, a meaſure containing two furlongs.
Dicaſter, the Judges of the antient Thelans.
Dietique, of, or belonging to Diet; preſcribing a diet.
Differanté, differed, or diſagreed from; at variance with; alſo diverſified.
Differanter, to differ, or diſagree from; to be at variance with.
Difficulter, to make difficult; alſo to make bones of.
Digame, one that hath two Wives together; alſo one that hath had two Wives.
Digitation, the form of the fingers of both hands joyned together; or the manner of their ſo joyning.
Dilapider, to dilapidate; alſo to rid of ſtones.
Dille, the quill or faucet of a hogſhead, &c.
Dillon, a quinſel, for a horſe.
Dinanderie, broken ware, Tinkers work; alſo the place where ſuch ſtuff is ſold or made.
Dinarchie, the joynt Government of two Princes.
Dintiers, the dowcets or cods of a Deer.
Dipſade, a Snake, whoſe biting brings with it a mortal dryneſs.
Directer, to direct; alſo to acknowledge from whence a good cometh.
Diſceptatrice, a woman that debates a matter.
Diſcommoder, to diſcommodate, hurt, indamage, or hinder.
ſe Diſcoſter de, to rid himſelf of.
Diſcraſié, pulled, haled; of an ill complexion.
Diſcrucier, to vex, or afflict extremely.
Diſcuteur, a diſcuſſer, examiner, debater; alſo a valuer or praiſer of goods.
Diſeaux de gerbes, ſheafs of corn ſet ten and ten in a heap.
Diſenier, as Dixainier in the N. D.
Disferre, an horſe-ſhooe of two pieces joyned together at the top with an iron pin.
Diſmages, Tythings, or matters belonging to Tythes.
Diſparate, errour; alſo a ſenſeleſs and uncivil thing.
Diſpenſaire, a Book that teacheth how to make all Phyſical Compoſitions.
Diſruption, a burſting, or breaking aſunder.
Diſſemeler, to unſole, or put the ſoles off a ſhoe.
Diſſociation, a diſſociation, or ſeparation of fellowſhip.
Diſtract, any diſtraction, or diviſion of a Contract, Right, or Act.
Diſtrict, a Diſtrict, the Liberties or Precincts of a place.
Diſtroict, as Diſtrict. Diſtroict de Moulin, as Banlieuë de Moulin.
Dite, à ſa dite, at his nod, after his will and pleaſure.
Divaguer, to ſtray, or wander about.
Dixenier, as Dixainier in the N. D.
Dixme, Dixmer, as Díme, Dimer in the N. D.
Dizain, a tenth; alſo a Stanza of ten Verſes; a pair of beads containing ten pieces; a French penny.
Dizaine, as Dixaine in the N. D.
Dodacaëdre, a Geometrical figure of 12 faces.
Dodelinement, a rocking, dandling, or lolling.
Dodeliner, to rock, dandle, or loll. Dodeliner de la teſte, to carry his head unſteadily.
Dodelineur, the rocker of a cradle.
Dodelineux, a rocker; alſo one that nods much; alſo a fawning companion.
Dodine, as Dodelinement. Canards à la dodine, Ducks with French onion-ſauce.
Dodo; as apres bu dodo, after drink ſleep.
Dodrental, nine ounces heavy; nine inches, or a full ſpan long.
Dogguin, a filthy great old Cur.
Dogmatiſte, a forger of new Sects or Opinions.
Doil, a Pipe-ſtaff; alſo any Veſſel or Cask of a reaſonable big ſize.
Doler, to plane, or hew ſmooth.
Dolouëre, as Doloire in the N. D.
Doloureuſement, heavily, ſorrowfully; alſo grievouſly, till it ake again.
Doloureux, woful, ſorrowful; alſo painful. Parties doloureuſes, tender parts that cannot endure to be touched.
Domanial, of, or belonging to a Lordſhip.
ſe Domicilier, to go to keep houſe.
Domineur, as Dominateur, a Ruler, or Governour.
Domino, a kind of hood worn by Canons; a faſhion of Vail uſed by ſome women that mourn.
Dominotier, a maker of the hood called Domino.
Dommas, the Prieſt, or Canon, who by turn is to wear a Cope for a week together.
Donaiſon, a free gift, or deed of gift.
Dondaine, the name of a warlike Engine whereout great round ſtones were ſhot; alſo the burden of a Song.
Dondon, a ſhort and fat woman.
Donq, Donques, for Donc, then, therefore.
Dontereſſe, ſhe that tames or ſubdues.
Dorée, the Dorce, or St. Peters fiſh.
Doreloter, for Dorloter, to cocker, to dandle.
Doreloteur, for Dorloteur, a Cockerer, a Dandler.
Doriphage, a devourer of gifts, or bribes.
Dormeveille, a being between aſleep and awake; or a counterfeiting of ſleep.
Dormille, the ſickneſs of Silk-worms, during which they ſleep; alſo a kind of ſmall Lamprey.
un Dormir, a nap, a ſleep.
Dorque, a kind of great and round earthen Veſſel; alſo a great fiſh that's enemy to the Whale.
Dorſal, of, or belonging to the back.
Doſſe d'ail, a clove of Garlick.
Doſſeraſſe, a buttreſs, or ſupporter to bear up the great beam of a wall.
Dotal, given in dowry; of, or belonging to dowry.
Douannier, an Officer of the Cuſtom-houſe.
Doubé, rigged, or trimmed up, as a ſhip.
Douber, to rig, or trim a ſhip.
Doubleau, a ſemi-circle; alſo a double quarter of timber.
Double-marcheur, the little, ſpotted, and worm-like Serpent Amphisbana, ſuppoſed by ſome Authors to have a head at both ends, and ſo to go both ways.
Doublement (a Subst.) a doubling, a making twofold, or twice as much.
Double-vaiſſeau, a cauldron, or kittle full of boyling water.
Doublier, a ſtately table-cloth of damask, diaper, &c. hanging to the ground on both ſides of the board.
Doucente, the name of a thick, ruddy, and ſappy apple.
Dove, a Caſtle-ditch, or Town-ditch (with water in it).
Douëlle, a Pipe-ſtaff; alſo the ſtrickle uſed in meaſuring of Corn.
Douen d'antan, hence over a year.
Douëtte, à longues douëttes, in long rows, files, ranks.
Douger, to trip, as a horſe that ſtumbleth not outright.
Douleine, for doucine, a kind of plain.
Dourder, to knock, mawl, or thump.
Doux-auveſque, Doux-balon, Doux-bellieur three ſorts of apples.
Doux de la Lande, Doux-martin, Doux-veret, three ſorts of apples.
Douzain, a french penny; alſo a dozen.
Douze-doigtier, the name of a ſmall gut, or entral.
Drache, the little ſtalk whereby a Grape cleaves to the bunch.
Drageon, a Vine-branch, twig, or ſprig.
Dragonneau, a young, or little Dragon.
Drappeux, full of cloth, or fit to make cloth.
Drappier (Adj.) of, or belonging to cloth; alſo fit to make cloth.
Dreſſouïr, a Setting-iron, or Poaking-ſtick for Ruff-bands; a ſtanding thing.
Dridiller, to gingle, as a Hawks bells.
Droguement, a drenching, or miniſtring of Drugs.
Droguer, to drug, or mingle with Drugs.
Droguerie, the ſeaſon of fiſhing for Herrings, and other ſuch fiſh, to be ſalted and barrelled up.
Droicturé, that hath paid his relief, and all other the Duties of Tenancy.
Droicturer, a new Tenant or Vaſſal to do his Lord all right, and pay him all the rights belonging to him.
Droicturier, juſt, upright; alſo ſevere, ſtrict, according to the letter of the Law; alſo direct, or next. Droicturier Seigneur, a mans true, right, or lawful Lord.
Droiſſer, as Dreſſer, to direct; erect, inſtruct.
Droler, to play the wag; alſo to beat ſoundly.
Dromant, a ſmall and ſwift Veſſel uſed by Pirats.
Dropace, a depilatory, an ointment to take away hair.
Drugeon, a little branch, twig, or sprig.
Drugeonnement, a putting forth of ſmall branches or twigs.
Drugeonneux, full of ſmall branches or twigs.
Drylle, the maſte, or acorn of the female oak.
Ducat, for Duché, a Dukedom, a Dutchy,
Ductile, eaſie to be hammered, or beaten into thin plates.
Duelle, the third part of an ounce.
Duiſſon, an accuſtoming, uſing, or inuring; a making fit for.
Duit, accuſtomed, uſed, inured; alſo convenient, fitting.
Duiter, to make fit for his purpoſe.
Dumetté, downy, of down, ſoft as (or ſtuffed with) down.
Duner, to plain, as a horſe that neither halteth outright, nor ſets his foot hard on the ground.
Dunette, a thruſh; alſo a little Down, or ſandy hill.
Duplication, as Duplique in the N. D.
Duppe, for Dupe, a coxcomb, ſot, or fool.
Duracines, Peaches, Plums, or Cherries, whoſe pulp cleaves faſt unto their ſtones; alſo ſuch as are of a hard or firm pulp, and thereby long-laſting.
Dure-teſte, a kind of ſpotted and hard-headed Spider.
Dynarchie, the joynt rule of two Princes.
Eale, the name of a blackiſh Ethiopian beaſt.
Eavier, for evier, a ſink, or gutter, for voiding of ſoul water.
Ebouller, to throw, or tumble down.
Ebreché, that hath loſt divers teeth.
Eburnin, of, or belonging to ivory.
Ecarboté, ſtirred, or ſcattered, as the fire; alſo bruiſed, as an apple.
Ecarboter le feu, to ſtir up, or ſcatter the fire. Ecarboter une pomme, to bruiſe an apple.
Ecentrique, without center, out of the center; alſo without meaſure, whereof no meaſure can be taken.
s'Echauder, to grow too hot, to be ſcalded.
Echidne, a viper, or hydra; any kinde of Serpent.
Eclyptique, as Ecliptique in the N. D.
Ecphraſe, a plain declaration, or expoſition.
Edent, groveling on his face, or on his teeth.
Eſaiſter, to top (or cut off the top of) a plant.
Effable, which may be uttered in words.
Effacement, a razing, or blotting out.
Effaſſure, for Effaceure, a razing, or blotting out.
Effigial, repreſenting, reſembling; alſo belonging to an Image.
Effloreſcence, the outward skin or rind of any thing.
Effoncé, whoſe bottom is beaten out.
Effoncer, to beat out the bottom of a veſſel.
Effondré, howelled; burſt open. Chemin effondré, a way full of holes.

Effondrer, to draw the guts or garbage out of. Effondrer • un
cheval, to ſtrike a horſe through the belly. Effondrer un huis, to burſt open a door. Effondrer un vaiſſeau, to beat out the bottome of a veſſel.
Effondriſſe, the grounds of any liquor.
Efforcément, earneſtly, with tooth and nail.
Efforcillons, a diſeaſe in a Hawks tongue.
Effrayablement, in a fearful and terrible manner.
Effrener, to unbridle, to turn looſe.
Effrondille, the grounds of any liquor.
Effruicter, to take or gather the fruit of.
Effueillé, for efeuillé, bared of leaves.
Effueilleur, a pruner of trees, a puller of leaves from trees.
Egaronné, trodden, as a ſhooe, down at the heels.
Egaronner un ſoulier, to tread a ſhooe down at the heels.
Egaſſe, ſet an edge, as a tooth.
Egau, the leſs kinde of the baſtard-Mackarel.
Egener le labeur, to run through their work.
Egeſtion, a caſting out of excrements.
Egiptiaque, l'Onguent Eg. a certain Salve, or Oyntment, of a cleanſing faculty.
Egozillé, whoſe throat is cut; alſo vomited, or ſpued out.
Egoziller, to cut the throat of; to vomit, or ſpue out.
Egrette, a fowl that reſembles an Heron.
Egrumer, to pluck from the cluſter.
Egrun, any thing that exaſperates a diſeaſe or ſore.
Egualer, to equal, to make like.
Egualizement, an equalling, or a making even.
Egualizer, to equal, to make even.
Egyptelle, a kinde of white ſtone with black and red veins.
Ehanché, whoſe hip is out of joynt.
Ehancher, to put the bip out of joynt.
Ejarté, cut off by the hams; alſo without garters.
Ejarter, to cut off at the hams.
Elarmé, that can weep no more.
Elation, loftineſs; alſo a raiſing up.
Electre, Amber whereof beads and bracelets are made; alſo a mixture of Gold, Copper, and a fifth part of Silver.
Elegiaque, belonging to an Elegy, mournful.
Elemi, Elemmy, a kind of Gum, or Roſin.
Elenchie, Union elenchie, a Pendant-pearl of the faſhion of an egg.
Eleomeli, a ſweet and fat liquor iſſuing from the old trunks of certain trees in Syria.
Elephangines, certain Pills good to ſtrengthen the ſtomack, and to help digeſtion.
Elephantin, of, or belonging to an Elephant.
Elevatoire, the Inſtrument wherewith Surgeons lift up the broken parts of the Scull, and draw out bullets, &c.
Eleveur, a raiſer, or lifter up.
Elice, the Signe in Heaven called Charles wain.
Elicie, a firy vapour drawn from the Clouds.
Eliminé, put out of doors; alſo divulged, publiſhed.
Eliminer, to put out of doors; alſo to divulge, to publiſh.
Eliſer la monnoye, to clip money.
Ellée, as bailler les ellées à un cheval, to give a horſe the head.
Elocher, to looſen, or make looſe.
Eloiſe, a lightning; alſo a little ſpace of time.
Elopien, a kind of harmleſs Serpent.
Elourder, to dull, amaze, or aſtoniſh.
Elucider, to clear, or to make clear.
Emaceration, Emaciation, an emaceration, or falling away in fleſh.
Emané, proceeded, iſſued; alſo publiſhed, ſpread abroad.
Emaner, to proceed; alſo to publiſh, or to ſpread abroad.
Emantellement, a mantle; alſo a covering with a mantle.
Emargé, noted, or quoted in the margine.
Embabillé, well-ſpoken, that hath his tongue at command.
Embarrer, to beat inward, to bruiſe; alſo to rail, or ſet bars on. Embarrer ſon eſpée en un arbre, to faſten his ſword in a tree.
Embarrure, a bruiſing, or beating inward.
Embaſer, to give a baſis, or bottom unto.
Embaſſade, Embaſſadeur. See Ambaſſade, Ambaſſadeur in the N. D.
Embaſſement, as Soubaſſement in the N. D.
Embaſtonné, armed with weapons; alſo cudgelled.
Embaſtonner, to arm with weapons; to cudgel.
Embatage, the laying of ſtreaks about a wheel.
Embattes, the Eaſterly winds which commonly raign about the Dog-days.
Embaveté, ou Embavieté, that hath a bib on.
Embernir, to cover with, or to clad in rug.
Embeſongnement, a buſying, or employing; alſo a buſineſs, or buſie work.
Embeſongner, to buſie, employ, ſet on work.
Emblavé, ſown with corn; alſo whoſe corn is got up a pretty height above ground.
Emblavence de bled, corn ſprung a pretty height above ground; or the ſpringing up of corn.
Emblaver, to ſow the ground with corn.
Emblaveures, corn, whether growing, or in ſheaves.
Emblé, ſtoln. Je me ſuis emblé de la troupe, I flunk out of the company.
Emblic, a kind of round Mirabolan.
Emboëtture, a putting in a box.
Emboir, to ſoke, or drink up; alſo to imbue, to moiſten.
Emboiſtement, as Emboëtement in the N. D.
Emboiſter, as Emboëter in the N. D.
Emboiſture, as Emboëtement in the N. D. alſo the ring or plate of iron, &c. that keeps the box of a wheel from wearing.
Emboité, Emboitement, Emboiter. See Emboëter, &c. in the N.D.
Emboiture, as Emboëtement in the N. D.
Emboliſmal, added as a day unto a year; or increaſed as the year by ſo many days.
Emboliſme, an addition as of a day or more unto a year.
Emboſquer une terre, to plant, or ſet wood. S'emboſquer, to ſhrowd himſelf in a wood.
Emboſſer, to ſwell, or riſe in bunches.
Embottelé, made in bundles, or bottles.
Embotteler, to make up in bundles, or bottles.
Embouchoir, a Boot-laſt, or Boot-tree; alſo a horn to drench a horſe with, or any thing ſerving to convey a thing into the mouth.
Embouchonné, ſtopt with a ſtopple; alſo having a buſh (as a Tavern) hanging before it.
Embourbement, Embourbeure, a bemudding; a beraying with, or ſticking faſt, in mud.
Embouſcher en la Mer, to run into the Sea.
Embousé, bedunged, berayed with Cows ordure.
Embouté, plated, ſtiffened; or as Embouti, ſtretched out; alſo raiſed, imboſſed.
Emboutir, to ſtretch out; alſo to raiſe, or imboſs.
Emboutiſſement, a ſtretching out; a raiſing or imboſſing. Emboutiſſements de ſoye, Silk-thrums.
Embraſe, as Braiſe in the N. D.
Embrasée, an arm full, or fadom.
Embrider, to bridle, to keep in.
Embrocation, a gentle bathing of the head, or any other part, with a liquor falling from aloft upon it in the manner of rain.
Embronché, amazed with a blow, whoſe head hangs down after a blow received.
Embroncher, to hold down the head; alſo to hide the face.
Embrouillaſſer, as Embrouiller in the N. D.
Embrunir, to make (or to grow) brown.
Embufflé, deceived, led by the noſe.
Embuffler, to deceive, to lead by the noſe.
Embut, a funnet; alſo a pipe to ſuck with.
Emedullé, whereout the marrow is taken.
Emeduller, to take out the marrow.
Emendartice, a woman that mends or reforms any thing.
Emerillonner, to watch narrowly. Emerillonner à feu & à ſang, to proſecute with fire and ſword.
Emute, (for Mute) de Chiens, a cry of hounds.
Emmaigrir, to make lean. S'emmaigrir, to fall away, to grow lean.
Emmaiſonner, to houſe, to put into (or furniſh with) a houſe.
Emmancheure, a ſetting on of a haſt, or handle; alſo the upper part of a ſleeve.
Emmanchoir, the hole of a hatchet whereinto the handle is put.
Emmarrer, to caſt into the Sea.
Emmarteler, to put into a jealouſie.
Emmeché, furniſhed with match; alſo ſnuffed.
Emmecher, to furniſh with match; alſo to ſnuff.
Emmelie, a quiet kind of Dance.
Emmenteler, to cover with a cloak.
Emmeſnager, to ſet a houſe in good order.
Emmeublement, furniture, or a furniſhing with moveables.
Emmeubler ſa maiſon, to furniſh his houſe.
Emmi, through, in the midſt of.
Emminer, to put into a mine.
Emmitrer, to Crown with a Miter.
Emmorionné, covered with a murrion or head-piece.
Emmortaisé, joyned, or cloſed by mortaiſe.
Emmortaiſer, to joyn or cloſe by mortaiſe.
Emorcer, Emorcher, for amorcer, to bait.
Emoucé, Emoucer. ſee Emouſsé, Emouſſer in the N. D.
Empalmé, ſtruck with the palm of the hand.
Empalmer, to ſtrike with the palm of the hand.
Empanage, as Appanage in the N.D.
Empantouflé, wearing ſlippers. Livre empantouflé, a Book with a thick cover.
Emparagé, that hath his due part, or portion.
Emparement, a ſeiſing, or laying hold on.
Emparlé, homme bien emparlé, a well ſpoken man.
Empaſté, cruſted, or baked hard; made into paſt.
Empaſtelé, crammed with rolls of paſt.
Empaſtement, a paſting, a making of dough into paſte.
S'Empavoiſer, to cover himſelf with a ſhield.
Empayſer, to grow natural to; to thrive.
Empeigné, faſtned with the teeth of a comb; alſo ſcratched with a comb.
Empeigner, to comb, or to ſcratch with a comb. Empeigner le bout d'une douve, to pin the bar of a piece of cask.
Empeinte, de cette empeinte, at this puſh.
Empannaché, as Empanaché, ſet out with feathers.
Empennon, the feather of an arrow.
Emperler, to ſet thick with Pearls.
Empeſter, to infect with the plague.
Emphyteoſien, as Emphyteote in the N. D.
Emphyteuſe, as Emphyteoſe, in the N. D.
Emphyteutique, Seigneur Emphyteutique, a Lord that raiſes or improves his rents.
Empiece, not of a great while.
Empienne, as Empeigne, the upper leather of a ſhooe.
Empietement, an uſurpation of another mans right. Empietement d'une montagne, the foot of a hill.
Empietté, as Empieté in the N. D.
Empirance, an impairing; alſo allay in coin.
D'Empire, à l'empire, worſe and worſe.
Empireume, a mark of fire, or burning.
Emplacement d'une Ville, the ſeat of a Town.
Emplaſtration, a laying of plaiſter; a grafting by inoculation; the applying of a ſalve or plaiſter.
Emplaſtreux, full of plaiſters, alſo belonging to, or ſerving for a plaiſter.
Emplatement, a flatting; alſo a flat, or broad part of.
Emploicte, for Employ, an Imploy; alſo trade or traffick. Marchandiſe d'emploicte, ware that ſells well.
Emplotonné, made into a bottom, conglomerated.
Empocher, to put into a pocket.
Empoint, as bien empoint de faire, likely to do. Mal empoint, in ill plight.
Empointer, to point on. Empointer les doigts ſur le Luth, to ſinger a Lute.
Empoiſſonné, filled, ſerved, or furniſhed with fiſh.
Empoiſſonnement, a ſtoring of a pond with fiſh.
Empoulure, a bliſtered part of the body.
Empouppant, blowing as wind in the poop of a ſhip.
Empouppé, blown forward by a wind in the poop; alſo hit in the poop.
Empoupper, to blow in the poop of a ſhip, to ſet forward as a full wind doth a ſhip; alſo to hit the poop.
Empreer, to make a Meadow of.
Emprunelé, belonging to the apple of an eye.
Emputer, to accuſe, or complain of.
Emputeur, a ſecret accuſer, an informer.
Empyeme, an inward collection of corrupt matter in any part of the body, but eſpecially between the breaſt and lungs.
Empyreume, a dry and accidental heat.
Emulgent, as Veine emulgente, one of the two main branches of the hollow Vein.
Emutiſſement, the muting, or droppings of birds.
Enaigrir, to make, or grow ſharp; to anger, to exaſperate.
s'Enamourer de, to fall in love with.
s'Enarbrer, a horſe to riſe ſo high that he is like to fall backward.
Enarché, arched, covered with an arch.
Enarcher, to arch, or cover with an arch.
Enarmée, the handles of a ſhield.
Enarthroſe, a full and perfect uniting of bones.
Enaſer, to cut off ones noſe.
Encacquer, to put into a cag, or little barrel.
Encadener, to chain, or to lie in a chain.
Encagé, put into a cage, or priſon.
Encager, to put into a cage, or priſon.
s'Encaillouïr, to become as bard as a flint.
Encaiſſé, put into a caſe, or cheſt.
Encaiſſer, to put into a caſe, or cheſt.
Encaloché, that wears high wooden ſhoes.
Encaly, hardened, as the skin of a toyling hand.
Encant, as Encan in the N. D.
Encapé, covered with a hood, or cloak.
Encapeliné, wearing a little, flat, narrow-brimmed hat; or armed with a ſcull of iron.
Encapeluchonné, wearing a Cowl, as a Monk.
Encaper, to cover with a hood or cloak.
Encapitonner, to hood, or cover the head.
Encapuchonner, to hood with a capuch.
Encarené, laid on the ſide as a ſhip.
Encarener une Nef, to carry in a ſhip, to lay her on her ſide.
Encarné, incarnated, made fleſhy, or fat.
Encarner, to incarnate, to make fleſhy, or fat.
Encarrer, to level at, or as Acarer.
Encaſſé, put into a caſe, or cheſt.
Encaſſer, to put into a caſe, or cheſt.
Encaſtelure, a vicious or painful narrowneſs in a horſes heel; a growing narrow-heeled.
Encauſtique, enamelled, varniſhed, wrought with fire.
Encenſier, a ſtar in heaven placed under the ſting of the Scorpion.
Encepé, ſet in the ſtocks; alſo laden with irons.
Enceper, to ſet in the ſtocks.
Encerclé, incircled, incompaſſed, bound about with hoops.
Encercler, to incircle, to incompaſs, to binde about with hoops.
Enchalaſſer une vigne, to prop, or underſet a vine.
Enchambré, lodged in a chamber; alſo mortaiſed, incloſed within.
Enchampre, a chizel; a cutting, carving, or graving tool.
Enchapelé, crowned with Garlands; alſo covered with a hat.
Enchapeler, to crown with Garlands; alſo to ſet a hat on the head.
Enchapement d'une cheminée, the broad top of a chimney.
Enchaperonnement, a covering with a hood; alſo the out-jutting of a Roof.
Encharacteré, written, or printed in Characters.
Encharacterer, to write, or print in Characters.
Encharger, to charge, or give in charge. Encharger l'eſtomac, to cloy his ſtomack. Femme qui encharge, a woman that grows big on't.
Encharné, whereon fleſh is bred. Encharné au coeur, rooted in the heart.
Encharneler une Vigne, to prop, or underſet a Vine.
Encharner, to fleſh, to breed fleſh on.
Enchaſſillé de Menuiſerie, ſet in a Wainſcot-frame. Preſſe enchaſſillée, a Printers Preſs with a Tympan.
Enchauſſeure, a ſhooing; alſo the meaſure of a foot taken to make a ſhooe by.
Encheinure, as Enchainure in the N. D.
Encheminer, to ſet in the way.
Enchemiſé, covered with a ſhirt, or ſmock.
Encheper, to ſet in the ſtocks.
Encheriment, a raiſing of a price, a raiſing in price.
Encherre, as Encherir in the N. D.
Encheſneure, a chaining; alſo a courſe of things linked together.
Enchet, a falling, or dropping in.
Enchevallé, ſet with one foot over another.
Enchevaller, to ſet one foot over another.
Encheveſtré, ty'd in a halter; alſo intangled.
Encheveſtrement, a tying in a halter; alſo a being intangled.
Encheveſtrer, to tye in a halter; alſo to intangle.
Encheveſtrure, as Encheveſtrement. Encheveſtrure de cheminée, the mantle-tree of a chimney.
Enchiffrené, whoſe noſe is ſtopt with a cold.
Encirer, to wax, to make of wax.
Encis, the murthering of a great-belly'd woman, or of the Infant within her belly.
Enclaveure, as Enclavement in the N. D.
Encliner, to incline; alſo to decline. S'encliner, to bow down.
Encloſtré, ſhut up in a Cloyſter.
Encloſtrer, to ſhut up in a Cloyſter.
Enclotir, to drive a Fox or Coney into an earth, or berry.
Encloucher, to tell one what he ſhall ſay.
Encoigné, thruſt into a corner; made corner-wiſe; alſo wedged in.
Encoigneure, as Encongnure in the N. D.
Encoleure, as Encoulure in the N. D.
Encollé, having a fair, ſtiff, and big neck; alſo put about the neck. Long encollé, necked like a Crane.
Encoller, to put about the neck.
Encollure, as Encoulure in the N. D.
Encombre, as Encombrier; alſo rubbi • h.
Encombrement, an incumbring, or peſtering; alſo an annoyance, or incumbrance.
Encombrer, to incumber, to peſter. Encombrer le mariage de ſa femme, to alien his Wives land.
Encombrier, a cumber, an incumbrance; a miſchief, or misfortune.
Encontenancé, that hath put a good face on the matter.
Encontenancer, to put a good face on the matter.
Encoqueluché, hooded; alſo ſick of the diſeaſe called Coqueluchoe.
Encoqueluchonné, wearing a hood, or Spaniſh Capuch.
Encoquillé, as Poiſſon encoquillé, a Shell-fiſh.
Encorbellement, a ſhouldering or ſupporting by Corbels, or Brackets.
Encordelé, corded, made up with cords; alſo intangled therewith.
Encordeler, to cord, to make up with cords; alſo to intangle with cords.
Encordonner, to twiſt of many ſtrings.
Encoremes, the ſignes of urine (eſpecially thoſe that ſwim on the top thereof).
Encornal, the hounds of a Mast.
Encorné, horned; alſo put into a horn.
Encorner, to trim with horns; alſo to put into a horn.
Encorneté, put into a horn, or cornet.
Encorneter, to put into a horn, or cornet.
Encornure, a trimming with horn; alſo the horns of a beaſt.
Encorny, hard and ſmooth as horn.
Encoultrer, to furniſh with a culter.
Encourement, a puniſhment, a penalty incurred.
Encourrayé, bound (or furniſhed) with leathern thongs.
Encourayer, to binde (or furniſh) with leathern thongs.
Encourtiné, covered with (or ſhadowed by) a curtain, hid behinde a curtain.
Encourtiner, to draw a curtain over, to cover with (to ſhadow by) a curtain, to hide behinde a curtain.
Encoutelaſſer, to arm (or furniſh) with a cuttelas.
Encraſſé, grown thick with filth and ordure.
Encraſſer, to make thick with filth and ordure.
Encreſmé, full of cream, made of cream.
Encreſmer, to fill, or furniſh with cream.
Encreuſé, hollowed; alſo laid up in holes.
Encreuſer, to hollow; alſo to lay up in holes.
Encrier, (Adj.) of, or belonging to Ink.
Encroüé, lodged, as a cudgel in a tree, hanging on, or ledged in.
Encrouër, to lodge as a cudgel in a tree, to hang on, or ledge in.
Encrouſté, pargetted; becruſted, or whereon a ſcab is ſet.
Encrouſtement, a pargetting, a bringing of a ſcab on.
Encrouſter, to parget; to bring a ſcab on.
Encruché, put into an earthen pot, alſo as Encroüé.
Encrucher, to put into an earthen pot.
Encrudir, to make, or become raw.
Encueur, the Scithy (a diſeaſe of horſes and other cattel.)
Encuict, raw, undigeſted; alſo hardned through heat.
Encuiraſſé, grown hard, or ſtiff; alſo bound hard.
Encuiraſſer, to harden, or ſtiffen; alſo to binde hard.
Enculé, ſet upon the tail; alſo ſet aſlope, or with an imbowed bottom.
Encuvé, put into a fat, or tub.
Encuver, to put into a fat, or tub.
Encyrer, as Inciſer in the N. D.
Endamoiſellé, effeminated; alſo attired in a Gentlewomans apparel.
Endebtement, a being indebted; a bringing into debt.
Endernier, the laſt, or the latter-end.
Endeſver, to rage, to be mad.
Endiabler, to poſſeſs with a devil.
Endité, as Endicté; alſo demonſtrated, pointed at with a finger.
