Endizeler les gerbes, to ſhock up ſheaves of corn, to make them up in (ten-ſheaved) half-thraves.
Endoille, as Andouille in the N. D.
Endoré, gilt all over; beſet, or adorned with gold.
Endorer, to gild all over; to beſet or adorn with gold.
Endormant, the Serpent Cenchris, whoſe ſtinging breeds a continual ſleeping.
Endormie, the herb henbane or poppy.
Endosé, that hath his ſhare or portion of; whoſe part is limited or preſcribed unto him.
Endoſſeure, the back-part of any thing; alſo an indorſement.
Endoüairer, to indow, to indue with.
Enduit, (Subſt.) or Enduite, plaiſter; a bed or lay of plaiſter.
Enduvetter, to fill, or ſtuff with down.
Eneaüé, watered; ſeaſoned with, or turned into water.
Eneaüer, to turn into water; to mingle, or ſeaſon with water.
Enfaiſſé, made up into a bundle.
Enfaiſſer, to make up into a bundle.
Enfantiere, femme enfantiere, a childe-bearing woman.
Enfantiller, to play like a childe.
Enfardelé, made up into a bundle.
Enfardeler, to make up into a bundle.
Enfermement, a ſhutting, or locking up.
Enfermier, an Overſeer of the Sick in Hoſpitals; alſo the Porter of a Cloyſter.
Enfeſté, kept Holy-day. Maiſon enfeſtée, a houſe with a roof tiled.
Enfeſter, to keep Holy-day. Enfeſter un edifice, to tile a houſe.
s'Enfeuiller, to cover himſelf with leaves.
Enfiellé, made bitter as gall; filled, or mingled with gall.
Enfieller, to make bitter; to fill, or mingle with gall.
Enfievrer, to put into an ague.
Enflamber, to inflame. S'enflamber de courroux, to chafe.
Enfle-boeuf, the Ox-fly, or long-legged beetle.
Enflecheures, the ratlings, the cordy ſteps whereby Mariners climb up to the top of a Maſt.
Enfleurer, Enfleurir, Enfleuronnier, to ſpread with flowers.
Enfondrant, ſinking, overwhelming; alſo yielding as a ſoft thing to the violence of a hard.
Enfondré, ſunk, overwhelmed; alſo extreamly dinted, or beaten far in.
Enfondrer un chemin, to make a deep way.
Enfondrer un harnois, to make a great dint in an armor.
s'Enforcer, as alors s'enforça la feſte, then did the feaſt increaſe.
Enforcir, to inforce, to ſtrengthen. S'enforcir, to grow ſtrong, to pick up his crums.
Enforti, ſtrengthened, faſtened; alſo thickned as cloth is by fulling.
Enfourchir, to beſork; alſo to beſtride.
Enfourchure, as Fourchure in the N. D.
Enfranger, to edge (or ſet) with fringe.
s'Enfricher, to be overgrown with weeds, &c.
Enfroqué, covered with a Monks hood or cowl.
Enfroquer, to cover with a cowl; to make, or inſtitute a Monk.
Enfueiller, to ſtick with leaves. S'enfueiller, to hide himſelf among leaves.
Enfumé, (Subſt.) a dusky Sea-fiſh, that lives upon ſlime and ordure.
Engage, a pawn, a pledge, an ingagement.
Engaigné, as Engigné; alſo egged, urged, provoked.
Engaigner to cozen, gull, or deceive; to charm; to egg, or to ſet on.
Engain, anger; alſo a couſening trick.
Enganer, to deceive; a nurſe to conceal her being with child.
Enganté, furniſhed with gloves. Mittaines engantées, mittains like gloves.
Engarber, as Encontenancer; alſo to cover.
Engarder, to keep from, to hinder. Engarder la hardieſſe de, to curb the boldneſs of.
Engaſtrimyte, that ſpeaks out of the belly, as one that is poſſeſſed ſeems to do.
Engé, ſtored with the kind of; alſo increaſed.
Enger, to produce, or make to grow; to ſtore or fill with the increaſe or kind of; alſo to increaſe.
Engerbé, bound up together in a ſheaf.
Engerber, to bind up in a ſheaf.
Engeronné, dandled on (or hugged in) the lap.
Engeronner, to dandle upon the lap.
Engigner, to charm, to bewitch; alſo to couſen.
Engigneur, a charmer; alſo a cheat.
Engiponné, muffled up; alſo ragged, or in rags.
s'Englacer, to wax as cold as ice.
Engler, to ſhut up in a corner.
Englobé, contained within the compaſs of.
Englober, to contain or to comprehend within the circumference of.
Englobure, an inglobing; alſo a globe-like circumference or compaſs.
Engolſé, ſwallowed up in a gulf.
Engoncé, ſet faſt in; ſtraitned, wanting liberty.
Engorgement, a pouring down the throat, a ſwallowing up, as of a River by the Sea; alſo a choaking.
Engouſté, put in taſt, brought unto a ſtomack; alſo inchaſed.
Engraiz, as Engrais, in the N. D.
Engrangement, an inning of corn, a putting on't up in a barn.
s'Engreger, to grow worſe, to become ſover.
Engreigné, as pore engreigné, a meaſeld hog.
Engreſſure, an ingrailling, or invecking, a kind of ſmall indenting in a Coat of Arms.
Engreſſement, for Engraiſſement, a fattening of cattel.
Engrommelé, curdled thick, gathered into knobs or knots.
Engroüé, choaked up, as the courſe of a water-mill, by weeds.
Enguerlander, to crown with a garland.
Engyronner, to inviron, or to incompaſs.
Engys, for aupres, near, hard by.
Enhanté, having a ſtaff or handle put to it.
Enhanter une pique, to put the ſtaff into the head of a pike.
Enharnachement, harnaſs; alſo the harnaſſing of a horſe.
Enharnacher un cheval, to harnaſs a horſe, to put on all his furniture.
Enhaſter, to put on the ſpit.
Enhazé, very buſy. Il eſt tout enhazé à pluvoir, it is ſet to rain.
Enherbé, bewitched, or poyſoned with herbs.
Enherbement, a bewitching, or poyſoning with herbs.
Enherber, to bewitch, or poyſon with herbs.
Enheriter, to make one his heir.
Enhuiler, to oyl, to anoint. Enhuiler un homme qui meurt, to miniſter the extream Ʋnction to a dying man.
Enhydrer, to breed many miſchiefs by the cutting off of one.
Enjablé, whoſe head is fitted for the Crows.
Enjabler, to make the head of a cask fit for the Crows.
Enjambé, ſtrid over; alſo incroached on.
Enjambée, a ſtride, or as much ground as one can ſtride over.
Enjambement, a ſtriding over; an incroaching upon.
Enjaveliner, to arm, or ſtrike, with a Javeline.
Enjauler, Enjauleur. See Enjoler, Enjoleur in the N. D.
Enjeoller, for enjoler, to deceive one with fair words.
En-j • u, a ſtake at play.
Enjonché, ſtrewed, or ſet out with green Ruſhes, freſh Herbs, &c.
Enjoncher, to ſtrew, or ſet out with green Ruſhes, freſh Herbs, &c.
Enjoyallier, to deck, or adorn with Jewels.
Enixe, earneſt, endeavouring, or labouring hard.
Enlacé, Enlacer, as Enlaſſé, Enlacer in the N. D.
Enlaidiſſement, a disfiguring, or making ugly.
Enlanguagé, bien enlanguagé, a well-ſpoken man.
Enlignagé, bien enlignagé, of good kinred.
Ennaſſé, caught, as fiſh in a wheel.
s'Ennaſſer, to be caught, as fiſh in a wheel.
Ennazer, to put on the noſe.
s'Ennieller, Corn, Vines, or Fruits to be blaſted.
Ennoircir, to black, or make black; to grow black.
Ennombré, number out, enumerated; told (counted) over.
Ennombrer, to enumerate, or number out; to tell (or count) over.
Ennoſſé, almoſt choaked with a bone.
Ennoüé, ty'd up, or on a knot.
Ennouër, to tye on a knot.
Ennoye, the name of a venomous worm.
Ennuicter, to benight, to turn into night.
Enortier, to nettle, or ſting with nettles.
Enoſſé, e'en choaked with a bone; alſo ſettled in the bones.
Enoyſelé, fleſhed upon birds, as a Hawk.
Enquaiſſé, put up into a cheſt.
Enquaiſſer, to put up into a cheſt.
Enquenouiller de filace, to draw a Diſtaff.
Enracinement, a rooting, or taking root.
Enramé, ſet thick with boughs; alſo got upon a bough.
Enramement, a laying, or ſpreading of boughs; a climbing on boughs.
Enramer, to ſpread boughs. S'enramer, to climb upon boughs.
Enrayé, ſtayd, or held back, as a wheel by a trigger.
Enrayer une rouë, to ſtay, or hold a wheel back with a trigger.
Enrayoir, the wheel-gate, or beam that ſtops the courſe of a Water-mill; alſo a trigger for a wheel.
Enrether, to catch in a net.
s'Enroidir, to grow ſtiff, to become obſtinate.
Enrollement, for Enrolement, an inrolling, or liſting.
Enrouiller les yeux, to ſtare, to gaze.
Enrucher, to put into a hive.
s'Enruiſſeler, to divide it ſelf into little ſtreams.
Enſablé, filled, or covered with ſand; run on the ſands.
Enſabler, to fill, or to cover with ſand; alſo to run on the ſands.
Enſacher, to put into a bag.
Enſafraner, to ſeaſon with Saffron; or to paint over with Saffron.
Enſaiſiné, fully ſeized, put into full poſſeſſion of.
Enſaiſinement, an inſeiſining, a putting into poſſeſſion.
Enſaiſiner, to give ſeiſin, to put into full poſſeſſion.
Enſaquer, to put into a ſack.
Enſeller un cheval, to ſaddle a horſe.
Enſoigne, an Eſſoin, a lawful excuſe for an abſent or impotent perſon.
Enſoigner, to eſſoin, to excuſe an abſent, or diſcharge an impotent perſon.
Enſoitter, to dreſs or furniſh with hogs briſtles.
Enſoulfré, Euſoulfrer. See Enſouffré, Enſouffrer in the N. D.
Enſtocatté, a field incloſed with pikes, and appointed for a ſingle Combat.
Enſuairé, wound up in a ſheet.
Enſuairer, to winde a coarſe in a ſheet; alſo to wipe with a handkerchief.
Enſuer, to ſow up, or as
Enſuerer, to winde a coarſe in a ſheet.
Entablature, as Entablement in the N. D.
Entacher, to ſpot, ſtain, or taint. Entacher une beſongne, to undertake a piece of work.
Entacheure, a ſpot; alſo a ſpotting, ſtaining, or tainting.
Entalenté, longing after. Mal entalenté envers, ill affected to.
Entelechie, abſolute perfection, or efficacy; perfect motion, or eſſence; force moving of it ſelf; alſo as Endelechie.
Entend-trois, an equivocation of doubtful or double meaning. Il fait de l'entend-trois, be anſwers of purpoſe from the purpoſe.
Entendu que, ſeeing, or conſidering that.
Enteſteure, a breeding, or bringing of the head-ach.
Enteyſer ſon are juſques à l'oreille, to draw his bow up to the ear.
Enthroner, to place in a throne.
Enthuſiaſme, as Entouſiaſme in the N. D.
Entiercé, ſequeſtred into a third hand.
Entiercer, to ſequeſter, or put into a third hand.
Entiereté, intireneſs; alſo conſtancy, or obſtinacy in an opinion.
Entimbraillé, Entimbré, that bears a flouriſh hanging from the top of his helmet.
Entiquer, to cleave, or ſtick faſt like a tick.
Entoilé, made of, or furniſhed with linnen or canvas; alſo intangled, or caught in toyls.
Entoiler, to make of, or furniſh with linnen; alſo to intangle, or catch in toyls; to compaſs or hem in with toyls.
Entoisé, bent, as a bow; lift up, as a ſword ready to ſtrike.
Entoiſer un are, to bend a bow. Entoiſer une eſpée, to lift up a ſword with an intention to ſtrike.
Entommeure, as Entoumeure; alſo a funnel.
Entonnelé, tunned, put into a cask.
Entonnelement, a tunning, or putting of liquour into a cask.
Entonneler, to tun by a funnel.
Entorce, as Jambe entorce, a crooked leg.
Entortillonné, Entortillonner, as Entortillé, Entortiller in the N. D.
Entouillé, bewrayed, or defiled; alſo peſtered, incumbered, hindered.
Entouiller, to bewray, or defile; alſo to peſter, to incumber.
Entoumeure, a gobbet, a great bit.
Entourner, to inviron; alſo to winde about. s'Entourner, to turn round.
Entourtillé, as Entortillé in the N. D.
Entourtillure, a wreathing, a rowling about with.
Entourure, a Compaſs, any thing that compaſſeth and incloſeth another.
Entract, the greeniſh ſalve called Trait.
Entrage, for Entrée, a fee or cuſtom due at the entering of Merchandiſe into a place; alſo a fine paid for a Leaſe.
Entrait, a ſhort piece of timber indented within another place, thereby to hold it the faſter.
Entrape, any thing that catches or hinders a man as he goes.

Entraveſtiſſement, an interveſting, or interveſture; a mutual poſſeſſion, or joynt poſſeſſing of. Entraveſtiſſement de ſang, is between ſuch as are joyned by marriage, where the ſurvivor hath all, or the moſt p • rt of that which was joyntly poſſeſſed.
s'Entr'accointer, to grow a • quainted together.
s'Entr'accrocher, to lay faſt hold one of another.
s'Entr'aguiſer, to ſharpen each the other.
s'Entr'aimans, mutual friends, loving one another.
s'Entr'approcher, to draw near one another.
Entr'arraché, plucked up here and there, rooted out from between.
Entr'arracher, to pluck up here and there, to root out from between.
s'Entr'aſſener des eſpées, to ſtrike (or hit) one another with their Swords.
Entr'avoir, to have, or poſſeſs one another.
Entrebecqueter, to peck at one another.
s'Entrebleſſer, to hurt, or wound each other.
Entreboyau, a thick and fat skin that faſtens Bowels to the back, and each of them to the other.
s'Entrebrecher, to break, or make breaches into one another.
Entrebriſé, half broken; alſo diſtinct, diſtinguiſhed; alſo uneven, as a thing that is half burst.
Entrebruire, to make a humming noiſe.
Entrecaſſer, almost to break. s'Entrecaſſier les dents, to bruiſe the teeth by gnaſhing them hard one againſt another.
s'Entreceder, to yield one to the other.
s'Entreceler, to hide, or conceal one another.
Entre-cep, the diſtance between stock and ſtock.
s'Entrecercher, to look for one another.
s'Entrechanger, to interchange; almoſt to change. Maveuë m'entrechange, my ſight grows dim.
Entrechaucher, to tread upon, to trample amongſt.
s'Entrechoiſir, to chuſe out one another.
Entrecolomnement, a leaving of ſpace between pillar and pillar.
s'Entrecommuniquer, to communicate one with another.
s'Entrecoſſer, to jut or but together, as Rams.
s'Entrecoudoyer, to juſtle one another with the elbow.
Entrecouler, to glide, or run between.
Entrecoupeure, an half cutting, a cutting off in the midſt.
Entrecourir, to run on both ſides, joyntly to run. s'Entrecourir, to incounter, to run one upon another.
s'Entrecraindre, to ſtand in fear of one another.
s'Entrecroiſer, to lie croſs one another.
Entrecroiſure, a double croſs, or intercroſſing.
Entrecuiſſes, the cods of a wilde Boar.
Entredent, the ſpace that is between two teeth.
s'Entredepecer, to pull one another in pieces.
s'Entredire injures, to revile one another.
Entrediſcerner, to know one from another.
s'Entredonner, to exchange. s'Entredonner courage, to encourage one another.
s'Entr'empoigner, to catch hold of one another.
s'Entrefaire grandefeſte, to make very much of one another.
s'Entrefaſcher, to fall out one with the other.
Entreferir, to ſtrike at one another; alſo to interfere, as a Horſe
Entrefeſſier, the ſpace between the Buttocks.
Entrefeſſon, the ſpace between the Privities and the Fundament.
Entrefileures de drap, the ſpace between thread and thread.
s'Entrefondre, to run over head and cars into.
Entrefoſſé, the ſpace that is between ditch and ditch.
Entrefouler, to trample in the midſt of.
s'Entrefroiſſer, to cruſh one another in pieces.
s'Entrefrotter, to rub one againſt another; to interfere.

Entrefrotture, a rubbing one againſt
another; a horſes interfering.
s'Entregenter, to know well how to carry himſelf in all companies.
s'Entregronder, to grumble one at another.
s'Entreguerroyer, to make wars one upon another.
s'Entrehapper, to catch hold of one another.
s'Entrehucher, to whoop at one another.
Entreject, a caſting, or putting between.
Entrejoindre, to joyn together. S'entrejoindre, to embrace each other.
s'Entrejouër, to play (or ſport) one with another.
Entrelaiſſer, to leave off, to diſcontinue.
Entrelas, a knot hard to be looſed, an intricate buſineſs; alſo an interlacing.
Entrelaſſeure, an interlacing. Toicts ornez d'entrelaſſeures, Roofs decked with interlaced frets.
Entrelier, to tie together, to binde between.
Entreluicter, to wreſtle one with another.
Entroluire, to give a glimpſe, to ſhine between.
Entrelunaires, as Jours entrelunaires, the days wherein neither the old nor new Moon is ſeen.
Entremander, to ſend between party and party.
Entremutiner, to ſet together by the ears.
Entremy, par entremy, amongſt, or in the midſt of.
Entrenaiſtre, to be born between, or among.
Entrenoüé, knotted between; alſo ſwum between.
Entrenouër, to tie knots between; alſo to ſwim between.
s'Entr'obliger, to binde themſelves one to the other.
Entr'oeil, the ſpace between the Eyes.
Entr'oublié, forgotten in the mean while.
Entr'oublier, to forget in the mean while. S'entr'oublier, to forget each other.
Entreparler, to interrupt one that ſpeaks.
Entrepas, a faſt walk, a rack.
s'Entrepigner, to go together by the ears.
Entreplanter, to plant or ſet between.
Entrepreſſer, to crowd in another. S'entrepreſſer, to thruſt hard one another.
s'Entrepreſſer, to lend one to another.
Entreprins, Entreprinſe, as Entrepris, Entrepriſe in the N. D.
s'Entrepromettre une choſe, to promiſe a thing on • to another.
Entrer, (Subſt.) an entry, or going into.
s'Entreregretter, paſſionately to wiſh for one another.
Entreroulé, rowled between, rowled now and then.
s'Entreruer de pierres, to pelt one another with Stones.
s'Entreſaiſir bras à bras, to ſeize one another by the Arms.
Entreſcieures, frequent (but diſtant) cuts or entries made by a Saw.
Entreſemer, to ſow here and there.
Entreſerrer, to cloſe in, or between.
Entreſolive, a ſpace between two Raſters.
s'Entreſouvenir de, to remember one another of; alſo half to remember.
s'Entreſpier, to ſpie one anothers doings.
s'Entreſuir, as s'Entreſuivre in the N. D.
Entreſuytte, s'Entreſuyvre. See Entreſuite, Entreſuivre in the N. D.
Entretenement, coherency; alſo wages, or entertainment. Entretenement de voix ſan; reſpirer, the holding of a note.
Entretoiſe, a croſs quarter of timber.
Entreveiller, to be waking now and then.
s'Entreverſer, to overturn (or overthrow) one another.
Entreviſer, to view now and then.
Entreviſiter, to viſit now and then.
Entrevomir, to vomit now and then.
Envaiſſelé, put into a veſſel. Un bel eſprit envaiſſelé, a good potwit.
Envaſer, to put into a veſſel.
Envaſquiné, in a long Spaniſh, or old-faſhioned Vardingale.
Envelopoir, any thing that ſerves to wrap another in.
Envent, a ſhort blinde Serpent which is thought to ſleep all Winter.
Envermer, to fill with, or grow full of worms.
Enverſé, inverted, turned upſide-downward, or the inſide outward; alſo turned in and out.
Enverſer, to invert; to turn upſide downward, or the inſide outward; alſo to turn in and out.
Enviné, ſtored, or ſeaſoned with Wine.
Envirollé, whoſe top, end, or tip is bound about with a ring or hoop of iron, &c.
Envoulté, charmed in his chief member.
Eolipyles, a kind of hollow braſen bowls.
Epalouïr, to melt, or ſwelter with extream heat.
Epanalepſe, the name of a Rhetorical figure.
Epanode, a ſeveral rehearſal of two things which at firſt were ſpoken of joyntly.
Epanons d'un dard, the feathers of a Dart.
Epatique, for hepatique, the herb Trinity, or noble Agrimony.
Epaular, an O • k, a great Sea-fiſh mortal enemy to the Whale.
Ephectique, one that after long ſtudy is more doubtful than he was at firſt.
Ephemerique, that laſts but a day.
Epicaizer, to judge according to equity.
Epigaſtre, all the outward part of the belly from the bulk to the privities.
Epigaſtrique, belonging to that part of the belly.
Epiglottide, the cover-weeſel, or ſtop of the throat.
Epilemie, a Song of the Superſcription of a thing.
Epilence, a kind of falling-evil in a Hawk.
Epinices, Songs of Triumph after a Victory.
Epinyctide, a wheal that riſes on the skin by night.
Epiphore, a rheumatick-dropping of the eyes; alſo violent impreſſion.
Epiphyſe, an addition (or appendix) to a bone.
Epiſemaiſie, a ſignification of the mind by the countenance or geſture.
Epiſtrophe, the ending of two verſes with one word.
Epiſtyle, a little pillar ſet upon a greater; alſo an Architrave.
Epitaſſe d'une Tragedie, the buſieſt part of a Tragedy.
Epitheme, a liquid and outward Medicine.
Epithemer, or Epithimer, to bathe, or to moiſten.
Epitoge, a long Cloak, or Caſſock worn looſe over other apparel; alſo a Graduats hood.
Epizeuxe, the name of a Rhetorical figure.
Eprenas, a kind of bloudy flux.
Equaliſer, to equal, to match, to compare.
Equarri, Equarrir. See Equarré, Equarrer in the N. D.
Equarriſſement, a meaſuring, or ſquaring out by a Squire.
Equeſtre, of, or belonging to horſemen, Knights, or Gentlemen.

Equibiens, the Halſes, or two holes in the prow of a Ship, through
which the Anchor-cables paſs.
Equidiſtant, equally diſtant one from the other.
Equilance, the hole wherein the tongue of a Ballance playeth.
Equilibrer, to weigh in equal balances.
Equiparable, fit to be compared, or equalled unto.
Equiparer, to match, or make equal, to compare, to liken.
Equipoler, to be of equal value.
Equipoller, to countervail, to be of equal value.
Equippée, equipage; alſo a ſudden prank, a digreſſion. Les equippées d'un Lievre, the outright courſe of a Hare.
Eraige, an Airy of Hawks, or as Herage.
Eramme, a Fine ſet on a parties head for want of due appearance.
Eraſer, as Ecraſer in the N. D.
Erater, to take the Milt out.
Ereole, a ſmall weight of two grains.
Ergalie, the framing of Veſſels and Furnaces for Extractions, &c.
Ergate, a Windbeam, or drawbeam; alſo a rack for a Croſs-bow.
Ergoture, as Ergot in the N. D. alſo an arming, or furniſhing with ſpurs or dew-claws; alſo Sophiſtry.
Erigoteures, the ſpurs of a Cock.
Erme, as Terres ermes, Land that lies waſte and untill'd.
Ermitage, Ermite, as Hermitage, Hermite in the N. D.
Erner, to break, or bruiſe the reins; to cruſh, or weaken the back.
Eroder, to gnaw off, or about; to eat into; alſo to drive from field to field, from hill to hill.
Erogene, the name of a love-procuring herb.
Eroſion, a gnawing or eating into.
Erraillé, ſpread wide open, ſet far aſunder. Oeil erraillé, a ſtaring eye.
Errailler, to ſpread wide open; to ſtare with the eyes; to ſtraddle with the legs or thighs.
Erramment, out of hand; alſo at random.
Errandonner, to flie away at random.
Errater, to take out a mans milt, thereby to make him the nimbler.
Erratique, as fiebvres erratiques, Agues whoſe fits hold no certain time of return.
Errement, as Arrement; alſo a patch, tract, or way.
Errhine, a tent-like medicine put into the noſe.
Eruce, the herb Rocket; alſo the Canker-worm.
Eructation, a belching, or breaking of wind.
Erugineux, of the colour of Verdigreaſe, ruſty, canker'd, corrupted.
Eryſipele, a painful and hot ſwelling or impoſtumation.
Esbaaillé, cloven, riven, ſet wide aſunder.
Esbalançon, a horſes diſordered leap out of time and meaſure.
Esbarber, as Ebarber in the N. D.
Esbaſé, driven out of his baſis.
Esbaſer, to drive out of its baſis. S'esbaſer, to ſlip from its baſis, or foundation.
Esbaudir, to cheer up, to make merry; alſo to rouſe up from ſleep.
Esberger, to lodge, to harbour. Eſberger en ſoy une faute, to be guilty of a fault; alſo to take a fault upon himſelf.
Esblaré, gaſtly, or pale of countenance.
Esblouïſſon, a miſt caſt before the eyes. Esblouiſſon de la tête, giddineſs of the brain.
Esboché, Esbocher, as Ebauché, Ebaucher in the N. D.
Esboire, to ſoak in, to drink up.
Esbouffer, to burſt out into laughter. S'esbouffer à parler, to burſt out in ſpeech.
Esbouilli, throughly boyled; overboyled, decay'd in boyling, almoſt dried up with boyling.
Esbouillir, to boyl throughly, to overboyl, to boyl almost dry; alſo to work as new beer, &c.
Esbourjonner, &c. See Ebourgeonner in the N. D.

Esbrandi,
•• ſt violently upon. Quand le feu eſt esbrandi en pluſieurs maiſons, when fire hath violently ſeized on many horſes.
Esbreché, broken, or whereinto a breach is made.
Esbrecher, to break, or make a breach into.
Esbrillade, a jerk given a horſe with the bit or bridle.
Esbrouër, to rub hard. Esbrouer des narines, to ſhort.
Esburré, unbuttered, or from which batter hath been taken. Laict esburré, butter-milk.
Esburrer, to take butter from, to make butter-milk of.
Eſcaché, cruſhed, or ſqueezed hard together.
Eſcachement, a cruſhing, or ſqueezing hard together.
Eſcacher, to cruſh, or ſqueez hard together.
Eſcacheur, a cruſher, or ſqueezer of things hard together.
Eſcachure, a cruſhing, or ſqueezing of things hard together.
Eſcaffette, a kinde of great and long muſcled ſhell wherewith ſome women skin their milk.
Eſcaffignon, a Sock; alſo a pump, or a cloſe and ſingle-ſol'd ſhoo of thin leather.
Eſcaigne de fil, ou de ſoye, a skain of thread, &c.
Eſcailleure, a ſcaling, or ſhaling. Eſcailleures de pierres, ſhards.
Eſcaillon, an Horſes tuſh, or tusk.
Eſcalbotter, to pill, as peaſe do in boyling.
Eſcallé, ſcaled, or taken by ſcalado.
Eſcaller, to ſcale the walls of a town.
Eſcalonnier, as dents eſcalonnieres, a horſes tusks, or tuſhes.
Eſcalventré, whoſe guts are ſquaſhed out.
Eſcalventrer, to tread out the guts.
Eſcamme, Eſcamne, a form, or bench; alſo a ſtep to get up higher.
Eſcampe, a ſcaping, or flying away.
Eſcandillé, ſcantled, made according to a pattern or ſcantling.
Eſcantuole, the Pump of a ſhip; alſo a ſounding-plummet.
Eſcapelin, a remnant of a piece of ſtuff.
Eſcappe, a ſmall ſquare-edged circle or fillet in a pillar, &c. alſo the body of a pillar.
Eſcarade, the opening of the nether part of the branch of a Horſes hit.
Eſcaras, as Echalas in the N. D.
Eſcarbillat, lively, ſprightly; alſo hair-braind, fantaſtical.
Eſcarboter le feu, to ſtir up the fire.
Eſcarbouiller, to cruſh, to ſqueeze. Eſcarbouiller la cervelle, to beat out the brains.
Eſcare, a fiſh that chews his meat; alſo a ſcar.
Eſcarlatin, of ſcarlet, or of a ſcarlet hu • . Roſe eſcarlatine, a damask Roſe.
Eſcaroufler, to ſcratch off, to tear.
Eſcas, the tenth penny of the value of Moveables, wherein a Forreiner ſucceeds a Freeman.
Eſcaſſable, as Meubles eſcaſſables, Moveables ſubject unto Eſcas.
Eſcaveſſade, a jerk with the cord of a caveſſon.
Eſceer, to cut, or ſlive; alſo to pill.
Eſcerveler, to take the brains out of; alſo to daſh the brains out.
Eſchafaudé, made into a ſcaffold; alſo preſented on a ſcaffold; carry'd from ſcaffold to ſcaffold; ſet on the pillory.
Eſchafauder, Eſchafaulder, to build ſcaffolds; to preſent on a ſcaffold; to ſet on the pillory; alſo to deviſe or practiſe villany.
Eſchafaudis, Eſchafaut, as Eſchafaud, a ſcaffold; alſo a pillory.
Eſchaffaudage, for échafaudage, a ſetting up of ſcaffolds.
Eſchalaſſier (Adj.) bearing ſtore of props or ſtakes, of, or belonging thereto.
Eſchampé, Eſchamper. See Eſcampé, Eſcamper in the N. D.
Eſchanſonner, to do as the Cup-bearer.
Eſchanteler, to break into cantles; to cut off the corners or edges of.
Eſchantillé, curtailed, cut or broken into corners, or cantles.
Eſchantillonner, to take (or cut) off a pattern.
Eſchappé (a Subſt.) an eſcape, an evaſion.
Eſchaque, ſcurf, ſcales, or dandriff in the head.
Eſcharalle, a dead and ſtinking fleſh which breeds about wounds.
Eſcharceté, niggardlineſs; alſo baſeneſs, or want of due alloy in Coyn.
Eſcharcette, as Eſcharceté in the laſt ſenſe.
Eſcharde, a ſplinter; alſo a ſcraggy girl that looks as if ſhe were ſtarved.
Eſchardonner, to weed, or pluck up thiſtles.
Eſchardonneuſe, a woman that weeds, or plucks up thiſtles.
Eſchargotté, pruned as a tree, picked round about.
Eſchargotter, to prune a tree, to pick any thing round about.
Eſcarpeux, flaunting it with many ſcarfs about him.
Eſchat, Droicts des Eſchats & Tavernes, a certain Duty or Impoſition upon Wine ſold by retail and in Taverns.
Eſchaſſeur, Eſchaſſier, one that goes upon ſtilts.
Eſchaubouillé, bliſtered; or having the Shingles.
Eſchaubouillure, a bliſter; an Inflammation called the Shingles.
Eſchaufaiſon, a warming, or making hot; alſo an heat; or a diſeaſe that comes of immoderate heat.
Eſchauguetté, watched in a Beacon, or high Tower; beheld from high, or afar off.
Eſchauguetter, to watch at a Beacon, or in a high Tower; to ſee far about; to ſtand Sentry.
Eſchauguetteur, a Sentinel in a high Tower or Beacon; alſo a Scout.
Eſchef, a fall, waſting, or diminution.
Eſchelette, for Squelette, a Skeleton; alſo a Wall-pecker; alſo the little ſtalk of a Grape.
Eſchellement, a ſcaling, or getting upon by a ladder.
Eſcheller, for Echeler, to ſcale, to climb up a ladder.
Eſchelleur, a climbing by a ladder.
Eſchemeau, the bed of a Vine, the ridge wherein it ſtands.
Eſchemer, to ſwarm, or breed young, as Bees.
Eſcheque-mat, for Echee & mat, a Checkmate, at Cheſs.
Eſchet, an Eſcheat, or thing fallen to.
Eſchiffler une branche d'arbre, to ſplit, or half break off a branch.
Eſchinal, the head of a ſink covered with a grate.
Eſchine, for Echine, the chine, the back-bone.
Eſchinée de pore, a chine of Pork.
Eſchiner, to break the back of.
Eſchineux, of a great and ſtrong back.
Eſchinon, the chine, or upper part of the back between the ſhoulders.
Eſchope, Eſchoppe, a little and low ſhop. Faire eſſay à l'eſchoppe, to lay a ſmall and thin piece of ſilver, &c. upon a hot burning coal, thereby to try the value and alloy of it.
Eſcimer, to top, to cut off the tops or heads of.
Eſclaboché, beſpotted, beſprinkled with water or dirt.
Eſclabocher, Eſclaboter, to beſpot with water or dirt.
Eſclaffer de rire, to burſt out into laughter.
Eſclaireur, an obſerver, or overſeer of others; alſo an aſſiſtant unto a Plaintiff or Accuſer.
Eſclate, a Sling; alſo a kind of diſeaſe among children.
Eſclature, a flaſhing, or glittering; alſo a Splitting, or burſting into ſplinters.
Eſclayer, to make way through hurdles.
Eſcleche, a diſmembring, or ſeparation; alſo a part or piece diſmembred, or ſeparated from.
Eſclerci, Eſclercir, Eſclerciſſement. See Eclairci, Eclaircir, Eclairciſſement.
Eſclere, or Eſclerre, the herb Celandine.
Eſcliſchement, a diſmembring, or dividing of an intire thing.
Eſcliſſe, as Ecliſſe, a Cheeſe-fat; alſo a hurdle.
Eſcliſſe, ſquirted; alſo made up of ozier, or wicker-twigs; alſo bound up in ſplents.
Eſcliſſer, to ſquirt; to make up with ozier, or wicker twigs; alſo to bind up in ſplents.
Eſclot, a wooden ſhooe; alſo a reed, or cane to ſuck with; a reſt in Muſick; a Galley-ſlave.
Eſclou, the print of a horſes foot.
Eſcluſant, ſtopping, as by a ſluce.
Eſcodilles, the bulbed roots of Daffodils.
Eſcogriffe, a lusk, a great ſlouch.
Eſcoinſon, a ſcunch, the back-part of the jaumb of a window.
Eſcolaſtre, the Rector, or Overſeer of a School; alſo an unlearned, or mean Scholar.
Eſcolaſtrerie, a Rectorſhip, or Government of a School; alſo mean Scholarſhip.
Eſcolleté, whoſe collar is taken off.
Eſcolleter, to take off the collar from a garment.
Eſcome, the blade, or broad end of an Oar.
Eſconduire, to ſend away with a denial.
Eſconduit, ſent away with a denial.
Eſconjuré, driven away by intreaty, or by conjuring.
Eſconjurer, to dri • e away by intreaty, or conjuring.
Eſconſement, a concealing. Eſconſement de Soleil, the Sun-ſetting.
Eſcopetade, the ſhot of a ſmall piece.
Eſcorcée, Eſcorcement, a barking, pilling, or paring; alſo the pilled, or unrinded part of a plant.
Eſcorcer, to bark, pill, or pare.

Eſcorné, that hath loſt his horns; out of countenance; alſo whoſe corners are broken, or cut off; defaced, ruined, ſcorned, diſgraced. Arbre eſcorné, a tree whoſe branches are lopt off. Dez eſcornez, ground dice, blunt cornered dice.
Eſcornement, depriving of horns; a diſgracing.

Eſcorner, to deprive of horns; to take from one a thing which is (or he thinks is) an ornament and grace unto him; to break off the corners of a ſquare thing; to lop trees; to ruine, deface, or diſgrace any thing.
Eſcoſſe, for gouſſe, the husk of a Bean, or the like.
Eſcotté, that is within a ſhot, or hath paid a ſhot.
Eſcotter, every one to pay his ſhot, or to contribute ſomething towards it.
Eſcouärde, as Eſcouäde, a parcel of Souldiers. Un Cap d'Eſcouärde, a Corporal.
Eſcoube, a Bruſh; alſo a maukin for an oven.
Eſcoudé, deprived of his ſupport, of the ſtay whereon he leaned, of the means whereon he relied.
Eſcoüé, curtailed; alſo wagged, or ſhaken up and down.
Eſcouër, to curtail; alſo to wag, or ſhake up and down.
Eſcouillon, a wiſp, or diſh-clout; a mankin, or drag, to cleanſe and ſweep an oven.
Eſcoluable, drainable, eaſie to be dried or conſumed; ſoon gone.
Eſcoulant, as Eſcoulement, a drain, or ſtrainer; alſo a ſloping place, down which a thing eaſily glides, or is apt to run.
Eſcoullement, Eſcouller, as Eſcoulement, Eſcouler in the N. D.
Eſcoupellé, topped, or whoſe top is cut off.
Eſcoupeller, to top, or cut off the top of a tree.
Eſcourgeon, Starch-corn, a kinde of baſe wheat, which being ground yields very white meal, but light, and little nouriſhing.
Eſcourre, to thraſh; alſo to beat or ſhake duſty clothes, &c.
Eſcourſouër, the dale of a ſhips pump, whereby the water is paſſed out.
Eſcourté, curtailed, ſhortened, cut, or chopped off.
Eſcourter, to curtail, ſhorten, cut, or chop off.
Eſcouſſe, a ſhaking, or jogging; alſo a ſwing. It is alſo the Feminine of Eſcoux.
Eſcouteur, an hearer, hearkener, or liſtener.
Eſcouvillonner, to ſpunge a Piece, to cleanſe her before and after ſhe is diſcharged.
Eſcoux, ſhaken, jogged, ſwinged. Paille eſcouſſe, wherein no Corn is leſt.
Eſcrager, to cruſh, or ſqueez out of.
Eſcraigne, a little hovel made of poles ſet round with their ends meeting at the top, and covered thick with turves, ſods, dung, &c.
Eſcrain, as Ecrin, a casket, or little box.
s'Eſcravanter, to burſt, or ſplit himſelf.
Eſcreté, unchalked, or deprived of chalkie whiteneſs.
l'Eſcrever du jour ou de la nuict, the dawning of the day, the twilight.
Eſcri, Eſcriement, an outcry, or acclamation.
Eſcriner, to pull off the hair.
Eſcrober, to jog, as a Cart in an uneven way.
Eſcrou, as Ecrouë in the N. D.
Eſcrouellé, troubled with the Kings evil.
Eſcroupionné, whoſe crupper is broken, rumpleſs.
Eſcueuil, as Ecueil in the N. D.
Eſcuiſſe, whoſe hip or thigh is out of joynt.
Eſcuiſſer, to put the hip or thigh out of joynt.
Eſculé, whoſe tail is burſt, heel trodden down.
Eſculer, to burſt the tail off. Eſculer une aiguille, to break a needles eye. Eſculer ſes fouliers, to tread his ſhooes down at the heels.
Eſcumement, a foaming; a skimming; a ſcowring of the Seas.
Eſcureur, a Scowrer; alſo a Squirrel.
Eſcuſſonnable, fit to be grafted en écuſion.
Eſcuſſonné, defended or covered with a Scutcheon, or Shield.
Eſcuſſonner, to defend, or cover with a Scutcheon, or Shield; alſo as Enter en écuſſon.
Eſcuyere, a woman-Eſ • uire; a Gentlewoman that attends on a Knight as his Eſquire.
Eſcuyrie, as Ecurie in the N. D.
Esfarouché, Esfarouchement, Esfaroucher. See them with an f, inſtead of s, in the N. D.
Esflanqué, ſwayed in the back; alſo lean, ſhrunk in the flank, that hath no belly at all. Esflanqué en cheval de poſtillon, as lean as a Poſt-horſe.
Esflanquer, to ſway in the back; to make lean, thin-flanked, or ſmall-belly'd.
Eſgail, a fine morning-froſt, that ſhines like glaſs.
Eſgargaté de crier, whoſe throat is almoſt burſt with crying.
Eſgaronné, trodden down, as a ſhooe at the heel.
Eſgaronner un ſoulier, to tread a ſhooe down at the heel.
Eſgarouillé, as yeux eſgarouillez, wide-ſtaring, or gloring eyes.
s'Eſgaudir, to rejoyce, to be merry.
Eſgeré, ploughed, or broken up, as land for fallows.
Eſgerer, to plough, or break up land for fallows.
Eſgommé, ungummed, whoſe gum is taken away.
Eſgommer, to ungum, to take away the gum.
Eſgorgeté, whoſe throat is cut; alſo bare-neckt.
Eſgorgeter, to cut ones throat; alſo to go bare-necked, or to fold down the collar of a Garment, thereby to bare or diſcover the neck or boſom.
Eſgoſiller, to cut the throat of.
Eſgouteur, a drainer, or drier up by drops.
Eſgoutille, a little hole or gullet through which water can do little more than drop.
Eſgoutoir, a drain, channel, or ſink.
Eſgrailler, to ſtraddle with the feet or legs.
Eſgrainer, as Egrener, to ſhake corn out of its ear.
Eſgrapher, to looſe, to pull aſunder.
Eſgrette, as Aigrette in the N. D.
Eſgrugé, grated ſmall; alſo crummed, or broken into ſmall pieces.
Eſgruger, to grate ſmall; alſo to break unto crums.
Eſgrumé, Eſgrumelé, uncluſtered, taken from its cluſter.
Eſgrumeler, to uncluſter; to take aſunder things that hang looſe together.
Eſgrumé, to pluck grapes from their cluſter.
Eſgruner, to crumble, to break ſmall.
Eſgualation, an equalling, levelling, or making like.
Eſgueré, Eſguerer, as Egaré, Egarer in the N. D.
Eſgueulé, for Egorgé, whoſe throat is cut.
Eſguillé, of a needle, full of needles, wrought with the needle, prickt with needles.
Eſhanché, whoſe hip or haunch is out of joynt.
Eſhancher, to put a haunch or hip out of joynt.
Eſhancheure, a putting of the hip or haunch out of joynt.

s'Eſhonter, to be ſhameleſs, or bra
• en-faced.
Esjetté, ejected, caſt out, or lanched forth.
Esjetter, to eject, caſt out, or lanch forth.
Esjuner, to keep faſting, to ſtarve.
Eſlainde, an engine wherewith great ſtones are lifted up.
Eſlangouré, Eſlangui, languiſhing, fallen into languiſhment.
Eſlaver, to waſh away, or over.
Eſlay, a career, or courſe o • horſback.
Eſlevable, fit to be elevated, raiſed, advanced; fit to be bred, or brought up.
Eſlevement, a lifting up; an advancing, or promoting; a ſwelling, or puffing up; a breeding, or bringing up.
Eſleveur, a lifter up, a • advancer, a bringer up.
Eſleveure, a lifting up, a riſing, or ſwelling up in height, an imboſſing, a bunch, a thing riſen, ſwoln, or puffed up.
Eſligible, eligible, fit to be elected.
Eſloingné, Eſloingnement, Eſloingner, as Eloigné, Eloignement, Eloigner in the N. D.
s'Eſmayer, to be careful, ſad, penſive.
Eſme, an aim, or level taken; alſo a purpoſe, or intention.
Eſmenuiſer, to make, or break ſmall.
Eſmer, to aim, or level at; to make an offer to ſtrike; to purpoſe, or intend.
Eſmerauldin, like, or belonging to an emrald.
Eſminage, a meaſure containing about half a buſhel.
Eſminal, another meaſure, being the half of the bichot.
Eſminotte, a meaſure of about two buſhels.
Eſmoignonné, cut off at the ſtump, made a ſtump of.
Eſmoignonner, to cut off at the ſtump, to make a ſtump of.
Eſmonde real, oſmond royal, male fern.
Eſmondement, a picking, purging, or pruning.
Eſmont, for Emcut, the mute, or dropping of a bird.
Eſmorce, touch-powder; alſo a tickling; alſo the ordure that cleaves to an unwiped or ill-wiped arſe.
Eſmotellé, whoſe clods are broken; alſo conſumed, or eaten.
Eſmoteler, to break clods; alſo to conſume, or eat.
Eſmoucé, Eſmoucer, as Emouſſé, Emouſſer in the N. D.
Eſmouche-lourdaut, a deceiver of ſimple people.
Eſmoucher, to rid of flies, to drive them away.
Eſmoucheté, fly-blown; alſo pinked, or ſet with little tufts.
Eſmouchette, the round tuft or head of herbs, wherein their ſeed is contained.
Eſmouellé, for émoellé, deprived of marrow.
Eſmouvement, a moving or ſtirring up; an agitation, wagging, or ſhaking up and down.
Eſmouveur, a mover, or ſtirrer up.
s'Eſmoyer de, earneſtly to ask, or enquire of.
Eſmundé, Eſmunder, Eſmundeur, as Emondé, Emonder, Emondeur in the N. D.
Eſmutir, Eſmutiſſement, as Emutir, Emeut in the N. D.
Eſor, as Oyſeaux eſors, wilde, unmade, or ill-manned Hawks.
Eſpagnolade, a Spaniſh trick, blow, bob.
Eſpagnollette, a band-ſupporter of wyre in works done over with ſilk.
Eſpaillier, as Eſpalier in the N. D.
Eſpalé, ſcattered abroad with a ſhovel.
Eſpaler, Eſpaller, to ſcatter (or to ſpread) abroad with a ſhovel.
Eſpalmé, pitched over as a ſhip.
Eſpamé, troubled with a cramp, or convulſion, faln into a ſwoon; alſo weakned, or made lean with faſting.
Eſpamer, to cauſe the cramp, or a convulſion-ſit; to weaken, or make lean.
Eſpampé, as roſes eſpampées, roſes fully blown.
Eſpamprement, the pruning of a Vine.
Eſpandable, which may be ſhed, ſpilled, or poured out.
Eſpandement, a ſhedding, ſpilling, or pouring out; alſo a ſpreading.
Eſpanir, to blow, or ſpread, as a blooming flower.
Eſparcet, a kind of thick graſs, or pulſe.
Eſparcetiere, a plot, or cloſe ſowed with Eſparcet.
Eſparer, to ſting with the heels. Le ciel commence à s'eſparer, the skie begins to break.
Eſparre, the bar of iron that is nailed on a door, and turns at the end on the hinge.
Eſpartillé, diſperſed, divided by partitions, infuſed by ſmall parcels.
Eſpartir, to ſcatter, diſperſe, part, or divide.
Eſparvain, a ſpavin in the leg of a horſe, &c.
Eſpasé, broad-footed, well underlaid, well ſpread, or well grounded.
Eſparement, the broad foot, or footing; the groundwork or foundation of.
s'Eſpater, to be broad-footed, or well underlaid; to ſpread, or bear a good breadth at the bottom, and thereby to be well-grounded or fixed.

Eſpave, a ſtray, a beaſt unowned; any thing whoſe original or owner is not known; a Stranger born in a far Country. Eſpave & effreinte des Chiens, a foul default of dogs, having utterly loſt both ſight and ſcent of the Game which they hunted.
Eſpave, (Adj.) maſterleſs, or without owner; alſo forrein, far-born, of unknown birth or beginning.
Eſpavent, a ſpavin in a horſe.
Eſpavité, the right a ſoverain Lord hath to the Lands or Goods of Strangers dying within his Dominions; or the being a ſtranger, as Eſpave.
Eſpaulart, a Sea-monſter, enemy to Whales.
Eſpaulée, as par eſpaulées, by fits, now and then.
Eſpauletée, as Eſpaulée. Refaire une muraille par eſpauletées, to repair a Wall by parcels, without taking any of it down.
Eſpaulette, a little ſhoulder; alſo the wing of a gown, doublet, &c. alſo a buttreſs, or ſhouldering-piece. Maſſonnerie à eſpaulettes, uneven work in walls, &c.
Eſpaulier, belonging to, or ſerving for the Shoulder.
Eſpaulure, a burſting, or unjoynting of the ſhoulder.
Eſpauſmure, a ſwooning, or falling into a trance.
Eſpectative, as eſtre à l'eſpectative, to ſtand waiting.
Eſpendre, as Epandre in the N. D.
Eſperable, fit to be hoped for, hopeful.
Eſperit, as Eſprit in the N. D.
Eſperlucat, a lock, or buſh of curled hair; alſo a neat or ſpruce companion.
Eſperonnade, Eſperonnement, a ſpurring, a prick with a Spar.
Eſperruqué, that wears long locks, or curled hair.
Eſpervain, a ſplint in a horſes leg.
Eſpeſſeur, Eſpeſſi, Eſpeſſir, Eſpeſſiſſement. See Epaiſſeur, Epaiſſi, Epaiſſiſſement in the N. D.
Eſpiceur, a taker, or taxer of fees.
Eſpiecé, piece-mealed, cut (broken, or torn) in pieces.
Eſpiecer, to cut, break, or tear in pieces.
Eſpieur, a ſpier, marker, obſerver. Eſpieur des chemins, a highway-robber.
Eſpinal, a thorny grove, or plot.
Eſpince, a pinching, nipping, or pricking.
Eſpinée, the chine, or back-bone of a Pork.
Eſpiner, to prick, as a thorn. s'Eſpiner, to prick himſelf; to intangle himſelf amongſt briars and thorns.
Eſpinees, ſplints in a horſes legs.
Eſpingarderie, the Harquebuzery, or a Troop of Harquebuſiers.
Eſpinglé, pinned, or furniſhed with pins.
Eſpingler, to pin, or furniſh with pins.
Eſpinguer, to ſpring, or leap ſprightly.
Eſpinoye, a thicket, or ground full of thorns.
Eſpis, the two utmoſt and fatteſt pieces of a ſide of Pork.
Eſplanaderaye, a plain way, or ſtrand.
Eſplaner, to make plane, to level.
Eſpleurer, to weep bitterly, to weep his eyes dry.
Eſploucher, as Eplucher in the N.D.
Eſployé, diſplayed. Aigle eſployée, a ſpread Eagle.
Eſpluquer, as Eplucher in the N. D.
Eſpluyer, to ſprinkle, or ſpatter upon.
Eſpoindre, to prick, or ſpur; to urge.
Eſpointement, an unpointing, a blunting, a breaking the point of. Eſpointement de queſtions, a pacifying of quarrels, a reſolution of queſtions.
Eſpois d'un Cerf, the top of a red Dears head; of a fallow the ſpellers.
Eſponce d'heritage, a quitting an Eſtate in land.
Eſponcer, to quit, or give over.
Eſporle, a Vaſſals acknowledgment of the Services and Duty's which he ows unto his Lord.
Eſporler, a Vaſſal to acknowledge the Duty's and Services he ows to his Lord.
Eſpoudrer, to duſt; to wipe the duſt off.
Eſpoventable, Eſpoventablement, Eſpoventail. See Epouvantable, Epouvantablement, Epouvantail in the N. D.
Eſpovente, Eſpoventé, Eſpoventer. See Epouvante, Epouvanté, Epouvanter in the N. D.
Eſpouiller, to louſe, or rid of lice.
Eſpouillereſſe, a woman that kills lice.
Eſpouſe, a diſeaſe in a horſe.
Eſpremaſon, the bloody flux, with a painful wringing of the bowels.
Eſpreu, tout à eſpreu, expreſly, of ſet purpoſe.
Eſprevains, a ſplint, or ſpavin in a horſes leg.
Eſpringalle, an ancient Engine of war whereout ſtones, pieces of iron, and great arrows were ſhot at the walls of a beſieged town.
Eſpringeller, to leap, ſpring, bound, or ſpurt.
Eſpucer, Eſpuceter, to flea, or to kill fleas.
Eſpuiſoir, any thing that ſerves to drain or empty a thing of moiſture; the hollow ſhovel wherewith water-men lade their leakie boats.
Eſpuration, the running of a ſore; alſo a cleanſing, or clarifying; alſo a ſtraining of liquor from.
Eſpurgé, purged out, cleanſed; alſo pruned.
Eſpurger, to purge, clean, or cleanſe; alſo to prune trees.
Eſquadre, Eſquadron, as Eſcadre, Eſcadron in the N. D.
Eſquaille, Eſquailler, as Ecaille, Ecailler in the N. D.
Eſqualier, to level, or make even.
Eſqualle, Eſqualler, as Ecaille, Ecailler in the N. D.
Eſquarriſſcur, a ſquarer of ſtones, or timber.
Eſquarriſſcure, Eſquarrure, a ſquaring; alſo ſquareneſs.
Eſquartelé, Eſquarteler, as Ecartelé, Ecarteler in the N. D.
Eſquartelement, Eſquarteleure, Eſquartellement, a quartering, diſmembering, or tearing in pieces.
Eſquarter, for Ecarter, to ſcatter; alſo to empty quart-pots.
Eſquener, to break the back of.
Eſqueuillon, as Eſcouillon, or a ſpunge, or ſcowrer for a piece of Ordnance.
Eſqucuré, out of heart, much fallen away.
Eſquiavine, a beating of a ſtubborn and untoward • ade.
Eſquiche, the firſt rude or ſlight draught of a model of Platform for a building.
Eſquiché, imboſſed; rudely done, or ſlightly drawn.
Eſquicher, to imboſs; to make a ſlight draught of a Model or Platform.
Eſquignonné, cut, or broke off as a lump; alſo cut, or broke into lumps.
Eſquignonner, to cut, or break off a lump; alſo to cut, or break into lumps.
Eſquilleux, ſplinty, full of little ſplints or ſcales.
Eſquine, bois d'eſquine, the knotty and medicinal root of an Indian Bull-ruſh.
Eſraciné, rooted up, or plucked up by the root.
Eſraciner, to root up, or pluck up by the root.
Eſraillé, ſpread, or ſet wide open; ſtaring, ſtradling; alſo frayed. Oeil eſraillé, an eye whoſe lower lid is reverſed.
Eſraillement, a ſpreading abroad, or ſetting wide open; a ſtaring, ſtradling, fraying.
Eſrailler, to ſpread, or ſet wide open; to ſtare, to ſtraddle, to fray as in ſtarching.
Eſrené, broken-backed, unfit for Venerious acts.
Eſrener, to break, or cruſh the reins.
Eſſais de fourrage, ſcatterings, or leavings of ſodder.
Eſſangé, wet, as linnen before it be laid in the bucking-tub.
Eſſanger, to wet linnen before it be laid in the bucking-tub.
Eſſardé, dry, thirſty. Soif eſſardée, an extream thirſt.
Eſſart, a glade in a wood; alſo a piece of untilled ground.
Eſſaur, as Eſſor in the N. D.
Eſſedaires, a kinde of Warriers in old time, who marched in waggons, but fought on foot, and hard laid to retir'd again to their waggons.
Eſſemé, inſ • amed, unfattened; alſo ſwarmed.
Eſſemement, an inſeaming, or unfattening; alſo a ſwarming.
Eſſemer, to inſeam, to unfatten; alſo to ſwarm.
Eſſencié, made, or become of one eſſence with.
Eſſencier, to make, or become of one eſſence with.
Eſſepper, to cut the ſtock of.
Eſſeulé, left all alone, abandoned, forſaken.
Eſſenoücre, a common ſink, or ſewer.

Eſſil, a ſhingle, or thin boord of
wood, ſuch as we cover houſes with.
Eſſiller, to laviſh, or ſpend waſtfully.
Eſſilliere, the clout that's laid between the legs of an Infant.
Eſſoin, as Eſſaim, a ſwarm of bees.
Eſſoine, as Exoine; alſo want of ability in Souldiers to defend or beſiege a place.
Eſſongne, Droict d'Eſſongne, a Duty or Fine payable (in Brittany) by the Heir or Succeſſor of a deceaſed Tenant unto the Lord, under whoſe Cenſive he held, and injoyed land at the time of his death.
Eſſonier, to eſſoin, to excuſe, or diſcharge an abſent or impotent perſon, &c.
Eſſort, as Eſſor, the open air.
Eſſoyné, weakened, diſabled, made impotent; alſo eſſoined, whoſe abſence is excuſed by reaſon of his impotency.
Eſſoyner, to weaken, to diſable; alſo to eſſoin, or excuſe.
Eſſuccer, to ſuck up, to draw dry, to drain.
Eſſueil, the threſhold of a door.
Eſtablage, ſtabling for horſes; alſo a fee due for their ſtanding in an Inne, &c. alſo as Eſtallage, ſtallage.
Eſtablement, ſtabling, or ſtanding for horſes.
Eſtagues, the tyes, two ropes ſerving to ho • ſe up the ſail.
Eſtabli, Eſtablir, and Eſtablier, a ſtall.
Eſtablies, Companies, Squadrons, or Battalions of Souldiers.
Eſtacquer, to mark for his own, to ſet his mark upon.
Eſtaffillade, as Eſtafilade in the N. D.
Eſtager, Eſtagier, a Vaſſal, Subject, or Inhabitant; one that hath a houſe or dwelling under a Lord.
Eſtagné, guelt, or lopped, as a tree.
Eſtagner, to gueld trees, to lop or cut off their branches.
Eſtagues, the tyes, two ropes ſerving to hoiſe up the ſail.
Eſtaie, Eſtaier, as Etaie, Etaier in the N. D.
Eſtail, as Etal, a ſtall. Il leur tient eſtail, he holds them tack.
Eſtaillé, handſomely clipt, or ſhorn; ſo cut as he looks as a Lion.
Eſtailleures de pierres, ſhards of ſtones.
Eſtaillier, a Stall-man, he that looks to the ſtall, and there expoſes his ware to ſhew and ſale.
Eſtails, tyes; the ſtrings or ropes of ſails.
Eſtainct, for Ereint, extinguiſhed, quenched, put out; ſpent, conſumed.
Eſtainier, of, or belonging to tin or pewter.
Eſtallage, as Etalage, the laying out of Wares upon a ſtall.
Eſtallé, Eſtaller, as Etalé, Etaler in the N. D.
Eſtallement, the ſtall of a ſhop; alſo as Eſtallage.
Eſtallon, Eſtallonné, Eſtallonnement, Eſtallonner, as Etalon, Etalonné, Etalonnement, Etalonner in the N. D.
Eſtallonnage, or Eſtalonage, as Etalonnement in the N. D.
Eſtambor, the ſtern-poſt in a ſhip.
Eſtambres, the partnours in a ſhip.
Eſtamé, (an Adj.) tinned, or done over with tin; glazed, made ſmooth, and ſtick, as an earthen veſſel.
Eſtamineux, uſing a ſtrainer; alſo fit to make a ſtrainer of.
Eſtamper, to ſupport with treſtles; alſo to brui • apples.
Eſtamperche, a great upright beam in buiding; a principal poſt.
Eſtancer, as Etançonner, to prop, to underprop.
Eſtanche, a ſtanching. Pierre d'eſtanche, a bloud-ſtone.
Eſtanſon, Eſtanſonné, & Eſtanſonner, as Etançon, Etançonné, & Etançonner in the N. D.
Eſtanterol, part of a ſhip near unto the ſtern.
Eſtaphe, a ſtirrup for a ſaddle.
Eſtappe, as Etape in the N. D.
Eſtaudir, to ſhelter under a ſtall.
Eſtaudy, a ſcaffold, in building; alſo a ſtall before a ſhop; alſo a defence of boards uſed in approaches, or 〈◊〉 the entring of a breach.
Eſtay, the ſtay, a rope faſtened to the top of the main-maſt, and holding it ſteady when the mainſail is hoiſed up.
Eſteindement, for Eteignement, an extinguiſhing, quenching, or putting out.
Eſteinte, an extinguiſhment. Gambadans à eſteinte de chandelle, till the candle went out.
Eſtelé, for Eroilé, ſtarry, or full of ſtars; alſo having (as an horſe) a ſtar in the forehead.
Eſteler, to ſet thick with ſtars. Eſteler les chevaux. See Atteler in the N. D.
Eſtellage, ſtallage; alſo as Attelage in the N. D.
Eſtelle, a rod, or ſtick; alſo a little ſtar, and the vowel of a ſpur.
Eſteller, as Etaler in the N. D.
Eſtellin, a Goldſmiths weight, containing 28 grains or the 20th part of an ounce.
Eſtellon, or Eſtelon, as Etalon in the N. D.
Eſtelloner, as Eſtalonner in the N. D.
Eſtencher, for Etancher, to ſtanch, or to ſtop • lood.
Eſtendement, Eſtendure, an extending, or ſtretching out.
Eſter, to ſtand, or continue in, to ſtick unto.
Eſterdre le beſtiail, to litter cattle.
Eſterlin, as Eſtellin, or a penny ſterling.
Eſternir, to ſtrew, ſpread, lay along.
Eſterniſſement, a ſtrewing, ſpreading, or laying along.
Eſtier, as Setier in the N. D.
Eſtincelletre, a little ſparkle, a ſmall twinkling.
Eſtiomene, S. Anthony's fire (a painful ſwelling full of heat and redneſs.)
Eſtiomener, to cut off the member ſo inflamed, or infected.
Eſtire, the iron tool wherewith a Currier drains the skins he receives from the Tanpit; ſome call it a Sle • ker.
Eſtiré, ſtretched, ſet on the tenter-hooks.
Eſtirement, a ſtretching, or ſetting on the tenter-hooks.
Eſtirer, to ſtretch, to ſet on the tenter-hooks.
Eſtival, of, or belonging to ſummer.
Eſtive, the loading of a ſhip; alſo the hold wherein moſt of the lading is contained.
Eſtivé, loaden, or laden (as a ſhip.)
Eſtiver, to ſummer, to paſs the ſummer in.
Eſtivet, a little ſummer. L'eſtivet de S. Martin, the latter end of autumn.
Eſtocage, a linage, or the chief ſtem of a linage.
Eſtoccader, to give the ſtoccado, to thruſt through.
Eſtoccage, 4 d. upon the ſale of an Inheritance, due in ſome places unto the Landlord, and to be paid him in lieu of a Relief the ſame day it is ſold.
Eſtocquer, as Eſtoccader, or as Eſtoquer.
Eſtoeuvier, of or belonging to a Tennis-ball.
Eſtoillé, the lizard Stellio, whoſe neck is full of ſtar-like ſpots.
Eſtoillée, the herb Lions-foot, Ladies-mantle, great Sani • l • .
Eſtoillette, a kinde of rich ſur.
Eſtoillins, an Order of Friars that wear ſtars on the breaſts of their gowns.
Eſtole, a ſtole (for the neck of a Prieſt.)
s'Eſtomaquer, to take pet, to be angry with.
Eſtomiſſeur, as un vieil eſtomiſſeur de ſacre, an old bangling or buzzing Saker.
Eſtoquant, giving the ſtockado unto; alſo reviling, railing at.
Eſtocqué, thruſt, ſtabbed into; alſo reviled, or railed at.
Eſtoquer, to thruſt, or give the ſtockado unto; to revile, or rail at.
Eſtorce, for Entorſe, a ſtrain; alſo a bad part, an unhappy turn played.
Eſtorcir, Eſtordre, to wring, wreſt, or pull out by force.
Eſtoré, built, erected; alſo furniſhed, ſtored. Tenir à Cour feſte haute & eſtorée, to keep at Court a plentiful feaſt.
Eſtorer, to build, or raiſe up; alſo to ſtore, or furniſh.
Eſtouillon, a fan to gather wind withal.
Eſtoupade, ſtoppage, or ſtopping. Eſtoupade des reins, a kernel about the reins.
Eſtouper, to ſtop, to make up.
Eſtouppade, as Eſtoupade; or a tent, or ſtopple of tow.
Eſtour, a ſight, ſhock, or incounter.
Eſtradiote, as chevaucher à l'eſtradiote, to ride long, or with long ſtirrups.
Eſtraigner, to wring, or gripe with the fiſt. Trop embraſſer & peu eſtraigner, to have too many irons in the fire at once.
Eſtrain, Straw, Litter, fodder of Straw or Stubble. De grand train ſur l'eſtrain, from keeping a great train into the ſtraw, that is unto beggary.
Eſtraindre, as Etreindre, to binde hard.
Eſtraine, for Etrene, a new-years-gift; a handſel.
Eſtrainte, as Eſtreinte; alſo a kinde of cloſe buckle or claſp for Cloaks, &c.
Eſtraieres, as Eſtrayeres, or as Eſpaves.
Eſtrangé, eſtranged, alienated, grown out of acquaintance.
Eſtrangement, an eſtranging, or alienating; a ſhunning of company; a quitting of all uſual faſhions.
Eſtranger, (a Verb) to eſtrange, to alienate, to ſeparate from. S'eſtranger de, to ſhun, or to avoid, to withdraw his minde from.
Eſtrangeté, ſtrangeneſs; a ſtrange act or accident; alſo rudeneſs, frowardneſs.
Eſtranguillon, as poire d'eſtranguillon, a choak-pear.
Eſtrappé, mowed, or cut down, as ſtubble.
Eſtrapper, as Etrapper, to mow, or cut down ſtubble.
Eſtrappoire, as Etrape, a kinde of little and long handled Cickle, wherewith ſtubble is cut down.
Eſtraſſier, one that cards or ſpins ruffled ſilk.
Eſtrave, the ſtem, or ſtem-poſt of a ſhip.
Eſtraver, to unſhackle, to free or deliver from ſhackles.
Eſtrayeres, Eſcheats, the goods of ſtrangers dead without Frenchborn iſſue, and of baſtards dead inteſtate, or without iſſue.
Eſtrée, a houſe, or place of abode.
Eſtreignement, a ſtraining, wringing, or ſqueezing.
Eſtreinte,, a ſtraining; a ſtrain; a ſilver girdle for women; or as Eſtrainte.
Eſtreintif, a reſtringent and binding medicine or plaiſter.
Eſtrelin, an Eaſterling, one of the eaſt parts, or of the Hanſe-towns of Germany; alſo a drunken ſwaggerer.
Eſtrelin, for Sterlin, Sterling. Livre eſtrelin, a pound ſterling.
Eſtrette, a wring, or pinch; a violent onſet on an enemy; alſo a kinde of puniſhment.
Eſtrez, a croſs of G •• les in Heraldry.
Eſtribort, the ſtar-board, or the right ſide of a ſhip.
Eſtrié, a kinde of bread or paſte of fine flower kneaded with water, white-wine, the yolk of eggs, ſalt, and ſugar.
Eſtrié, as un homme bien eſtrié, a man well ſoaked, or drawn dry by wenching.
Eſtrief, one of the three little bones that be ſeated far within the ear, and ſerve as inſtruments of hearing.
Eſtrier, (a Verb) to drain, or draw dry.
Eſtrilloir, that which is wrapped about thread in winding, to keep the fingers from being cut therewith.
Eſtrindore, a kind of brittiſh dance.
Eſtriqué, pulled on as a boot, &c. alſo as Eſtricqué.
Eſtriquer, to pull on boots, or boot-hoſe; alſo to force a wilde beaſt into the plain. S'eſtriquer, to prank up himſelf.
Eſtriver, to be contentious, to ſtrive, to contend; alſo to put his foot into the ſtirrup. Il eſtrive trop, he puts his foot too far into the ſtirrup.
Eſtronçonné, cut off by the trunk.
Eſtronçonner, to cut off by the trunk.
Eſtuvier, (Adj.) of or belonging to a ſtews.
Eſtuyer, to put into a caſe.
Eſtyrole, the looſneſs, or pilling of the skin about the root of the nails.
Eſvachir, to flag, to ſlack • n, or grow looſe.
Eſvent, the vent of a wine-veſſel.
Eſventelles, the ſails of a windmil.
Eſventeur, a fanner, or winnower of corn; alſo a vent-giver.
Eſventoir, Eſventoire, a fan, a flyflap.
Eſventoiſe, a vent in a cask, &c.
Eſviſagé, pulled by, or ſcratched on the face.
Eſviſager, to pull by, or ſcratch on the face.
Eſvolé, bra • en-faced; alſo ſhallow-brained, or hair-brained.
Eterni, thrown, or ſtuck down, laid ſtat along.
Eternizé, Eternizer, as Eterniſé, Eterniſer in the N. D.
Eteſies, the Eaſt-winds which commonly blow in the Dog-days.
Eteſtement, an heading, or lopping of trees.
Ethologie, a moral, an interlude of a moral ſubject.
Etiquet, as Etiquete in the N. D.
Etiqueté, noted, titled; alſo lodged by ticket.
Etiqueter, to note, to title; alſo to lodge by ticket. Etiqueter les Teſmoings, to deliver a Breviate concerning the Witneſſes names, and the points whereon they are to be examined.
Etiveler, to whiſtle, or whoop, as an hunter.
Etmoide, Os etmoïde, the bone whereof the top of the noſe is made.
Evader, to eſcape, to give the ſlip.
Evagation, a wandering, or ſtraying abroad.
Evaguer, to wander, ſtray, or rove.
Evaporall, an hole, pipe, or place to breath out at.
Evaſement, a wide opening, or wide ſpreading; alſo the wide, open, and hollow circumference of a thing.
Evaſer, to widen, to gape, to ſet wide open; alſo as Esbaſer.
Evé, watered, moiſtened, or mingled with water.
Evendiqué, claimed, or challenged; recovered by claim or challenge.
Event, as Eſvent, vent. Poulce & event, a thumbs breadth given between every ill in the meaſuring of cloath.
Eventation, eventing; alſo the opening of a vein.
Euër, to water, to moiſten, or mingle with water.
Everdumé, whoſe freſh taſte (and ſharpneſs) is decayed; alſo drained of juice.
Everdumer, to wring or ſqueez the green juice out of herbs, to take off their greeneſs, freſhneſs, or ſharpneſs.
Everſion, a ſ • bverting, or overthrowing.
Evertuément, laſtily, effectually, with all ones endeavour.
Evieux, as Eveux. Terre evieuſe, ſoil full of springs.
Eviré, without ſtrength, force, or • igour.
Eviſcerer, to bowel, to draw out the bowels or guts of.
Evitation, Evitement, an eſch • wing, hunning, or avoiding.
Euloge, a praiſe, or benediction; alſo a teſtimonial given of ones praiſe; an Epitaph; a last Will.
Evohe, the cry of mad men; or the ordinary acclamation of Bacchus his mad Prieſts.
Euphorbe, the poyſonous gummy thiſtle Euphorbium; alſo the cauſlick and congealed ſap or juice thereof.
Eur, & Eureux, as Heur, Heureux, in the N. D.
Euſtagues, Ropes in a ſhip called the Ties.
Evulſion, an evulſion, pulling up, or drawing out.
s'Exacerber, to be exasperated, or very angry.
Exagitation, a ſtirring up, a toſſing.
Exagité, toſſed, vexed, moleſted; alſo debated, or diſcuſſed throughly.
Exagiter, to toſs, •• x • or mol • ſt; to debate, or diſcuſs throughly.
Exalumin • ux, as p •• l • s exalumin •••• , bright, ſhining, orient P •••• .
Exa ••• ation, for Examen, examination, 〈◊〉 after.
Exangue, blo • dle • s; timoro •• s, fearful; pale.
Exanthemes, the ſmall pox; alſo wheals on the skin.
Exarcat, the chief place or dignity under the Emperour, the Lieutenancy of the Empire.
Exarche, a Vice-Emperour, or Lieutenant of the Empire.
Exaulcé, exalted, extolled; alſo perfectly heard and to the purpoſe.
Exaulcement, an exalting, or extolling; alſo a perfect and effectual hearing.
Exaulcer, to exalt, or extol; alſo to hear perfectly and effectually.
Excandeſcence, an inclination or promptneſs unto anger; an anger ſoon taken, ſoon come and gone.
Excentriquer, to diſcloſe, or lay open.
Excogiter, to excogitate, or earneſtly to conſider of.
Excortiquer, as Excorcer, to pill, or take off the rind from.
Excretion, the voiding of the ſuperfluities and excrements of the body.
Exemptible, free, quit; alſo that may be removed with eaſe.
Exenterer, to bowel, to take out the entrails.
Exequant, finiſhing, performing, executing; alſo proſecuting, purſuing; alſo expreſſing, declaring.
Exercité, practiſed, exerciſed, of good experience in.
Exfoliatif, as trepane exfoliatif, that go's no farther than the ſuperficies of the ſcull.
Exfoliation d'os,, an opening or taking up of the only ſuperficies of a bone.
Exherber, to weed out herbs, graſs, or weeds.
Exiguer, to give up a beaſt kept unto halves; to part the profit that hath been made or increaſe that hath come thereof.
Eximé, lean, drained, drawn dry; alſo exempted, freed, diſcharged from.
Eximer, as Eſſimer; alſo to exempt, free, or diſcharge from.
Exiture, an egreſs; alſo a ripe impoſtume.
Exoiné, eſſoined, excuſed for his a • ſence by reaſon of ſickneſs, or other lawful impediment, alledged and depoſed by another.
Exoineur, an Eſſoiner, or as Exoniateur,
Exolution, a faintneſs, or looſneſs in all the parts of the body.

Exoniateur, an Eſſoiner, an Attorney, &c. who ſ • lk ••• tly excuſes the abſence of another by ſwearing
or affirming that he is ſick, or not able to appear.
Exonié, eſſoyned, or excuſed; ſaved harmleſs.
Exonier, to eſſoyn, to excuſe one from appearing in Court, or going to Wars, by oath that he is impotent, &c. alſo, to ſave harmleſs.
Exoſtoſe, a ſwelling of the bones.
Expatriation, a baniſhment, or being out of his own Country.
Expatrié, baniſhed, or abſent from his own Country.
Explanade, a plain paſſage, an eaſie way.
Expletif, filling, making up; fulfilling, perfecting.
Exploictable, ſeiſable, liable unto an execution or ſeiſure.
Exploictation de biens, an execution of goods, or a ſeiſure of them by the King, a Court, or Landlord.
Exploicteur, a doer of an exploit. Sergent Exploicteur, the ordinary Serjeant for Seiſures, Executions, &c.
Expoſeur, an expoſer; alſo an expoſitor.
Exprobation, an upbraiding, or twitting in the teeth.
Exproprié, deprived of all propriety in.
Expugnable, which may be got by force.
Expugné, won by aſſault, overcome with violence.
Expulſé, expelled, thruſt out by force.
Expulſer, to expel, or thruſt out.
Exſiccatif, exſiccative, of a drying property.
Exficcation, a drineſs, or drying up of.
Extenſible, extenſible, which may be extended, or drawn out in length.
Extipiſcine, ſouthſaying by the inſpection of the entrals of beaſts.
Extiture, a ſhew, or ſtanding forth.
Extrajudiciaire, extrajudicial, done out of Court.
Extraneïſer, to drive, or baniſh into a forreign Country.
Extrayeur de proces, an abridger of Caſes, a breviate-maker.
Exuberance, exuberancy, abundance, great ſtore, or plenty.
Exuberer, to abound, to be plentiful.
Exulceratoire, exulcerating, eating into the fleſh.
Exuler, to baniſh, or to be baniſhed.
FAbagine, Judas-tree, the Tree wherein 'tis thought he hanged himſelf.
Fabrice, fabrick; the reparation, or maintenance of a Pariſh-Church; alſo the ſtate, or the eſtate of the Pariſh it ſelf.
Fabril, of ſtone or timber, of or belonging to the craft of a Smith, Maſon, or Carpenter.
Facet, a Primmer, or Grammar for a young Scholar.
Faciendaire, one that's employ'd in a buſineſs for another.
Facque, a little pocket; alſo as Faquin.
Fadeſeries, Fadeurs, for fadaiſes, trifles, ſilly things.
Fadoche, the name of a certain pear.
Fadrin, the Maſters Mate in a Ship, the Officer that hath the command of ſlaves in a Galley.
Fafiloches, ravellings of linnen or cloth.
Fagouë, a certain kernel under the Kannel-bone; alſo the fag-piece, or kernelly part next unto the neck of a Boar.
Faictis, made according to; alſo neat, or well-made.
Faille, fail; Sans faille, without fail. Alſo a round and oat-bearing Vail worn by Nuns and Widows of the better ſort.
Faillite, a failing, or want; a deceiving, or diſappointing; waſting; fainting. Payer ſes Creanciers en faillites, to pay his Creditors in Papers.
Faine, a Beech-tree; alſo a Beech-maſt, or Buck-maſt; the fruit of the Beech-tree.
Faintiſe, for feintiſe, a feigning, or diſſembling.
Fais, a bundle, a burden, or load.
Faiſances, as Corvées, in the N. D.
Faiſanneau, for faiſandeau, a young Pheaſant.
Faiſannier, a keeper, or breeder of Pheaſants.
Faiſt, for faîte, top, ridge, or roof.
Faitifs, Faitis, and Faitiſſé, as Faictis.
Faizander, as faiſander in the N. D. or elſe to dreſs a Pullet or Capon like a Pheaſant.
Fal, a Player, or Playing-ring, in a bit.
Faldes, a pair of Baſes to ride with.
Fallevuches, the sparkles ariſing from Furnaces wherein metals are melted.
Faloiſe, for falaiſe, a bank, down, or hill by the Sea-ſide.
Faloppe, the Chit, Meadow-lark, or H • ath-lark.
Falotier, of, or belonging to a Creſſet-light.
Falouze, Harts fodder, or Harts eye.
Famé, of good report, or reputation.
Familiarizer aucun, to grow familiar with one.
Fan • gue, a meaſure that contains about as much as the French buſhel.
Fanfrelucher, to ſwive; alſo to trifle it.
Fanfreluches, looſe threads in rags and torn clothes; any ſuch traſh; or as finfreluches. Fanfreluches antidotées, ſopperies.
Fangas, a heap of mud, or dirt.
Fangeas, Fangeat, a dirty, or muddy ſlough on the highway.
ſe Fanir, to wither, to fade.
Fantaſie, as fantaiſie in the N. D.
Fantaſ • é, fanci'd, imagined, feigned; alſo affected.
Fantaſier, to fancy, to imagine, to think of; to affect.
Fantaſine, for fantôme, a Viſion, an Apparition.
Fantaſſin (Adj.) of, or b • longing to a Foot-ſouldier.
Fantaſtiquer, to conceive, imagine, or deviſe; to affect fantaſtically; to fill with (or feed on) idle fancies.
Fantoſmeries, ſtrange fancies, extravagant conceits, caſtles in the air.
Faquinage, portage, the fee or furniture belonging to the Porter.
Far, an high Tower, or Beacon at the mouth of an Haven, wherein continual lights are kept a nights for the direction of Sea-faring people • ; a Lanthorn on a Watch-tower by the Sea-ſide.
Farain, pain farain, a kind of great and very yellow houſhold-bread of the better ſort.
Faras, a great confuſed heap; alſo a mixture of ſundry Grains together, called Bolymong.
Faraſſe, a Creſſet, alſo courſe Tow.
ſe Farcer de, to deride at.
Farcereau, a maker of Plays; a deviſer of Jeſts; an inventer of Lyes.
Farcerie, a playing, or jeſting; an acting, or making of Plays; a counterfeiting.
Farciere, one of the three skins that wrap an Infant in the womb.
Fardeler, to pack up into bundles.
Farfadet, a little ſpirit, a young hobgoblin.
Farfelu, ſhort and thick, as thick as long.
Fariboles, idle diſcourſes, tales of a tub.
Farineux, done over with meal; alſo dry as meal.
Faron, the week of a Link, or Torch.
Faroucheté, b • come wild and cruel.
Farrage, a mixture of Grains and Seeds ſowed together for Winter-forrage, or •• dder.
Farragiere, a piece of ground ſowed with the winnowings of Corn, or with courſe Corn and Pulſe mingled all together.
Faſciné, charmed, bewitched; diſfigured, or transformed by inchantments.
Faſciner, to charm, to bewitch, to disfigure, or transform by inchantments.
Faſſade, for façade, the front of a building.
Faſſe, a Weel, or a Bow-net.
Fatalizer, to deſtinate, appoint, or deſigne to an inevitable iſſue.
Fatraſſé, patched, botched; confuſedly put together; alſo vain, idle; made, or conſiſting of traſh.
Fatraſſier, trifling, vain; confuſed, huddled together.
Fatrer, to botch, patch, or bungle up a thing.
Fatrouiller, to play the fop, to buſie himſ lf about idle things; alſo as fatrer, to botch.
Fatrouilleur, a trifler; alſo a bungler.
Favas, as faval; alſo a bean- • l ••• , a b ••• - •• raw.
Faucer, to ſt ••• d, as a crook • d blade.
Fau • ha • e, a mowing, or the • ire of a 〈◊〉

Fauch •• o •

Fau ••••
a 〈◊〉 to • to mow with.
Fau • hon, a ha • g • r.
Faudiere, the skirt-piece of an armour.
Faverots, a kinde of ſmall beans, or as
Faulcé, as fauſſé in the N. D.
Fauldetueil, for fauteuil, a great elbow-chair.
Faulſaire, faul • é, faulſe-braye. See them with a • s inſ •• ad of 〈◊〉 t •• N. D.
Faulſée, a breach; alſo a ſtriking, or charging through and through.
Faulſer, faulſer, and faulſe, as fauſſer, fauſſet, fauſſe, u • der faux in the N. D.
Faulſeteux, moſt falſe, full of lies.
Faultif, faulty, apt to do amiſs.
Faulveret, as Fauvete in the N. D.
Favorite, a She-favorite, a Princes Miſtriſs.
Fauſonnerie, a forging, or falſifying of evidences, a falſe counterf •• ting of another mans hand.
Fauteur, a favo • rer, f • rtherer, helper; a p •• taker, a companion.

Fauveau, a d • n • or •• ; alſo a P ••
•• n, or fork-fi • h; alſo ( 〈…〉 ) dark, yellow, d ••• , ſomewhat fallow.

Faux- •• rcher,
〈…〉 , or go awry: to ſ • ip, or ••• bl • .
Faux-marc •• r • , a 〈◊〉 got by a ſhip, or 〈…〉 .
Faux oiſeau, as fouperdrieux; or any hawk in general.
Fayerie, as fé • rie; alſo a fan • y, illuſion, or viſion of Fairies.
Fayfort, a warranting of the goodneſs, and ſufficienty of ſale-ware.
Fay • ſe, a ſwath-band for a childe.
Fé, for ſoi, Faith. Fé Dieu, Gods me.
Feage, Fee-ſimple; or an Inheritance or houſe held in Fee-ſimple.
Febé, a ſecret ſtory, a thing hidden.
Febri • itant, ſick of an ague, or feaver.
Febril, of, or belonging to an agu • , or ••• er.
Feconder, to make fertile, or fruitful.
Fecot, the youngling of an ew (or of any other ſuch beaſt) newly • ome out of •• r b • lly.
Fecture, the fri • hing, o • making up of.
F •• ulent, thi •• , m • ddy, dreggy.
Feine, b •• ch-maſt▪ alſo a kinde of Cider-appl • .
Felerin, Fla •••• , or a 〈◊〉 like it.
Felice, happy; alſo fertile, • r • itful.
F • lle, a kind of • h • - •• t.

Fellon, Fello •• e, as fel ••
▪ felonie in the N. D.
Felure, a flaw, or ſmall crack.
Femier, a Bayliff, or overſeer of the husbandry in a Gentlemans houſe.
Femmette, a little woman, or wife.
Fendant, a great flaſh, or cut.
Fendillé, cloven, broke into ſmall chinks.
Fendiller, to cleave, to break in ſmall chinks.
Fendu, (Subſt.) the ſlit of a thing.
Feneſtrage, windows; the faſhion, or contrivement thereof.
Feneſtrier, belonging to a window; alſo placed in, or looking out at a window.
Fenons, outward ſplints (made of ſticks about a finger thick; firſt wrapped in hay or ſtraw, then within a piece of linnen.)
Fenugrec, the herb, or ſeed Fennigreek.
Feodalité, the eſtate of a Feodal or chief.
Fereules, the thing whereon Images or Pageants are carried; alſo coffins.
Ferial, of, or belonging to a holy-day; idle, •••• ing, vacant; jocund, merry, pleaſant; alſo ridiculous.
Feriat, a vacation-time, an idle (or a play) day.
Fermail, the claſp of a book, &c.
Fermaille, a ſmall claſp, or buckle.
Fermailles, for fiançailles, a formal betrothing of a couple before their full marriage.
Fermaillé, claſped, buckled; alſo garniſhed, or ſet thick with ſmall buckles.
Fermailler, to buckle, to claſp; alſo to ſet or garniſh with ſmall buckles.
Fermailler, (a Subſt.) a buckle-maker, or claſp-maker.

Fermailler, a ſmall buckle or claſp; alſo a carkanet, or border of gold, ſuch as Gentlewomen wear about their heads or hoods; alſo an inchanted image, collar, or chain worn about the neck, as a preſervative againſt poiſon, witchcruft, wounds, &c.
Fermance, a certain Officer within the Juriſdiction of La Solle.
Fermant, (Subſt.) a buckle, haſp, or claſp; alſo a ſhutter; any thing that ſurely bindes or faſtens.
Fermative, an affirmation, or proteſtation of right unto a thing in controverſie, made before a Judge by him that pretends it.
Fermement, (Subſt.) a ſhutting, locking, cloſing, or making up.
Fermeture, Fermeure, a ſhutting, locking, cloſing, or making up.
Fermier, (Adj.) farming. Sergent fermier, that hath farmed his place (which by law he ſhould not do.)
Fermoirs, the claſps of a book; or as fremoirs.
Fernel, a certain beam in the prow of a Ship.

Ferrage, the ſhooing of horſes; alſo any work, or working in Iron. Droict de ferrage, a Priviledge whereby ſome ſpecial Officers and followers of Court claim to have their horſes ſhod at the Kings charge; alſo a certain fee due to the cutters of the Mint.
Ferraſſe, the Fork-fiſh; alſo courſe tow.
Ferrat, ſhod (as a horſe) with iron.

Ferrementiporte, a wandring Prieſt that ever carries about him the Ornaments or implements belonging to the Maſs, called, ferremens de la Meſſe; alſo a carrier of tools, or heads of Spears, or blades of Weapons.
Ferret, the tag of a point.
Ferreur, a flax-comb, or hatchel of Iron.
Ferreux, of Iron, as hard as Iron.
Ferriere, a kinde of big Dutch leathern bottles; alſo a place to keep Iron in; a pouch to put horſenails in &c. a kinde of adamant.
Ferronnier, for ferron, an Ironmonger, one that ſells unwrought Iron in bars, &c.
Ferrumination, a ſodering, or faſtening together, properly in matters of Iron.
Ferve, par ferve, according to, after the rate of.
Ferveſti, Ferveſtu, clad in, or armed with Iron.
Ferulacé, round; alſo of the kinde of the herb Ferula.
Ferules, ſplents for broken legs, arms, fingers, &c.
Ferun, rankneſs, rammiſhneſs; extream or ſtrong unfavourineſs.
Ferure, a ſtroke, or hit; a ſtriking, or hitting.
Feſſe-breviaire, a Prieſt that quickly whips over, or mumbles up, his breviary; any one that ſays over his ordinary prayers too faſt.
Feſſée, a laſh on the breech.
Feſſe-pinte, a good-fellow, one that can drink luſtily.
Feſſe-tondue, a hawdy companion; a ſmall-ſmock.
Feſſier, belonging to the breech, or buttocks.
Feſſiſier, to play tricks with the buttocks.
Feſt, for faite, top, or ridge. Gibet à feſt, a Gibbet that hath a topping or chaplet made over it.
Feſtard, and Feſtardiſe, as fetard, fetardiſe.
Feſte, for faite, the ridge, or top of a houſe.
Feſter, to feaſt it, to keep holy day.
Feſtide, for fâcherie, grief, or trouble.
Feſtier, for fêtoyer, to treat, or entertain his friends.
Feſtiere, for faitiere, a ridge-tile, or (being turned) a gutter-tile.
Fetiſſe, as liqueurs fetiſſes, made, or compounded liquours.
Feton, as feſton in the N. D.
Fetuſé, touched, or wiped over with a feſcue; alſo tickled by ſuch a touching.
Fetuſer, to touch, or wipe over with a feſcue; alſo to tickle by touching with a feſcue.
Feverondes, the eaves of an houſe.
Feugiere, for fougere, fern. Feugiere de cheſnes, the herb Oakfern.
Feultré, made of felt, covered with felt.
Feultrer, to make of, or cover with felt.
Feulu, for feuillu, full of leaves.
Feur, the coſt and charge a husbandman is at in the tilling and reaping of his ground; alſo a fair; a rate or price ſet on a thing.
Feurmariage, as formariage in the N. D.
Feutraict, drawn out of his Country; alſo wine, corn, &c. take the 〈◊〉 .

Feutré, wrought thick as •• lt; alſo ſtuffed, or •• iſtened with felt. Feutré d'herbe,
〈◊〉 thick, or overgrown with g •• ſs.
Feytura • e, a charm, or inchantment.
Fia •••• lſ • , for F •• nç ••• es, a formal but 〈◊〉 of a Couple before their 〈◊〉 marriage.
Fibreux, full of hair-like threads, or ſtrings.
Fichet, as arbre de fichet, a tree that is come of a twig or tender ſcion planted.
Fiche • re, a fixing, or faſtening.
Ficotte, as par ma ficotte, by my feckins.
Fidelium, the laſt Prayer that's ſaid for the dead. Il paſſe pluſieurs choſes par un fidelium, he huddles up many things under one.
Fidicule, the Harp of Heaven, a company of ſtars which reſemble an Harp.
Fiduciale, the index or hand of an Aſtrolabe.
Fied, & Fieffe, for fief, a Fief.
Fiefvement, a feoffement, or an infeoffing.
Fielleux, fall of bitterneſs, as bitter as gall.
Fienteux, full of dung, or ordure.
Fieret, ſomewhat lofty, a little fierce.
Fiereté, Fierettement, as fierté, fierement in the N. D.
il Fiertà, 'tis like unto, or agrees well with.
Figueraye, Figuerie, Figuiere, a ground f • ll of fig-trees.
Figurement, a figuring, ſhaping, or forming.
Figurine, a pretty little image, or figure.
Filace, as filaſſe in the N. D.
Filacier, ready, or eaſie to in • pun.
Filandiere, a spi •••• r, a flax-woman; alſo a ki •• of ſmall boat.
Fila ••• é, full of ſmall threads or ſ ••• s.
Filerie, a spinning, or spinſtry; alſo a friendly meeting between the young men and maids of a Countrey-Town, where they play at many ſorts of active Games, while theſe both ſpin and look on.
Filiation, the being or eſtate of a ſon.
Filipende, Filipendule, filipendula, Dropwort, red Saxifrage.
Fillains, the tackling of a ſhip.
Fillaſſe, as filaſſe in the N. D. La fillaſſe de noſtre Dame, the ſmall and tender ſtrings of a Cobweb.
Fille-femme, one that goes for a maid, but is none; a crackt piece; alſo one that has got a clap.
Fillet, a watering bit for a horſe.
Fillette, a young girl; alſo a ſmall wine-veſſel.
Filliere, as filiere in the N. D.
Fillole, a buddy knob in a Vine, like a wart.
Filon, a vein of metal in a Mine.
Fimport, a c • urſe in Law, binding a Plaintiff to ſ • tch in, and make joyn in ſuit with him, all ſuch as can pretend any right or intereſt in the thing which he means to recover.
Fimporter, a Plaintiff to do as aforeſaid.
Finage, the ſmalleſt tackling of a ſhip.
Finages, the utmoſt limits or liberties, the utmoſt bou •• ds or borders of a Country or City.

Finaiſon, as quand argent ſaut finaiſon nulle,
〈◊〉 gain, or ſatiſfaction, without money.

Fine de poules,
•• as d • ng, or ordare.
Finement, (Subſt.) an ending, or finiſhing; in end, or concluſion.
Finer, for ſinir, to end, or to finiſh.
Finerot, as chemin finerot, a way that is about 18 foot broad.
Finiteur, the circumference of a Pillar from the top to the bottom thereof.
Fique, par ma fique, by my feckins.
Frealins, children, or freed men, maintained or nouriſhed in the Kings houſe, or upon h •• land.
Fiſq, as Fiſque in the N. D.
Fiſſaye, a quick and violent dance much uſed by the French.
Fiſtuleux, full of fiſtula's, or of holes like a ſpunge.
Fivatier, a Copy-holder, or cuſtomary Tenant, properly the Vaſſal or Tenant of a Lord Cavier.
Flabellation, a fanning, or giving wind unto.
Flabellé, fanned, that hath wind given to it.
Flacconner, to •• y the pot, to drink hard.
Flacquer, to mak • a thing to ſ ••• .
Flagorneur, a tale-teller, a pick-thank, a ſecret accuſer.
Flagrance d'un delict, the plain apparency, or pa •• ableneſs, of an offence; the crying of a ſin.
Flagrant, flaming, burning. Prendre au faict flagrant, to apprehend upon the deed doing, or preſently after.
Flaine, a tick for a bed.
Flaironner, to ſcent, ſmell, or vent.
Flaiſtri, Flaiſtrir, Flaiſtriſſure. See flètri, flètrir, flètriſſure in the N. D.
Flaman, Flambant, a kind of Sea-fowl, of the bigneſs of a Stork, and indifferent good meat.
Flambe, flame, a great blaze of fire; alſo the blue flower de lace.
Flambillon, a ſmall flame, light, or link.
Flambo, a kind of long, ſlender, and flame-coloured Sea-fiſh.
Flamiche, a kind of better bread than ordinary; alſo a kinde of cake.
Flammette, a little flame; the herb Crowfoot; a kind of la ••• t.
Flammie, the Office, or Dignity of a Pagan Arch-Prieſt.
Flammuie, the herb called upright Clamberer, or upright Virgins bower; alſo the herb Spear-wort, or Spear-crowfoot.

Fl • n •••
a ar •• g •• -horſes drawing 〈◊〉 , theſe that run along his 〈◊〉

Flaſſade, the covering of a bed; alſo the daintieſt kinde of Ray, or ſmooth Thornback.
Flaſtereau, a kind of flat Naveau.
Flaſtri, marked, burnt, or branded with an hot iron.
Flaſtrir, to mark, burn, or brand with an hot iron.
Flatant, Flatard, flattering, or ſawning on.
Flatement, a flattering, or fawning on.
Flatereau, one that flatters a little.
Flatereſſe, a flattering, or coxing woman.
Flatré, branded in the forehead, bored through the ear, marked for a knave.
Flatrer, to brand, burn, or mark with a hot iron.
Flatriſſement, a branding, burning, or marking with a hot iron; a publick mark, or diſgrace.
Flattir, to heat, or mak • flat.
Flatucux, Flatulent, flatulent, windy, full of windy humours.
Fleble, for foible, feeble, or weak.
Flecheurs, bowers, the muſcles that ſerve to bow the joynts of the fingers.
Flechiſſure, a bending, or bowing; alſo crookedneſs.
Flegart, a common place, or way.

Flegmon, a hot and 〈◊〉
• welling or inflammation of blood.
Fleichade, a wound or • rick of an arrow.
Flet • let, a • Hall • b •• -fi • h.
Flettan, the greate • t k ••• of Salt-fiſh.
Fl •• te, a • ighter, a ſmall or 〈◊〉 a ſl •• nder.
Fleurant, ſmelling, or caſting a ſcent.
Fleureter, lightly to paſs over; to vent, or wind; alſo to ſneak, or cave-drop it.
Fleuretis de paroles, an idle flouriſh of words.
Fleurette, for petite fleur, a little flower.
Fleureux, ſtored with choice of flowers; alſo fragrant, ſweet-ſmelling.
Fleurin, for florin, a Low-Country Coyn worth about 11 s. ſterl.
Fleuronné, flouriſhing; ſet thick with flowers.
Fleurtis, a flouriſh, or flouri hing. Fleurtis des oyſillous, the warbling of little birds.
